content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												Just beat F.E.A.R. 3, making me beat every single F.E.A.R. game, okay review time, this game, while not bad, was good in aspects and bad at everything else. let alone, as a fan of the series, this game was kinda a let down too me. I enjoyed the fast pace combat, but it took out all stragity that made the first and second games a hard deal, you actual had to plan out your combat route, know when to use slow-mo, and keep ur wits on guard, Playing as paxton can be pretty fun aswell, as it's a diffrent kinda play to the Series. slo-mo in F.E.A.R. 3 had sometimes almost no propose because by time u use it, its gone already, F.E.A.R. 3 compared to the others had minimum to no horror aspect, no dark atmosphere, and quite frankly, the story line was poor and kinda boring. they tried to escalate the matter of the situation, without telling us why it's happening. Taking out the replica forces made NO sense to me, and they never Evan explain why there not there, i mean they were in 2, and still being controlled, so why not in 3, and why the ♥♥♥♥ is point man in captivity when at the end of F.E.A.R. 1 he escaped with his team. F.E.A.R. 3 has beautiful graphics, smooth game play, brutal combat, and an interesting Ranking system. As for story line, atmosphere, tone, and excitability, it was a huge let down, i have to say by far F.E.A.R. 2 was the best in the series. F.E.A.R. 3 just feels more like call of duty when it trys to be creepy. this is a great stand alone game, esp for FPS fans, but for personal fans of the F.E.A.R. Series as a whole, this is just a disappointment. hopefully, if they make another game, they will try to make it less "Call of dutyish" and return to the Dark, disturbing, amazing storyline that F.E.A.R. use to be. What they gained in making fast paced action game play, made it less horror, and less stragidy and more just shoot shoot shoot. and where are my martial arts melee attacks that were so fun to pull off. like i said though, good standalone game, but with the F.E.A.R. logo, its a let downStandalone game: 7/10F.E.A.R. Game: 4/10

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												I always heard bad things about F.E.A.R. 3 and the first few hours of me playing it gave me all I need to make my own opinion about the game. If you're a fan of the original F.E.A.R. you turn back right now, otherwise you'll most likely loose your admiration for this franchise. To be honest I didn't really liked F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin as much as I liked the first F.E.A.R. game and it's expansions, it did have the F.E.A.R. feel to it but for me it wasn't as good as the original. But now, F.E.A.R. 3 is where they've messed up everything, everything I liked about the previous games was gone. First, there's no medkits or reflex boosts on the game because you now have regenerating health and you unlock levels, and yes I do mean actual ingame levels, by scoring points, I feel like they tried making F.E.A.R. 3 a kinda of score attack game but making it similar to modern first person shooters. So, if there's no medkits and reflex boosts there's not that much of incentive to go through each level exploring and trying to find hidden stuff to make your life easier... but then again they've changed that, most of the hidden stuff that you can now find in F.E.A.R. 3 are corpses which you can "connect to" and gain points by doing so and also finding some weird little statues that I also believe that give you points. Everytime you level up you can gain an increase to HP, increased time that you can use your slow time and increased ammo for each gun. I pretty much hate when developers nowadays make first person shooters with regenerating health because that basicly just means that everytime you're on low health you just need to get behind a wall and wait for your health to regenerate which I find to be somewhat, dumb. And now the guns. I thought that the shooting from F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin was easier than the original F.E.A.R. but hell did they make it Call of Duty style on F.E.A.R. 3, you can pretty much just spray and pray with any gun without aiming down sights and you'll still get the kills even in long range with a shotgun, I realize that this might be appealing to some people out there but for a guy like me who likes guns to have a real kick to them and feel authentic when shooting and having the need to compensate recoil and spray patterns I find this Call of Duty style of gun handling to be really frustrating, so what's a first person shooter with shooting that people don't like?, yeah. And now, the story, maybe it was just me but I had the feeling during the whole game that the game was trying to shove you the story all the time, I didn't really get much of it and also they did it in kind of a weird way. I think F.E.A.R. 3 was designed as a co-op game because everytime there's a cutscene, and yes there's now cutscenes on a F.E.A.R. game, it's always the two brothers talking and by the time it ends you have the feeling that you're supposed to start a mission with you and your brother fighting the "bad guys" but no, there's just one of you there, and I find that to be rather weird because a few seconds ago there were two people there, couldn't they just put the other brother as an AI companion? One thing I certainly have to mention is that the enemy AI, mainly the soldiers is pretty well made, everytime you try to get behind cover they try to flank you while others distract you by providing supressive fire and enemies usually always go looking for cover as soon as they spot you and they even flip furniture in order to get cover behind it. The last thing I really hated about F.E.A.R. 3 and I'm sure many people will agree with me on this, is that the game despite looking pretty damn good it isn't scary at all, the F.E.A.R. franchise was supposed to be abunch of scary first person shooters with some paranormal elements and that ocurred in the previous game but in this one it kinda turned into a demonic invasion, creatures spawning from the walls through some kind of portals and at the end nothing pretty much made any sense to me, for me F.E.A.R. 3 looked more like fighting a demonic invasion other than fighting horror  and Alma and they pretty much failed on the scary and tense component from the previous games. The first F.E.A.R. was very tense and spooky, F.E.A.R. 2 was not that much but it still had some tense sections and some ocasional jumpscares while F.E.A.R. 3 is just a run and gun shooter. As you can clearly see I did not liked F.E.A.R. 3 at all, it is certainly a good game but not what I expected from a F.E.A.R. game. If you're a fan of the F.E.A.R. franchise I advise you not to play this or only playing it if you're curious about the story but if you haven't played any of the F.E.A.R. games you might enjoy your time with this one, I don't know honestly. Personally I don't recommend this one.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												I have always been an avid fan of the FEAR franchise. Fear 3 is the 3rd and probably most unique installment of this franchise. I am wondering if this should be considered the last one or WB is planning to publish another episode sometime in the near future.In Fear 2 we skipped the story of the good old Point Man, our protagonist from the 1st episode, and now we pick up his tale from where we were left off. Paxton also returns and this gives a game a unique experience as coop campaign is now available. Paxton can jump into enemies and take over them for a short period of time. On his own he is rather weak but once you possess a soldier you can use his weapons and should you be eliminated you can quickly find another host.Sequences with the Mech also return and they are more devastating than ever. There are more monsters now so it seems the developers upped the horror-like nature of the game a bit. Single player is relatively long and with the 2nd protagonist (Paxton) you have replayability here which is good news. The field where Fear 3 really shines is multiplayer. There are various game modes out there that are interesting and challenging, too. In F**king Run, for example, you are running away from a wall that means instant death once it reaches you. While running away you also need to eliminate the oncoming waves of enemies and cooperation is a must as if anybody from your team is caught by the wall that's game over for the entire group. I liked Fear 3. For me the best is the 2nd episode in this trilogy but the 3rd installment also offered an exciting action-horror experience and while I do not really favour the approach of releasing more and more sequels for a game I would be delighted to play a possible 4th episode.

Posted: February 6
												Fast, action packed with really nice graphics - what more can you want.Underrated and over criticised - in my experiencew quite a few reviews are just unfair, particularly where graphics, performance and gameplay are concerned.Im on Windows 10 and it runs flawlessly in 4K, looks really nice, as an example the sunset  coming through a window and displayed on a wall. But ive got a good TV and ive got the settings configured to make it look nice.Yeh its not not just your GPU and the game, set your TV to complement the graphics.I dont know why the AI gets dumped on so much - seems pretty good to me - enemies take cover most of the time and run around trying to outflank you, i aint come across any AI better than that and i aint come across any AI that was intelligent, cos its AI, its a computer.And if a game aint the same as one you played 10 years ago you gotta get over it - it aint fair on the Devs.Im loving the action and the sweet, fast responsive controls make it really exciting, your hit you dash - recover - you melee after creeping up on your foe - then theres one behind you pumping a shotgun and you gotta get away again - superb.Plus theres some good challenges.The camera - always a critical thing for me is near perfect and the 360 controller handles it great.Could have done with a map window though.Well worth the money.I believe in reviewing games in the first couple of hours, cause im a game player, i love video games, when i find one i wanna play i can play excessively till im knackered and irritated, it aint fair on the Devs to review a game when ive overplayed it.Enjoy.

Product received for free
												The weakest link of the F.E.A.R series. This is more like an action shooter than a horror shooter, the co-op is fun and takes about 3 or so hours. I'd advise you to get F.E.A.R 1 or 2, or even both instead of this. If you're a hardcore fan and want to see the finale, it MIGHT be worth getting.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												I have played the F.E.A.R. trilogy on the Xbox 360, as well as the PC. (However I have yet to finish this one yet on the PC). So here is how I feel about this game.As a shooters, is a fun game. The gun mechanics feel nice. The guns themselves feel nice. Hell, if you have a good PC running this at max settings, they look gorgeous. And I like the co-op-slash-competitive mode this game does. Whoever gets the highest score, becomes the "favorite" son to Alma. And you also level up in this game which increase stuff like ammo capacity, slo-mo, and whatever else.However, as a F.E.A.R. game, it is terrible. And that's why I don't recommend this for F.E.A.R. fans. F.E.A.R. 3 is the weakest installment of the series, lacking everything that made the first two great. Even F.E.A.R. 2, however others feel about it, was still faithful to the first one than this. The developers have essentionally made this as Call of Duty: Psychic Warfare.First, you are now relying on auto regen for your, now apparently low health bar. You used to be tough in previous installments, and need to find health kits to restore your health. Which was one of the things I have liked about this series. Now you can't even step out of cover without needing to GET BACK INTO cover after getting hit with a few bullets. (I'm exaggerating here, but the point is, they have basically nerfed your HP.)(Edit: I want to add really quick that I am playing this on normal difficutly. In case you're wondering if I was playing it in hard mode.)Secondly, the fear isn't there anymore. The game used to get you spooked with it's atmosphere. As supposed to the cheap jump scares studios typically do. (Which, there are some in previous installments, but they weren't heavily reliant.) Oh yeah, speaking of which, this one doesn't even have that. The atmosphere is gone. Now is just another generic first person shooter.Now, in case you're thinking, "But what about the slo-mo? F.E.A.R. is known for that?" So were Max Payne and True Crime. Doesn't mean anything if the game itself is still bad, does it? Yeah, it's there, but it's not like it saved this game.So overall, this is a disappointing installment. And this is after I said that it's a fun game. Perhaps if this was a different game, like say, a sequel to Blacklight, (Not counting Blacklight: Retribution) I could have given this a more positive review. Because it is a fun shooter. Generic or otherwise.If you're still thinking about buying this to see for yourself, I say wait for a steam sale, or, if you still have an Xbox 360 or PS3, see if you can find a copy for cheap. They should be around $10 or less by now.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
About The Games:The F.E.A.R franchise has always been & always will be a game about "The Paranormal" expect a lot of Ghosts in each of the games more so in F.E.A.R 1 & 2. That generally has a solid story line and to be expected in a game about the paranormal plenty of gore & jump scares THESE ARE NOT BAD THINGS!F.E.A.R had you playing in the shoes of an unknown solider for the "First Encounter Assault Recon Team" or F.E.A.R for short, you went in and you were tasked to capture a test subject who was designed to control these "Super Soldiers" for a war. The project was a success except things went wrong & the leader went nutso & so you're here to clean up the mess.F.E.A.R 2 had you playing the role of another solider for the "First Encounter Assault Recon" who was in another squad & was deployed just before the♥♥♥♥♥♥hits the fan in the first game, you were tasked to find & capture a doctor who was working on the test subject & then you are to eliminate the test subject & attempt to shut down project Origin by eliminate the main "Ghost" who was causing all the mayhem around the city, unfortunatly things don't pan out so well & then♥♥♥♥♥♥hits the fan & of course once more you're trying to battle your way out of the storm.F.E.A.R 3 on the other hand has you go back into the shoes of the "Unknown Soldier" from F.E.A.R 1 along with the ghost of your brother Paxton Fettle who was the test subject they were developing to control the "Super Soldiers" & use it for the war. The story fell really flat here & it certainly wasn't as much of an enjoyable game as the first 2 were.The Review:F.E.A.R 3 offers VERY minimal satisfaction for returning fans of the original games or for Single Player gamers as it's lost everything that made the first 2 F.E.A.R games great & on edge spooky, there's very little in the way of scary scenes & there's certainly not a solid story line here as there were more with F.E.A.R 1 & F.E.A.R 2.What F.E.A.R 3 does offers us is a very solid CO-OP experience with friends, there's some very EXCELLENT game modes, and Story is a blast to play with a partner to add some excellent gameplay mechanics, Story CO-OP:1 thing F.E.A.R 3 got right was the CO-OP experience you get while playing Story. 1 Player plays as a Ghost that can use all kinds of ghostly powers & telekenetics to dispatch of the foes, this includes: Possession of Enemies to use as stealth bait (Can flank enemies & then shoot them in the back so long as you don't fire at them first or get spotted body snatching) Telekenetic Smashes Ghostly Blasts, etcWhile the other player uses Firearms & Slow Motion reflexes to eleminate his foes as the F.E.A.R opperative. Each player gets to do different things in order to help you progress in the story so you're constantly helping each other out in order to get to the next section, this improves the games experience so i recommend playing CO-OP with a friend in order to get the most out of your game experience.CO-OP Multiplayer Modes:Moving onto the CO-OP Multiplayer experience we get some really fun CO-OP Modes such as: ♥♥♥♥ing RUN!,This game mode is a fun & fresh addition to bring something new & creative to a multiplayer game mode, it's kind of like a Death Run, you're given about 30 seconds to get a head start before something dark begins chasing you from behind & if you fall too far behind or stop too long at sections for a shootout with the pursueing enemies you'll get wiped out & then you're stuck watching to see if your team can survive. (Sounds boring on paper but once you get into a game, it becomes suspenceful & interesting to see if you're fast enough to escape). Survival Mode:This game mode is a classic game mode, survive the waves of enemies for as long as you can & try to best your friends or help them out & get the best top score together. (There's nothing quite like a good team building experience for me, i just enjoy the good old Survival)Multiplayer Modes:Now onto the Multiplayer Modes here's nothing new we have our usual game modes such as: Deathmatch Last Man StandNothing ground breaking or exciting here, Multiplayer is pretty well dead & you may or may not find the occasional server here or there. I recommend just playing with friends who may also enjoy the CO-OP experience or maybe a friendly Deathmatch with a group of friends.The Verdict:Finally it all boils down to my final conclusion of this game & sad to say that it's not a good one.I'll admit that it's impossible to say i did not have any fun in this game because i did have some fun, it's just not a game to play for it's Story or for the Single Player experience. This game thrives on it's obviously designed CO-OP experience that the developers had planned from the moment they started making F.E.A.R 3.This game is also very obviously ported from a Console so expect some very average controls for the PC & also very average Graphics.If you're looking for a more satisfying Single Player or Horror experience i very, VERY, whole heartedly suggest you look at F.E.A.R 1 or F.E.A.R 2 or even both of these games, this is because they are more enjoyable for the Single Player experience & for the Gameplay, Story & on edge Horror of the Single Player mode that'll keep you from rounding the next corner for a while.The Rating:This game receives a 4/10.  This is because of a few different factors  It has a very poor Story & for a game that started off so well in this department it's just not justifyable, it seems like the Developers just said after F.E.A.R 2 released "Oh ♥♥♥♥ the story let's just slap together the final installment & hope to god somebody buys it" Single Player has lost all meaning now, there's no scary scenes or suspenceful moments, it's all about the gun play & it's very baddly played, you're going to much more enjoy the Campaign with a friend simply because of that unique and amazing gameplay experience you get from playing as or with a Ghosly helper. Horror is almost non-existant anymore, this franchise started off SOOOOO thick with spooky and scary elements & it really made me want to stop playing at certain times because of the feeling i got everytime i saw a shadow or light flicker on the corner of the screen or when a ghost popped out behind a wall and started whispering creepy♥♥♥♥♥♥to me. Focus on run & gun play, the final nail in the coffin if not just because they removed what made the game so unique and scary was fear of the unknown, now just leaves fear of the "Oh what do i shoot next", there's no longer any great moments of anticipation of when will the next ghost decide to show itself or oh god when does the next shootout happen, now it's just shootout, after shootout, after shootout, and it really never stops.And with all this stuff out of the way i need to ask myself the question. "Do i recommend this to anyone else?"Do I Recommend This Game?:This would have to be a NO! I don't recommend this to anybody who loved the first 2 games of the franchise & i certainly don't recommend it to people who love horror, BUT! I can however recommend this game only to those who seek a unique and quite fun CO-OP experience with friends, i can only recommend it for these people.Further Reading:Check out my Review on F.E.A.R 2: Project Origin: http://steamcommunity.com/id/Paddles01/recommended/16450/

content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
[Edit]We managed to find solution to the coop issue. It seems that you and host needs to stay idle for a while in lobby and in beginning of the game in order to avoid being disconnected all of sudden. We spent 5 minutes talking at lobby and 5 minutes just standing at the beginning of a level. When we finally started to play, we managed to play several levels forward without any issues.Pros:* Coop was fun (when it works) and adds a lot to the game.* Possessing enemies were super fun. Friend in a bad spot? Posess an enemy from behind the enemy line and backstab everyone.Cons:* Scoring system sucks. Fettel will always lead in scores in normal game play (shared psychic links). Game endings are also tied to the score system. Should one of the brothers have more points than the other, it will cause good or bad ending.* The game is not scary. Game does not follow the original fear at all.* Controls are.. awkward. The game tries to have contextual controls, but fails in it. For example I need own keys for shooting while on feet or in vehicle.* The game has this typical AAA-game feeling. There is just no depth to it. There is no love for this game.I'm not going to change my rating for this game. We wasted too much time on the problems and it left a bad taste in mouth.[Original]I'm going to give thumbs down, as I was really looking to play this as a coop/multiplayer game.Buy only for the single player experience. The coop and multiplayer modes disconnect frequently from the host or kicks clients, hosting or not. Tried with multiple hosts with each having an excellent internet connection speeds. All required ports open. With and without a firewall. It just does not work.A real shame. The game is interesting, controls are working, the game is responsive, but everything is ruined by frequent disconnect issue.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												F.3.A.R. An interesting concept gone completely horribly wrong. Following some what the events of F.E.A.R. 2 you can play as either the Point Man or Paxton Fettel, making for an interesting Co-Op experience compared to recent titles. The game play can be quite entertaining, however offering very little replay value. Also the story writing goes further down the trash bin, personally letting me down as I am a die hard fan of the original F.E.A.R. and admittedly enjoyed F.E.A.R. 2. However taking a thriller/shooter and casualizing the game play to CoD style truly took the games identity away. I have lost all hope of this game coming back to its original stature. Do NOT purchase this title, do not recommend. Also looking at the banners for each title should show how the quality was given up each title to where it stands today.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												Okay, I am going to get right into this and say that F.E.A.R. 3 is a BAD game, but it is only a BAD game to people who have played the other games. If you've played the other F.E.A.R. games, you understand why this game is the bane of our existance, but, if not, I shall explain it to you. Alright, F.E.A.R. and F.E.A.R. 2: Project origin were both made by the same company and in the same style. They had large maps that you could get lost in and unnerving environments. Monolith was NOT afraid to hit you with a scare that comes across as mild, though is nothing compaired to the rest of the game, but it get's you anyway, probably even more than the really big scares. It was the small things that kept people on edge for the duration of your play time. The characters were well thought out and they were in no way scared to be brutal. They slapped you with a psychic canibal clone commander from the start who blew through innocent men and woman to get to the people who tortured and killed his mother who was forced into carrying to children via clone fetus implant. Yeah... Pretty sick stuff. The Problem with F.E.A.R. 3, however, was, not only the fact that the developer who made it KNOWS NOTHING ABOUT HORROR, but also the fact that it was so pointless and soul-crushing that it totally went in the OPPOSITE DIRECTION of what the original creators wanted. Day 1 RUINED F.E.A.R. by turning it into a light, CHEAP, co-op, FPS hell. They almost entirely removed the horror aspect of the game and handed us one of the biggest loads of trash. The problems are as follows. 1. Going by the story line of the previous games, the ending was anti-climactic and a serious let down.2. The horror aspect it an attempt to use wierd sounds and over-cooked map textures to scare people as well as cheap jumpscares that would hardly startle a small infant.3. They changed the characters to a fault. The two biggest examples being the Characters Paxton Fettel and Point Man. Paxton had always been propper and rightfully creepy simply by the way he delivered his lines and their context. He now speaks in partial slang and comes across more annoying with his lines than his former eree. Point Man was originally personality-less, intended to be that way by the company that was implimenting his make-shift powers. They didn't want him to have a personality. This also helped the immersion of the game by allowing the player to impliment themselves onto the character. NOW, Point Man has a very angry and cliche silent-protagonist role, comming across as an overused-"badass" steriotype. 4. CUTSCENES. The other games had little to no cutscenes. What few they had were all in first person and allowed the player some range of head movement. In F.E.A.R. 3, however, the cutscenes are full on thirdperson with no choice, no point, and do little to advance the story. If anything, they just annoy the player. (Paxton's cheesy jokes don't help any.) This also breaks the immersion charm that the F.E.A.R. games were known for. 5. The story is dead. Yes, they continue on from the last game involving Alma's third child, but hardly any of the game is even about that. You play a "must save the princess" sort of game with the Character Jin sun-qwan who can't seem to keep away from trouble, but was a total badass in the other games. She didn't need to be saved and was a good ally. In this game, she even has the gall to be annoyingly bossy, something I quite detest, especially seeing as her voice actor get's very ear-clenching after level two. They also make sure to kill off the Protagonist from F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin in an unessisarily brutal way and give him a voice, though he had none in his own game (Though I wonder HOW IN THE HELL THIS GAME GOT AHOLD OF ROBIN ATKIN DOWNS.) 6. They play Alma as a completely innocent little girl, running from the tyrant that was her father. Alma was, in no way, innocent. She was an evil, demonic spirit who killed many to get what she wanted and even mind♥♥♥♥♥♥♥her youngest son to get it, making HIM kill many people as well at age 10 and again at age 30. Another thing to note is that Harlon Wade did some bad things, but, as it is shown in F.E.A.R. 2, was reluctant to do said things to Alma, but did because he thought they were for the better. He certainly loved Alma, though she did kill him, and was clouded in judgement by those of the Armacham corperation. A spirirt such as his could not have come back as a demon, let a long one with so much power over the surviving family. 7. Inconsistantcy. Paxton's role in this game, on its own, is an inconsistancy. Not only is he a ghost, which he shouldn't be due to him gaining a new body off of a clone in the DLC for F.E.A.R. 2, Reborn, but he seems to like becoming visible and invisible to anyone but Point Man at any given time. What I mean by this is: During the cutscenes, the game shows that Paxton is totally invisible to anyone but his brother, but, in combat and totally BAD times, he is visible to the world and can be harmed by bullets, though in some scenes it is depicted that bullets have no effect on him, which leads no another problem when, in Point Man's ending, he stops Fettel by shooting him. I know what they were trying to do in paying  respect to the first game, but with the way they loused it all up, it just doesn't work. 8. (Finally) The endings. In Point Man's ending, he shoots Paxton in the head, delivers Alma's baby, then leaves with it. (I've already explained the two problems with this ending.) and In Paxton's ending, he possesses his brother, delivers the baby, then eats his own mother, claiming it'll give him the power to take over the world, which, isn't just cliche, but NEVER HIS GOAL IN THE FIRST PLACE. Paxton's goal was always to avenge his mother and serve her. Now he wants world domination. What in the... Never mind... I digress...ALSO, if you want a bonus: THE FINAL BOSS IS SO EASY THAT YOU'D HAVE TO BE BRAIN DEAD WITH YOUR NON-FUNCTIONAL BRAIN REMOVED NOT TO BEAT IT THE FIRST TIME ON THE HIGHEST DIFFICULTY. I swear, it is as obvious as a five-foot black spider on a white bedroom wall and as liniar as the lines on a road.It has bad shotguns, too. They are 50% glass. That isn't a safe thing.

Game endings are also tied to the score system. Should one of the brothers have more points than the other, it will cause good or bad ending.* The game is not scary. Game does not follow the original fear at all.* Controls are.. awkward. The game tries to have contextual controls, but fails in it. For example I need own keys for shooting while on feet or in vehicle.* The game has this typical AAA-game feeling. There is just no depth to it. There is no love for this game.I'm not going to change my rating for this game. We wasted too much time on the problems and it left a bad taste in mouth.[Original]I'm going to give thumbs down, as I was really looking to play this as a coop/multiplayer game.Buy only for the single player experience. The coop and multiplayer modes disconnect frequently from the host or kicks clients, hosting or not. Tried with multiple hosts with each having an excellent internet connection speeds. All required ports open. With and without a firewall. It just does not work.A real shame. The game is interesting, controls are working, the game is responsive, but everything is ruined by frequent disconnect issue.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												As a fan of the first two FEAR games, I was pretty disappointed with how this game turned out. It gave up a lot of the interesting design of the first two for a rather bland, run-of-the-mill first person shooter experience. Levels were reduced to little more than straight corridors with things to hide behind and seemed to drag on longer than they should have as enemies filled choke points. Most of the guns felt uninspired compaired to guns from the first two and the weapon limit (brought over from 2, which was a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ part of that game) didnt help at all. The worst part though is the wasted opportunity of a second playable character in the form of Paxton Fettel. So many more interesting gameplay mechanics could have been introduced in his powers, but we only got a stun blast attack and the ability to posses someone, which is basically just like playing as Point Man. I only really played this to see the conclusion of the story, which wasn't that great really, so I cant really recommend this on any level. (single player wise anyway, never tried the multiplayer).

content:
Posted: May 17, 2016
Quick Bit- While having the most fully realized combat of the series and an interesting asymmetrical twist with the co-op gameplay, it falls extremely short due to the poor execution of the campaign with both co-op and solo, and the dead-on-arrival multiplayer.Extra Bit- I love this series, but thankfully the ire it wrought has long since become a dull ache, which allows me to convey a much more mellow expression for F.E.A.R. 3. It can be an enjoyable romp with a friend in co-op, and the odd, but ultimately interesting mechanics that makeup the dynamic brotherly duo of Point Man and Paxton Fettel can be oddly fun, even with the story being insultingly bad, and not enjoyed in an ironic way either.  The game still looks pretty decent, and the combat holds up solid, but of course you will literally need to bring a friend if you want to play co-op. The years have not been kind because like the multiplayer, co-op’s as dead as Alma is. Which is sad, because they did try, but not enough unfortunately to make it shine, and I don’t doubt WB had its gnarled claw in the mix as well. So the legacy ends with a thump, if not for F.E.A.R. Online making a final macabre display of the franchise, at least the name will be remembered for the superb enemy A.I.I will provide additional details, if requested for, in the comment section of the review.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												FEAR 3.... oh FEAR 3.... or as I like to call it "Call of Duty: Spooky Warfare". I know that it's usually not a good idea to write a review without finishing the game you're reviewing first but, I think we can make an exception for this 'game', for the record I got half way through. As with all the games in this series it combines (or atleast tries too) horror elements with actiony FPS elements. The horror elements in this game boil down to vague satanic references and zombies. The FPS elements is similar to the past games but the way it's done just doesn't feel like a FEAR game, except for one little tiny thing... regenerating health... I don't think I need to say anymore. The game still has slow motion like the past 2 games and is executed in much the same way. The Co-op system i wasn't able to test since noone I know has this game, can't really blame them, but I'm sure it's adequate. I don't know how the story to the FEAR trilogy ends, but I really don't care, the first game ended on a high note and I wish that's where the series ended aswell. Just a note the only reason I have this game is because it came with the WB Games humble bundle charity thing they did a few months prior to this writing, it came with the rest of the FEAR games along with the batman arkham games and some other stuff. Just please don't buy this game, if you want to play a FEAR game buy the first one it is, in my opinion and I'm sure many other, one of the best FPS games out there, this one being quite the opposite.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2013
												The first question you have to assume is whether or not F.E.A.R 3 is better or worse than F.E.A.R 2. I really can't answer that because this game is just so... flagrant with it's mediocrity.F.E.A.R is a tragic series to me simply because of how it strayed so far from it's roots. The original was a great game with non-linear map design, great AI and a very noticeable influence from Hong Kong action movies and horror films. With this game... it just feels like the devs didn't care. Like they went into it knowing it was going to suck so they just went "Eh ♥♥♥♥ it" and designed it anyway."Eh ♥♥♥♥ it" seems to be a reaccuring philosophy with this game. It continues right from the end of the original game but is so stylistically different it's shocking. The Point Man now looks like a homeless Jesus figure (compared to the faceless balclava wearing professional of the original). At the same time they attempted to do more unique things like playing as your super natural brother Paxton Fettel, and the multiplayer has some unique game modes. But if the texture quality and 6 hour campaign don't put you off the mediocrity will. None of the new features feel like they need to be there. Bullet time is completely unnecessary because of the new cover mechanic, and the new cover mechanic is pointless because we already had bullet time. It's like a ♥♥♥♥ing Catch 22 and all I want is for this series to stop sucking.

content:
Posted: April 15
												Thoroughly enjoyed instalments 1 & 2, I particularly enjoyed the atmosphere, relentless music and sound effects. I nearly made it past the dire opening prison level before giving up. I then re-started and gave it another chance based on a review that admitted the prison level was dire but that it got a lot better.  I made it into the slum area before asking myself the touchstone question: "am I enjoying myself"? Answer was a big fat "no", and it all just felt like a chore. When a game feels like hard work it's time to cut your losses.It's worth saying that I only play single player mode. The shortfalls of the 3rd instalment have been documented comprehensively elsewhere, but for me the killers were:* Can't turn off head bob (= motion sickness)* Waves of quite hard-to-kill opponents. In FEAR 1 & 2, you knew you had 3 or 4 in each squad to tackle.* 2 weapons only* Pointless "psychic links". Why am I collecting these? For co-op I think.* Poor, blurry environments.I normally take "save your money" advice as a challenge and prefer to make my own mind up, but I think in this case : "save your money".

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												I'm honestly surprised by how much I enjoyed this considering I'm a hardcore fan of the previous games. I would lie if I said it wasn't fun, alone or with a friend. This isn't what previous games in the franchise were, this isn't a horror game and it isn't as nearly as tactical as the previous games, but and this is a bit but, I had a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of fun. If this game simply wasn't called FEAR I can assure you it would have been received with much more positive reviews.I grew up with FPS games like FEAR, Half Life, Doom, Quake etc., I love corridor-ish FPS games, I don't mind them being linear, sure it's nice when they have more open levels and more than one approach to a given situation, but I don't really mind linearity as long as the gameplay is good. I love running forward and shooting stuff in games, sure it would have been nice to a true successor to FEAR, but I'm not going to let my fanboism be in the way of me enjoying this.PROS*Fun gunplay*Great with friends*Bloody and gory as hell*Action feels satisfying*Not scary, but definitely atmospheric*Two characters to play, very different too*The whole campaign can be played in co-op and in addition there are some bonus game modes*Visually appealing and should run even on weaker systems*Contrary to what most people say I found the AI to be pretty alrightCONS*For the most part linear (doesn't bother me)*Not that scary*Story went to♥♥♥♥♥♥br>*CGI cutscenes are baaaaad*Voice acting is questionable*Can get repetitive if you play alone*The occasional invisible wallEDIT:*Ending is♥♥♥♥♥♥br>*Really anticlimactic final intervalI had fun guys, I love FPS games, I didn't mind what most people dislike and both me and my friend had a lot of fun, we plan on finishing this together. It is not a bad game, on the contrary, a lot of fun if you get over the fact it isn't a true FEAR game.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Finishing off the FEAR trilogy!Every time I see FEAR 3 on sale I see people bashing it as the worst in the series, but the meta score is actually not too bad 74/100. Unlike the first 2 FEAR games, FEAR 3 has one of those regenerating health systems where you just hide under cover for a few seconds and you recover back to full health. No need to scrounge for med kits or armor. Also, the game seems built around 2 player co-op, which I like in first person shooter games (when I have someone to play with).*Spoilers ahead*FEAR 3 takes place an unspecified amount of time after the events of FEAR 2. Alma is pregnant and getting ready to give birth, as a result her psychic power is tearing up the city (possibly the world). Again the main opposition is the private military contractor Armacham, who seems to have become 100x more powerful than they were in the first games. Even without their clone super soldiers from the first games, Armacham seems capable of overrunning and occupying entire cities with soldiers, aircraft, and power armor. You play the Point Man protagonist from the first FEAR game (the guy you play in FEAR 2 also shows up briefly) but this time you have an “imaginary” friend Paxton Fettel (Bad guy from the first game). Your primary goal this time around is to reach Alma before she gives birth and deal with her once and for all. Unfortunately for you, Alma’s psychic pain has summoned nightmare creatures and twisted the surviving civilian population into crazed psychos.Unlike the previous FEAR games, FEAR 3 is broken down into missions or “levels” with each mission giving you a point score at the end. You gain points by finding collectables, killing enemies, and completing “challenges.” The challenges are similar to the “Skill shots” in Bulletstorm, where it’s basically just using various methods of killing. For example, 2000 points for killing enemies with a specific weapon, or 1000 points for getting 25 headshots, or 2000 points for getting 3 backstabs. The points aren’t just for show, by the way. You “level up” when you gain enough points and each level gives you some kind of perk, such as +10% health or +bullet capacity. You can replay levels as many times as you want to “grind” for points. This means that the game will get easier over time as you replay it. You might notice that when you first start the game, it seems far more difficult than the previous ones, well this changes as you level up and get stronger. The regenerating health means you can charge groups of enemies and just duck for cover when your screen is almost completely red (near death). Healing is free unlike FEAR 1 and 2 which had limited med kits.As I mentioned earlier, the game is built with 2 player co-op in mind. At the end of each mission there is a ranking between the 2 players to see who scored highest in several categories. The game’s ending depends on which of the two characters “won” the most missions. Of course if you’re playing single player the character you’re playing (Fettel or Point Man) will “win” every level you complete. Point Man’s gameplay is the same as the previous games (standard shooter with Slow-Mo power), But Fettel is a psychic commander. This means he can possess enemies and use them to fight (he doesn’t have slow-mo). Every time he takes over a new body he gets the weapons of the possessed enemy, so you can’t hoard powerful weapons or grenades the way Point Man does. You can only hold 2 weapons now, unlike 3 weapons in FEAR 1 and 4 weapons in FEAR 2. Possession also means you won’t be able to use the awesome power armors because the possessed body won’t last long enough. Pros:+Excellent graphics and visuals. Large variety of weapons available.+Some cool new enemies, particular the Phase Commander and Phase Caster.+A lot of replay value. I just finished the game and immediately restarted as Fettel. +2 player co-op available. Also a bunch of various multiplayer game modes I haven’t tried.Cons:-The game is very short, about 6 hours to beat the first time. Replay is strongly encouraged though.-The story is weaker than the first FEAR games. There’re a lot of unnecessary “dream sequences” that don’t seem to add much. You just walk forward about 15 seconds with someone talking in voice over and it ends.-I get the feeling that the enemies are much “dumber” than FEAR 1 enemies. They tend to stick behind the same piece of cover and just pop their heads out to shoot from there.Overall I think the game is well worth playing for fans of First Person Shooters and people who want to see how the FEAR story ends. Once you finish a mission in single player, the Fettel character is unlocked so you can try playing him for that particular level. The way to see the Fettel game ending is by playing through the game a second time (or play the game in co-op and Fettel has the highest score every mission). One thing I noticed is that the game’s Steam achievements seem to be half for multiplayer, and not many people are playing the multiplayer. This isn’t surprising since the game has been out for a few years. I’ll probably only be able to get about 45% completion for the game achievements by myself.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2016
												Yes, is good. There's nothing really wrong with this game. It has funny gameplay and some good moments. The production values here are high as you can expect from the WB brand. I write this as a FEAR fan. I've played the whole FEAR 1 + exp. and FEAR 2 + dlc just before playing this one. And also yes, the story is weaker,  the locations doesn't make all the sense they should and the character of Alma is a side note. In return we get a more developed relationship between the brothers, although only the character of Fethel is developed as the Point Man is not very talkative, in one of the bad design desitions. You can expect this from another developer than Monolith. It's a shame they couldn't do this. FEAR was their saga. On a final note, if you liked the previous ones you will like this one, just don't start nitpicking. P.D.: The Mech level is awesome as always.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												Fettel was the original antagonist, and may have been a vampire.  He died at the end of FEAR, came back as a ghost in a non-canon expansion, and came back as a possessed Replica soldier in a FEAR 2 expansion.  In FEAR 3 Fettel is clearly a ghost and there are no Replica forces.  Go figure.  3/5  Fun for 2-player co-op if you catch it on sale.  For the single player, it's inferior to the first two and likely not worth your time.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												Ok. Let me start by saying I'm a HUGE fan of the first two games. They both bring something different to the table and they had all the atmosphere, scares, and visceral combat the franchise is known for. F3AR Is severly lacking the simplest way this is not a FEAR game. There is a new studio, a new engine - and entirely new writers. Let me start with some gameplay changes: The persistent weapon carry system is gone - there is now a 2 weapon limit that resets upon the start of each new chapter. Don't bother saving up and trading off a weapon for a fully filled rocket launcher unless you plan to use it, because It'll be gone at the end by the time the cutscenes come up. The health/armor system is gone and in place is a regenerating health system. This hurts the gameplay due to the fact that you can simply melee the majority of the jump mosters and sit healing before moving to the next trigger- it kills the adrenaline entirely. The classic replicant variants are gone in favor or new, completely arbitrary lore-breaking entities with poor voice acting and predictable movement. The classic FEAR A.I. is gone, and what they've implemented here is atrocious. Many times "elite" AI will sit in a single place ducking behind cover while I set up for the next headshot. The booster/reflex injector mechanic is gone in favor or hoping players will alter their play to "score up" and unlock the next level, which merely increases your grenade and slo-mo meter. The slo-mo is the weakest yet, and drains much too fast and takes obnoxiously long to refill... The problem with this is that the award/score system is fundamentally flawed with things like giving you points for fully draining your meter 3 times in a chapter. The game rewards you for time in cover, picking up ammo, finding pointless psychic links, picking up alma doll's (what?), getting headshots, consecutive kills without damage and so on. This would be all fine and dandy but the co-op quickly turns into PVP with the ending of the entire game dependant on who gets the highest score overall. The clever level design and setpieces of the first are instead shifted here with lackluster textured environments that are riddled with tacky cover points much similar to gears of war and other 3rd person titles. The cover system hardly needs to be utilized, as a crouch toggle behind cover works faster - BUT - it doesn't give you the score points for staying in cover X amount of seconds (what?). The linearity and uninspired level design pushes further by unrealistic structures with only a handful of recycled items scattered throughout - this kills the immersion entirely. The intel items from FEAR 1 and FEAR 2 are gone, and there is no extra easter-eggs or background text to dive into, its bare-bones aside from collectibles that increase your score. Every time you collect items, or complete challenges, you have a constantly annoying banner popping up telling you how much of a badass you are for getting 30 slo-mo kills, picking up ammo you would anyways, or doing anything you normally would in the flow of gameplay. Again, another immersion killer - but hey - we've gotten past that this game isn't the slightest bit scary. The game isn't even chilling, the highly-scripted scares are mostly FX and art based with no actual tension to worry about death. The mech combat returns from FEAR 2 with two different variations, but gone is the extra effects such as infared vision. The addition of other enemy types hardly brings anything to the background of the story with weird psycho's called occultists, and a constantly pestering psychic monster which is explained later in the game. The variety presented here makes no sense with the continuity of the franchise and it has nothing fresh to bring to the table. Most of the weapon variants return from previous games although poor - gone is the selective fire mode, so once you get the 3-burst rifle, your stuck with 3 burst. The ammo placements are laughable, with hidden area's having a single pistol on the ground when I'm loaded up with two rifles. This might be great, but with the 2 weapon limit, it kills the need to ever use lesser tiers of weapons, save for again - the award points. +25 kills with the pistol! woo! The story of this game completely tarnishes everything in the FEAR universe. It leaves no leaf unturned. From the voice acting, or the follow events with characters from FEAR 2 - its a slap in the face to all fans who have invested thought into this mysterious story. Every chapter ends, and sometimes begins with a poorly animated cutscene that drags this experience even lower. It leaves even veteran players confused and asking... why? In short this game was made to cash in on the co-op craze and call of duty style reward system that was huge at the time. It threw away all of the innovations of the first two titles to lure in console players and casual FPS fans that can't stand a game without a progression system. I couldn't recommend this game even as a free title. The campaign is short, and rewards you for completing chapters fast & under a set time, rather than relishing in the atmosphere and taking in the level design. The name Day 1 Studios tells you everything you need to know about this game, because It's apparent they didn't spend more than 1 day on any particular facet of this once-amazing franchise. Two-thumbs DOWN.

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												I'll say right off the bat that I am indeed a fan of the original F.E.A.R. game, I do not like the second one very much, and I think this third game is a complete atrocity. I promise I tried to make this review short, but there's just so much to say... Sorry. Let us begin.I shall also mention that, at the time of writing this review, I have completed the game twice - once as Fettel, once as the Pointman. I have not yet played the coop, although I'm sure it'll be a grand old time.Right off the bat, it is glaringly obvious that this game is intended to be cooperative. Is that a bad thing? Well, not inherently, coop shooters have been around for a very long time and there are a couple examples of cooperative horror done right. That is to say, it is still very scary indeed in spite the fact that you are not alone. However, given the fact that F.E.A.R. 3 doesn't deserve to be called a horror game - I'll get to that later - that's a rather moot point. So, you play as either the Point Man from the first game, or his brother Fettel. The Pointman obviously has bullet time, and Fettel the ability to possess enemies for a given time. I will say that the Pointman plays how you expect him to, no problems there, and Fettel is quite fun to play as well with what seems - to me, anyway - to be a rather well fleshed-out special ability. However, at the same time, it seems well balanced to the Pointman's and the enemies around. Although it would not surprise me if it is commonplace to fight to get Fettel over the Pointman.Getting back on topic, coop in itself is not an issue really, but I do believe that it was one of the big downfalls of this game. I shall elaborate at the end of this review.The second glaringly obvious addition which made me very upset when I first saw it was the inclusion of a per-level point system, complete with goals to earn you additional points which are snarkily or punnily named. Well, that's not very F.E.A.R.-like at all, now is it? Or horror-game like in general, really. Why, you ask? Well, in terms of U.I. and game mechanics, having a score system - let alone one with a little status menu you can look at in-game (by pressing F1) - kinda breaks the player's immersion. Maybe a post-mission stats screen would be okay, but having nothing at all - like in the last two F.E.A.R. games - would be a lot better. Hell, in the first game, immersion was one of the biggest things they were striving for! Hence the inclusion of such details like a full shadow for the player, good arm models, and the ability to look down and actually see your legs and feet. Same with the stigma the first game had about never taking control away from the player when possible. There were probably two cutscenes in the first game, and most of the times control is taken away from you is a few seconds after something whacked you on your butt and your person gets up, and even then it's almost nice as a breather between the action. This game, on the other hand, of course has that point-system, and cutscenes galore; the things bookending every single level.Although to be honest, immersion is a bit of a moot point with the lack of actual scares in the game...Let's get onto the horror elements, now. Or rather the lack-there-of. This game is not a horror game at all, it is a first-person shooter through and through. What makes me say that? Well, there are only four or five times in the entire game where it even tries to scare you or creep you out - and those times a very shortlived and ineffective. Going in fully blind, I didn't even get that sense of dread and not wanting to keep moving forward like I did in the first game. It did make me jump once in fear, although that was when I was walking through a seemingly empty house and an enemy - unintentionally - snuck up behind me and started yelling while clawing at me. T'was unexpected, but I don't think most people would even get scared by that - assuming they were playing it like one should an FPS; keeping their head on a swivel. There really just seemed like a lack of effort with the scares, to be honest. While I am sure they did try their best with the scary moments that are present, keep in mind there's literally four or five of them.Alright, so because this game is an FPS now, let's cover that next.The short version? It's your standard console shooter. What do I mean by that? Well, we now have regenerating health, a full cover system, a two-weapon carry limit, a very standard assortment of weapons outside of two which are even then not too interesting. You read that right, regenerating health in a F.E.A.R. game. A cover system, too, which I thought at first was kinda nice and was a change I'd be indifferent too. However, about midway through the game on my first run, I had a realization; the cover system was killing the pace of the combat. Hell, there's practically no need for the Pointman's bullet time given this. Just play it like you would Gears of War or similar and you're good to go. There's no panic or amazing action like in the first game, where there was no cover, and you had to be quick and clever to take out a whole squad. Though this was helped by a normal - or nowadays 'old school' - health system which, of course, gave you one-hundred points of health, and up to ten medkits which healed you a certain amount at the press of a button. Here, even if you try and replicate the amazing shootouts you remember from the original F.E.A.R. - and even the second game to a lesser extent - you're going to die, because the very nature of the regenerating health system doesn't allow such things. Even if you pull it off, you're just handicapping yourself really.However, then I had a thought. I stopped thinking about it as a F.E.A.R. game. Suddenly things got a lot better. This isn't a lazy, poorly made cash-in in my eyes, it was just made with the wrong license. If this game didn't have the F.E.A.R. title attatched to it, I would like it a hellofalot more. There was effort put in, and it is certainly fun to play at points, and at it's worst it's just like any other standard MMS (Modern Military Shooter), and I'm sure it'll be a blast when I get around to coop. It just shouldn't have been a F.E.A.R. game.While this is byfar the worst game in the F.E.A.R. franchise, but it's not a bad game on its own. Unless you count modern shooters bad, and I don't disagree with you if you do.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												The internet convinced me this game would be terrible, a horrible abomination not even worth playing.Once again I am right and everyone else is stupid. In defense of these lesser minded opinions, this game is very unique in its series. You and an IRL friend engage in a six hour long campaign to outskill the other person. Bonuses are actively awarded for styling on enemies in a tremendous variety of methods. From backstabbing, headshots, using specific weapons, to killing without taking damage, the objective is to outdo your brother and become the "favorite son." Since the game was designed with 2p coop in mind, virtually all secondary item-finding exploration has been eliminated. This includes healthpacks and armor, which has been replaced with regenerating health. Even so the game presents a wide variety of environments and a ton of complex areas to go through.If you're playing this game by yourself you're really not doing it right. Grab a buddy and enjoy a pretty badass fps, laced with delicious FEAR-flavored sprinkles on top. Also the final boss is a giant instant-kill middle finger with attacks that are hard to predict and navigate around.

Posted: July 23, 2013
												If you are ever looking for an action packed spookfest, than this game is for you. FE3R reinvents the horror genre by adding a Co-Op mode so now you can experience the thrills and chills with your friends. The story is about two seperated brothers reuniting to win their mothers approval. The writing is deep and thoughful, and the scares are well executed and guaranteed to scare your pants off. The visionary movie director John Carpenter helped handcraft these cinematic frights. I would rate this game 4.5 spooky pumpkins out of 5 spooky pumpkins.

And this is what I did not feel....I think a game called FEAR should spread a little fear..Just like the first part! Still it is a nice game and I do NOT regret buying it!

Posted: June 23, 2012
												Paxton Fettel: Be the other guy.This game is not really up to the standard of its predecessors, lacking as it does in spooky time, having weird pre-rendered cutscenes in which they mangle the overarching story, and generally completely losing the strangeness of the paranormal phenomena. They also call him 'pointman' with what amounts to a straight face. -_-'These considerable failings are mostly made up for by Paxton Fettel and coop mode, because you can play as or with a murderous, excessively powerful psychic ghost zombie thing who giggles like Beavis and Butthead every time he possesses someone and explodes heads all over the place. Coop mode was fun from both sides, although I think the Fettel experience really carries this game.

Posted: January 13, 2013
												I must say I was extremely surprised by F.E.A.R. 3. Anyone who says this is not a proper Fear game has no idea what he's talking about. Yes, it is not scary at all, but to be honest: I never found the other ones scary either. They all (including the add-ons) had a VERY intense and dark atmosphere, but they weren't really scary. F.E.A.R. 3 does a great job at the gory, slow-mo shooting mechanics and the story is entertaining, however still largely nonsensical, but that is exactly how this series has always been: Great action, intense atmosphere, tons of blood and a completely ♥♥♥♥ed up mess of a story.

Posted: January 5, 2016
												Much better than F.E.A.R 2, the scares are back and the graphics are amazing. During gameplay you also have challenges which stop you from the run-n-gun which was a big part in the previous F.E.A.R. and makes you try out a different approach. Also they added a "take cover" option allowing you to duck behind walls and boxes other than just standing behind them.Great game and would recommend playing from the beginning.:Edit:After Playing the game as the "Bad brother" (fettel) a Strong Con of the game was that the Script was not changed, the same lines are said when you played as the "Good brother" and therefore some scenes didn't make sense.

Posted: October 31, 2012
												Long ago, a man killed my dog just to be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, and I wasn't this mad. I spent months repairing a collector car to its full glory only to have it stolen the day after I finished by French people and I wasn't this mad. I am literally as mad as anyone has ever been. For the rest of time, scientists will wonder what the enormous energy wave that caused the massive fluctuation in the natural magnetic field of the Earth was on this very day. It will have been my rage. Years from now, people will ask "where were you when Fidelman raged so hard he took out half the planet?" My anger will never end. It is an endless coil of pure raging exasperation that will consume this planet and then spread its bitter seeds to the far reaches of the universe. This rage will poison the multiverse. And as even Johndavid succumbs to the snarling tendrils of my resentment, He will weep tears of joy, as even His omniscience will not be able to fathom the passion and severity of my fury.I.AM.MAD.9/10

												If you like horror games....this is not a game that will make you be afraid!BUT!!!!!It's not that this game is not good!!!It actually is VERY good and quite hard!!!If you played the other 2,play this one too and you won't regret it!

Posted: February 27, 2015
												It's sad to see the F.E.A.R. series come to this. This game is suffering from consolitis, chest-high walls, popamole combat and flat storyline and characters. 4 hours into the game and I don't know if I even want to finish it. The only reason I even played this to begin with, is that the game supposedly has something to do with the other FEAR games. But you wouldn't know that from playing the game itself.  FEAR 2 already took some steps back, compared to the original game, but it was still an enjoyable game. Not great, but enjoyable.                FEAR 3 is barely recognisable as a FEAR game: Popamole combat, bland cutscenes and no atmosphere. You sit behind  chest-high walls and defeat enemy waves. Other times you watch bland cut-scenes or go through some uninspiring  flashbacks. I propably should mention the jump scares as well; They come off as desperate attempt to catch even a glimpse of the atmosphere of the previous games.            In the previous games you always felt somewhat sad for Alma's predicament and what had been done to her. That's a sign of good writing and it gave the games a great atmosphere. All that is gone in this 3rd instalment. First F.E.A.R. was a classic. It added bullet-time and horror elements to an fps game. It had good writing, aggressive combat and great A.I. It was an ambitious game. F.E.A.R. 3 on the other hand is mediocre in every respect. It's a mediocre Call of Duty game with some "horror" sprinkled on top of it.  The horror effects only remind the gamer, of the better F.E.A.R. games. "Oh hey! I remember that better FEAR game that was actually good. Maybe I should play that instead."5,5/10

Posted: November 2, 2015
												The original F.E.A.R. is one of my favorite Horror games of all time, and certainly on my top ten favorite FPS games ever. It delivered a sense of Horror and realism with graphics that excelled all possible thought during its initial release, and it was a while before we saw another Horror game deliver the same intensity and excitement F.E.A.R. did. Fast-forward a few years later, and we see the release of F.E.A.R. 2, a title that had promise in expanding the universe and story of Alma, but fell a little short when it came to delivering a captivating experience. Though not bad by any means, it certainly didn't live up to what the first F.E.A.R. had accomplished.And then there was the end to the trilogy, after an unecessary amount of ports and random spinoffs. This... this supposedly Horror game that has the word F.E.A.R. in the title, albeit as an acronym, is the biggest form of false advertisement I've seen in a while. It's like going to a pizzeria, and they have nothing to do with pizza. You're gonna tell me you're just going to say "ƒuck it" to the pizza when you know damn well you've been wanting pizza for the last couple of hours? One does not simply say "ƒuck it" to the pizza. Same thing here - I want my horror, and I got none of it. Where is the *FEAR* I'm supposed to be feeling? Where is the *FEAR* that the other two games exuded?F.E.A.R. 3 succumbed to the issue most banal FPS games have, which is waves of enemies, walk five feet, more waves of enemies, walk maybe ten feet this time just to make it seem like some actual ludology went into the design of the game, a couple lights flicker to remind you "oh I remember this from the other F.E.A.R. games! That means I'm playing F.E.A.R. - I almost forgot!", even though it doesn't mean sh!t, and then rinse and repeat. The story makes absolutely no sense and goes in an unecessary direction that's full of sh!t. That's the best way I can honestly put it - It's full of sh!t. Monolith had a genuinely good thing going and created a masterpiece from the first one, and a decent enough sequel to it, but whatever happened to this one once it changed studios... I just don't know. They clearly wanted to make a different game, but remembered that they were working on a game that already had a few entries before it. Basically ƒuck F.E.A.R. 3

Posted: October 13, 2012
												And alas we come full circle with the F.E.A.R series with F.E.A.R 3 or F.3.A.R if you're a fan of bad names. F.E.A.R 3 contructs its campaign to be a co-op based afair compared to the other games in the series, so it's best you play it with a buddy as I did. Gameplay remains much the same if you play as Pointman complete with slo-mo gunfighting and all. Fettell on the other hand is the more interesting character to play as he has some neat abilities like possession and suspending enemies. Story is pretty bare bones even for a F.E.A.R game with no really interesting character interactions except the dialogue between the brothers occasionally. The biggest flaw however is that the game is criminally short, like 4 hours total to beat all 8 intervals. Also the horror has taken a further backseat with the introduction of co-op. Overall whilst F.E.A.R 3 isn't a bad game, it's actually a fun co-op game to play with a friend, it's a bad F.E.A.R game compared to the others in the series.

Posted: June 23, 2011
												Although the storyline was disappointing (from a long-time F.E.A.R. fan's perspective) and the actual game only took about 6 hours to complete, F.3.A.R. is still a generally enjoyable game. The singleplayer seems to focus more on its action persona than its horror aspect, which was sad to see since the original game had an extremely frightening and terrifying atmosphere. The action is as you'd expect it to be - fast-paced, tight and fun, especially when you activate your slow-mo ability. Plus Co-Op is great with a friend. The multiplayer of the game is a pleasant surprise. Modes like "Contractions" (where you must survive against an endless wave of enemies) and "F**king Run" (a Left 4 Dead style gamemode where you must travel from one side of the map to the end, running from a giant wall of death) are extremely fun and require you to cooperate with your teammates to survive. If you don't, you won't last very long.A solid shooter that just doesn't live up to the original game.7/10

Posted: July 2, 2013
												Игра вполне хорошая, но это не F.E.A.R. Я ждал больше хорор моментов, неожиданных поворотов и более глубокий сюжет, который смог бы залатать дыры прошлых частей. На деле получилась игра с отличным экшеном(что для меня было на втором плане) но с наитупейшим сюжетом. Да и не то что бы сюжет тупой..просто он топчется на одном месте. Образ поинтмена мне вообще не понравился. Из солдата элитного подразделения феар, он превратился в бомжа. Этот образ ну никак не подходит. И что само бесит - галимый хорор и отсутствие неожиданных сюжетных поворотов. Напугать у разработчиков не получается. Да и эффекты присутсвия Альмы вообще испорчены. Во второй части от каждого появления бегали мурашки по коже.Разработчики в самом начале поставили не те задачи. Идея превратить FEAR в кооп шутер уже сразу не увенчался успехом. Вердикт - отличный экшн, слоумоу пыш пыш, но сюжет просто калл. И когда будите принимать решение о покупке игры, подумайте за что вы полюбили прошлые части феар. За сюжет, хорор, или же экшн. P.S. Я очень хочу увидеть 4ю часть, но что бы в разработчиках значился Monolith. Понятия не имею как можно залатать этот сюжетный бред после 3й части, но в их способностях я уверен.

Posted: February 27, 2015
												It's sad to see the F.E.A.R. series come to this. This game is suffering from consolitis, chest-high walls, popamole combat and flat storyline and characters. 4 hours into the game and I don't know if I even want to finish it. The only reason I even played this to begin with, is that the game supposedly has something to do with the other FEAR games. But you wouldn't know that from playing the game itself.  FEAR 2 already took some steps back, compared to the original game, but it was still an enjoyable game. Not great, but enjoyable.                FEAR 3 is barely recognisable as a FEAR game: Popamole combat, bland cutscenes and no atmosphere. You sit behind  chest-high walls and defeat enemy waves. Other times you watch bland cut-scenes or go through some uninspiring  flashbacks. I propably should mention the jump scares as well; They come off as desperate attempt to catch even a glimpse of the atmosphere of the previous games.            In the previous games you always felt somewhat sad for Alma's predicament and what had been done to her. That's a sign of good writing and it gave the games a great atmosphere. All that is gone in this 3rd instalment. First F.E.A.R. was a classic. It added bullet-time and horror elements to an fps game. It had good writing, aggressive combat and great A.I. It was an ambitious game. F.E.A.R. 3 on the other hand is mediocre in every respect. It's a mediocre Call of Duty game with some "horror" sprinkled on top of it.  The horror effects only remind the gamer, of the better F.E.A.R. games. "Oh hey! I remember that better FEAR game that was actually good. Maybe I should play that instead."5,5/10

Posted: February 4, 2016
												The final entry in the F.E.A.R. franchise as of this writing, F.E.A.R. 3 provides a much better story than that of F.E.A.R. 2 (which could fit on a post-it and was generally non-existant and boring), better visuals, better performance and much better gameplay. Is it better than F.E.A.R. 1? No, but it's a lot of fun in single player (I don't play co-op) and offers a campaign both as Point Man and Fettel, with the Point Man being the protagnist of the first game and Fettel being a ghost, offering interesting dynamics. The shooting is fast and fluid and the bullet-time mechanics the franchise is known far work beautifully in a series of shootouts involving soldiers and mechs providing a varied challenge. The addition of stick to cover mechanics isn't distracting. Although the shooting takes place mostly in tightly scripted sequences of areas with the occasional signposting problem where you need to look around to figure out where to go next, the steady clip of the action punctuated by good cutscenes maintains a solid pace throughout. A satisfying conclusion to the series that redeems the pathetic F.E.A.R. 2 and although I'd have liked more of the super intelligent AI of F.E.A.R. 1, this'll do.

Posted: February 5, 2014
												This game is actually creepy and actually scary in a startling way, it would be funny to invite your big tough friends over and watch them jump and scream like little girls while you play it. Maybe once I get my new speakers i'll do just that, that will be priceless.The game itself is pretty straight forward, you go from level to level and kill all the bad guys, each level has different types of bad guys sometimes there are soldiers and sometimes there are psychos with bombs strapped to their bodies and other ones who throw knives at you.I think for an older game they did really well putting it together, I've never really played a game that was so creepy before, once through the game though I think it will lose its appeal. 												Mit F.E.A.R. 3 oder auch F.3.A.R. kam ein Spiel auf den Markt, an das hohe Erwartungen gestellt wurden - leider blieben diese völlig unerfüllt. Die Spieleserie wurde zu einem reinen Shooter heruntergewirtschaftet und der eingebaute "Horror" ist eine blanke Lächerlichkeit. Zu allem Überfluss lässt die Story zu wünschen übrig und die beiden Endings, die man erhalten kann, lassen mehr Fragen offen, als beantwortet werden.Wenn man ein Shooter-Liebhaber ist und gerne lineare Storylines ohne mehr als Herumgeballere spielt und auch glaubt, dass Horror nur aus Blut und Explosionen von Menschen besteht, wenn man ein Achievementhunter ist und auf Scores achtet, dem würde ich es zweifelsohne empfehlen. Wenn euch jedoch die F.E.A.R.-Reihe am Herzen liegt: kauft euch F.E.A.R. 3 nicht. Mehr als schießen und durch die Level rushen findet ihr da leider nicht mehr.

												Alma returns in but this time her sons Point Man and Paxton Fettel introduce divergent co-op. Your distinctly different abilities affecting their own play as well as the experience of their co-op partner. There is single player or co-op modes as Point Man, a genetically enhanced super soldier originally introduced in F.E.A.R., and with him can shoot enemies with many weapons you will find on your way or can play cooperatively as his conniving brother Paxton Fettel, whose incredible telekinetic power has given him life beyond the grave.
