Posted: June 15, 2015
												A well made shooter with good atmosphere and impressive action. People seem to hate this one because it's unlike the other F.E.A.R titles but saying this game sucks is totally unfair. Personally, I would suggest this game to everyone even to the fans of the first F.E.A.R games, if they can pull their heads up their asses and just enjoy the game.

Posted: June 19, 2014
												I AM ONLY RECOMMENDING THIS IF YOU HAVE A CO-OP PARTNER!This game is a giant step down from FEAR 1 and FEAR 2.It makes me think that the studio fired everyone fromthose games, then hired away bunch of the best people from other studios who assisted on other top FPSs, but forgot the most important parts: a game designer, a lead writer and voice talent.So, the graphics are good, AI is still quite good, pacing is quite good, and environments are interesting. But they all also feel very GENERIC.The voices are bad, especially Alma's voice. Her only "line" is screaming, but it sounds like some random girl they pulled off the street. It stands out badly and wrecks the experience whenever it happens.The dialogue is terrible, and while the other games in the series' stories were nothing to write home about, this one's plotjust plain stupid and incoherent. Literally every chapter ends with the hero falling down a hole or having his vehicle exploded, which conveniently means that each level starts with him having lost all of his weapons in the previous level. THIS IS BAD DESIGN.Design-wise, the first 2 games were great in that lighting, sound cues and level design always had you looking and moving in the right direction. This one seems to have sound cues, but they're just parts of the soundtrack, so a little spooky chime that would have coincided with a crawling enemies scurrying past is just meaningless in this game. I found myself just plain missing some of the intended jump stares because I was turned in the wrong direction in this game, while that never happened in the other games. This game frequently resorts to graffitti arrows to guide you from arena-type area to arena-type area. Needing to do that should be a sign for developers that their game design SUCKS.They totally removed the great sound design and cues from the first 2 games and replaced it with a run-of-the-mill, looping soundtrack that doesn't match ingame dynamics closely enough.They also went with a rechargeable health mechanic that I don't think is as good for this series as the first aid kit model that all of the other games had. FEAR1 and 2 basically just made sure you were stocked up on health after every battle, which is just as unrealistic as the Halo model, but made each battle feel like a self-contained test of skill. Switching that model makes the basic feel of this game just feel out of character, and you can frequently just go hide behind a crate in the corner and recharge ad nauseum.Also, the bullet time mechanic gets drained MUCH faster than in the other games and recharges much more slowly. I found myself in bullet time around 50% of the time in FEAR2 but only about 20% of the time here. Instead, all of the typical enemies are much less balanced to the character than before. In the other games, it was almost impossible to get through most encounters without bullet time because of that balance, but here, you only really need it during boss fights. Again, it really doesn't feel like a FEAR game as a reult.They added a cover system that I basically never used, because you stay in 1st person perspective staring at the wall when you're in cover, which makes it a huge tactical disadvantage.One of the most stupid things they added is an experience point system that affects how long you can bullet time and how many extra ammo clips you can carry. You get experience points via a series of way-too-gamey "achievements". What that means is that to get the most experience, you have to stop using a weapon after getting 10-25 kills with it, because each weapon only has one level of achievement. So, instead of using the best weapon available, you're forced to drop a good weapon after you've met its "quota" if you want to maximize your bullet time. This is STUPID. Even more stupid is achievements for using bullet time and cover that mean you'll want to start each level by sitting in cover for 200 seconds and use 5 minutes each level draining and recharging bullet time from max to empty a bunch of times to get those achievements. It's a design decision that breaks the flow of the game and rewards playing out of character. THIS IS IMMERSION BREAKING.CO-OP is VERY FUN in this game, despite all of the problems. Gunplay is quite nice and reminiscent of Homefront, CoD, etc.The game is really designed to be played in CO-OP and it's disappointing that there's no AI "brother" companion during single-player. Him not being there during the shooting doesn't make sense in terms of the (badly written) story.All in all, there's no reason to play this game unless you're:1. Playing it CO-OP2. Are out of other FPS's to playPlease note that the FEAR1 DLC's stories have been retconned out of this game, so it's not even really worth playing if you somehow feel invested in the trilogy's story enough to need to see the ending.

Posted: March 19, 2016
												FEAR has been apart of my life since it first came out. Hearing the whispers of Alma and having her appear again and again eviscerating and tearing apart anyone in her way. While FEAR 3 is not the favorite among many players...it does keep up with the story along with shocking conclusions and revelations. The game runs great honestly...while lacking in color. I run at 4096*2160 resolution and had Reshade and an ENB in my game for the best visuals.The combat was great, you can take cover, be tactical or use slow mo and take out five men in three seconds.While there was an obvious lack of jump scares as compared to the first game and its add-ons, the overall atmosphere, gore, ideas and thought in the level detail kind of makes up for it.I wish Alma could have been more of a main character in this game, even speaking more to the players as a source of background.Overall it is a great game and a great series. I give it an 8.5/10 since I wish there was more jump scares. I hope there is a fourth game as well!

Posted: August 10, 2012
												Here's the deal, F.E.A.R. 3 is nothing like the other two entires. Remotely. It is a Call-of-Dutified entry to the series which has its fair share of "F.E.A.R. moments", though at a caveat, being delivered with a horribly inconsistent difficulty and a tedious combat system. As far as its story goes, it is passable, with none of the bells and whistles of the original two games with their expansive "voicemail messages" (F.E.A.R.) and "intel documents" (F.E.A.R. 2). Ending = crap. Also to be noted is the increasingly nauseating gore-factor, which is not for the weak of heart (or stomach). The graphics are pretty average, the sound effects atmospheric, though interrupted consistently by the in-game achievements (terribly, terribly integrated). That's right, the constantly popping achievements (in-game, not Steam) are one of my greatest gripes, as it really draws from the experience, as you could imagine, though thankfuly, this is not too much of an experience to be missed.6/10

content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												[Serious]So let me just say, I have beaten this game twice. Once by myself, and a second time with a friend. This game is, plain and simple, fun. It fails to deliver as a third installment to the "F.E.A.R." series (not counting expansions). The story is bland, but picks up after the 1st/2nd game. But the leveling system in the campaign, the "slow-mo" effect you love to use, and overall combat, is just stupid FPS fun. The game is also short, so while at risk for being reptitive, it can be beaten in 1 sitting. Play this game with a friend if you can, and you're sure to have a good time. The diversity of game mechanics between the brothers, while not completely different, is a nice attempt to see. One brother can slow down time, while the other can possess enemies. Personally, I say get it on sale, and you shouldn't be regretting your purchase. It's just too bad it went more action, over the "F.E.A.R." we were given from the first.Also, this game doesn't give a fug. Some of the things that happen in the story, is just ridiculous. I'M FED UP WITH THIS WUUURRRRLLLLDDD!!!!!!!

But if you get it for cheap, can bare 60 fov and have absolutely nothing better to do.. go for it.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												Now this, is a co-op oriented kind of game, it truly is. Almost every bit of the game was made for you and you friend(s). There's 5 gamemodes total. First, the co-op campaign of course, the main dish. And then you got the Contractions mode, which is basically a survival mode, with tons of enemies, several boss fights, while you got the EPA to fight back. There's also a Soul King mode, in another words, is your turn to play the scary ghost to hunt AIs down. All you need to do is possess and kill, yeah including your friends, remember they're playing ghosts as well. Next one, the Soul Survivor mode, I'd say this is a co-op survival mode combined with zombie infection and PvP. You, or one of your friends would be chosen to become spectre randomly, his or her mission is to take the friends down and corrupt them, to make them become spectres, while you guys are fighting the AI. Finally, the Fahking Run mode, just run, and don't look behind. Help your teammates, don't let him or her get caught by that massive WALL OF DEATH which crossovered from Mummy the film.In conclusion, this game is totally worth the price. There's a leveling system, you can earn the exp by accomplishing the goals, and in each level, you'll get various reward, such as Slow-Mo duration increased etc.. And almost all of the gamemodes can be play in your own, nevertheless if it's a multiplayer mode.HOWEVER, there's still two downsides. FIRST, there is no fahking in-game chat, yes, there's none, you gotta chat with your mates via steam while you're shooting the replica soldiers, and let me tell you, it is one pain in the♥♥♥♥♥♥indeed, and keep in mind, all 5 modes within the game are co-op, too. SECOND, although the co-op campaign is the main dish, it is still too short, which is sad. I beat this game for like 6 hours, and there's only 8 intervals, and the final one got nothing to shoot at, except for the final boss fight.Now if you can take those downsides, just go ahead and buy it then.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												I really wanted to like this game. I was a big fan of the first two in the series and was looking forward to an epic apocalyptic conclusion. This game dropped the ball on so many levels. It turned a FPS with an interesting story into just a straight FPS and threw the story away. I did enjoy playing as Fettel, but that was all. Alma was hardly threatening, Sgt Beckett died a pointless death, and the stupid Alma cultists....don't get me started. The graphics were on par with F.E.A.R. 2. I have heard that this game is fun on multiplayer, but I don't buy a game just for a multiplayer option. I buy and play for a story. Fear had it all: action and story!....until now.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												If you're looking at buying this game because you loved the previous games, don't.  It's got very little in common with them except the plot.  It's got none of the atmosphere that the previus games had.  There is no fear.  I am not saying the previous games were all that scary, but they had the genuinely spooky quality to them, F.E.A.R. 3 doesn't.  It really tries to show that it's a F.E.A.R. game, but all the blood and gore in the world won't bring back that feeling you got when you first heard Alma laugh right behind you and when you turn all you see the mere flicker of a shadow run past your periphery.They took everything that made the first games unique and awesome and made this another COD clone.  They replaced armor and health packs with regenerating health.  They limit your ammo supply, but leave lots of it lying around to pick up.  The SloMo drains too fast and isn't fun to use anymore.  There is no resource management, just run and gun.  The nerf to the SloMo combined with pre-positioned enemies takes all the fun away from anticipating where the enemy is coming from, using SloMo to catch them early and gunning down three to four enemies before they can react properly like the badass you're supposed to be.I am not saying the games sucks, it's just not I wanted or expected.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												What is F.E.A.R. 3?--F.E.A.R. 3 is a twisted sequel to the F.E.A.R. series of psychic-horror first person shooter games. F.E.A.R. 3, however, is more of a co-op arcade cover based FPS with some very light psychic-horror elements.----Who would most enjoy F.E.A.R. 3?--If you're looking for a fast-pased co-op FPS, with a darker twist, F.E.A.R. 3 may be an enjoyable pick-up. The game fails to deliver the ambient terror and jump-scares of the previous title, and has a far weaker delivery of plot than its predecessors. That being said, it can make for an entertaining competative co-op experience, and provides a substantial amount of replay value, if that's what you're looking for.----Over-all: 62.5%F.E.A.R. falls short in a lot of areas where the previous titles excelled, providing a weaker experience over-all. The game provides more replayability than any of the previous titles, but with that said, I'm not convinced that this is a good thing, on it's own, as the core gaming experience just isn't enjoyable enough to replay.--Mechanics: 3/5The mechanical flow of F.E.A.R. 3 is inferior to it's predecessor, F.E.A.R. 2. The AI is slightly less interesting, and largely more annoying to play against, the movement and cover system is functional, but not exactly fluid, as are the weapons. On top of this, the bullet-time (core mechanic) feels less fluid and less functional than in previous games.--Experience: 2/5The textures of F.E.A.R. 3 have been updated, but the stylization was a serious turn-off for me. The game felt visually cheap, arcadey, and generally far from immursive. The audio fell short in all regards as well, providing much less emphasis towards the atmosphere than in previous titles, and in places, distracting from the atmosphere (enemy AI call-outs). Balance: 3/5Some weapons clearly out-class others, and are just as accessible, and the bullet-time mechanic seems to have been gutted to a degree. This aside, the game is decently balanced, and rarely overly frustrating, but the general balance is anything but remarkable.--Longevity: 4.5/5If you can get past the short-comings of the game, it does provide a lot of content. There's a level-up system, two different viewpoints to play the campaign from, and a fairly decent co-op mechanic. Beyond that, there's a competative element, using an elaborate point system, and for the speed runners out there, a tracker for completion time.

												I have played this all the way through, although with more than a fair dose of disappointment, from the outset. I have always enjoyed the F.E.A.R. series in the past until now.  This is a terrible end to what used to be a wonderful and atmospheric storyline. F.E.A.R.  was blazing a trail all of it's own until F3 came along.The graphics may be slightly nicer but that's where the positives just shoot off at a tangent. The gameplay is mediocre - The difficulty is variable - The storyline was written like it was done by imaganative kids at best - The atmosphere and immersiveness of the previous offerings is overwhelmingly and completley extinct in this version.  Don't buy it.I only played it through after paying for it like a lamb to the slaughter. Damn sure I was seeing it through to the end, even if it pained my soul to do so. Forever scarred - I can't unsee what has been seen.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												The third chapter of this game is a bit disappointing but it has its good points....only for the fans of the FEAR series...Classic FPS, shoot at everything you see and, if you don't know FEAR yet...welll...expect a total horror movie style gameplay (with creepy sounds, messy dark hud in some situations, monsters spawning from nowhere etc...).The story is connected to the previous two chapters of the game; but this time Fettel and Point Man will be friends and they will cooperate to fight Alma....or well....at least they will try to cooperate....Gameplay, as you expect, is the usual AIM - SHOOT - KILL - LOOK AROUND - AIM - SHOOT - KILL - LOOK AROUND - AIM - SHOOT - KILL - LOOK AROUND - and so on. There aren't too many secrets or loots to find. So it's pretty pretty linear.Graphic is good with some good effects, but let's be honest...for the scenarios sometimes the textures could be better...even if the final result is still pretty coolNice arsenal of weapon to use but....they really satisfy us?...The gore level, as you expect from a game like FEAR, is really really high. You will easly see ripped body parts flying all over your screen...but....not everyone likes that...The longevity....well....that's a huge no no no....even if we play at the highest difficulty the game will still be too much easy and too much short. Ok if we finish the game with Point Man (the only character we can use in single player the first time) we will unlock Fettel. So we can play the game again as Fettel with a total different combat system (Point Man is a soldier...Fettel is an undead man with psychicl powers...yes fun to use but...is that enough?),So what's the good point if we like the FEAR series? The coop indeed! Ok this will make the game even more shorter (two peeps is better than one alone...) but at least you will always have a bit of fun because as always, playing togheter is better than playing alone.So if you are a FEAR fan and you have a friend (or a girlfriend/boyfriend) to play with....go ahead and buy the game!If you are looking for a good co-op game and you are not into FEAR...well....skip this game...there is better out there!Overall:Graphic 6/10Sounds 8/10Gameplay 6/10Longevity 4/10Fun 5/10 (alone) 7/10 (Co-op)

The powers available between the 2 characters make for a diffrent gameplay experience, which adds a unique flavor to the fps genre. This is one game that does achievments and  hidden items damn near perfectly, mostly 'cause it always give you points towards increasing your chracters abilities.  Add in interesting if convluted story (Fear 2:( ), great atmosphere and a minor competetive element and this is one of the best coop experiences of the year.Grab a friend and play 9/10 (co-op)

												F.E.A.R. is a game series that does a pretty good job at combining the FPS and horror genres by taking aspects from both (Specifically by throwing you into the middle of an intense, non-stop gunfight with jump scares around every corner). F.E.A.R. 3 is a nice addition to the series and a fun game to play my only complaint is that it's just not long enough. There are only a handful of levels that you could knock out on your lunch break which is disappointing seeing as to how intriguing the plot actually is. Still I'd definately reccomend this game to anyone who is a fan of horror games or shooters, crank the difficulty all the way up for maximum intensity.

												Tight combination of scares and creepiness with basic but solid first person tactical shooter.  A few jump scares and a creepy little girl are the main plot points, and they work although get repetitive by this the third installment (FEAR 2 is my favorite of the series).  Has slow motion time which helps make the game playable for people like myself that don't have great fast twitch reflexes, but if you like a more challenging shooter just don't use the slow mo ability and FEAR 3 will then be plenty challenging.  I’m not a big FPS fan myself, but even so I found the story and scary atmosphere along with the slow mo powers intriguing enough to have played all 3 games in the series, for what its worth.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												Unshackled from original developer Monolith, FEAR 3 was always going to come up against resistance.  Early impressions seem to justify this – the graphics are terrible (with a poorly optimised PC port),  the story is now more preposterous and impenetrable than ever, and there’s a bizarre focus on co-op that sits poorly with its horror themes. It’s hard not to draw comparisons with Dead Space 3, another horror franchise taken in a direction nobody asked for, that became more and more action orientated in an ill-conceived bid to make the franchise more accessible.Of course, calling FEAR a horror game is stretching it a bit. Even the excellent original was never truly scary – while it was tense and oppressively atmospheric, being armed with a machine gun and having the ability to slow down time was always going to take the edge off things. However, the horror elements were always fairly subtle – a girlish laugh here, a flitting shadow there. FEAR 2 largely abandoned this sadly, though it did contain the amazing elementary school level – probably the most creepy and sinister level in any FEAR game. FEAR 3, even forgetting the co-op elements, has horror elements so obvious and poorly considered that it is borderline parody. Alma, the series’ resident lank haired J-horror ghost (several years too late to the party even back in 2005) seems like she can barely be bothered even when she does deign to appear. There is a section late on where you’re on an escalator, and the Alma is just going in the opposite direction. You maintain eye contact as you pass, and it’s probably the least scary thing ever – you can just imagine her giving a half hearted shrug or honking a comedy horn.The core of the game, FEAR’s kinetic slo-mo combat, is thankfully still present and correct. The biggest change is that the game has dispensed with the armour and medpack system of previous game. My initial thoughts were ones of revulsion, but honestly it does work – supplies were so plentiful in the first two that you might as well have had fading health anyway, and your ability to pop medkits like skittles during combat made the normal difficulty a cakewalk – FEAR 2 in particular was almost insultingly easy.FEAR 3 is significantly harder as a result which is a welcome change, but the difficulty is uneven with some pretty horrible spikes later on. It’s obvious that some of the encounters were built with co-op in mind – there does not appear to be any concessions made to a single player. There’s a bigger variety of enemies compared to previous games too, but unfortunately these enemies are pretty one note compared to human opposition. I’m not sure that FEAR, known to for its excellent AI, really benefits from throwing zombies into the mix.But when you are fighting human opposition, the game sings – the gunplay is heavy and sharp, and the AI seems to have got its edge back after the lightweights of FEAR 2. The slo-mo gauge both empties faster and charges up more slowly, and though this can be improved with a poorly considered CoD style levelling system (why?), unlike previous games this ability is something you use when you need it rather than just clearing whole rooms. This is mainly down to enemies coming in waves, which adds a welcome level of resource management to every fight.I should probably cover that co-op mode as well. The game is built from the ground up to support this, which is a bizarre decision in a single player horror themed franchise. There’s a competition element that determines the ending of the game, but psychic ghost Paxton Fettle (still sporting his fetching bullet wound in his head) is so much more powerful (and entertaining) that it makes this part of the game a little trivial. Sadly in the single player you are limited to scowling mute beard-on-a stick Pointman until you have finished the game, and I don’t see this being a favourite to revisit.So then. Is FEAR 3 worthy of your time? Despite this review being something of a laundry list of complaints, it’s testament to the game’s core appeal that the whole package is still an enjoyable enough diversion. It never strays into greatness, but nor is it the abomination that it is often portrayed as. It’s just a shame that this will be how the series ends – a confused grab at the mass market that dilutes the appeal that made FEAR popular in the first place.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2011
												It's a shame FEAR 3 didn't sell. But I understand why. I'm a huge fan of the original FEAR developed by Monolith Productions, but its expansion packs developed by Timegate were not very good. Then FEAR 2 was lackluster, and Monolith made that one themselves! When FEAR 3 was announced as a Day One Studios title, we all sort of wrote it off. But it's the best pure FPS of 2011.Part 1 opted for J-Horror stylings. FEAR 3 doesn't attempt to be scary and fail. It just doesn't attempt. This is fine, because the thing I like about FEAR was its gunplay. The guns, the quite competent enemy squad AI, the slow motion effects. FEAR 3 brings this all back to form (2 felt a bit too "console-y") with two additions. The cover system is thankfully quite non-intrusive and doesn't reduce the game to "whack-a-mole" a la Gears of War. Co-op play is where it's at. In fact, the game is built for it. Don't play any other way or you may find it impossible. Note: the 2nd player has slightly superior powers.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												I've seen playthroughs of the previous two FEARs and it's pretty obvious that a new company made this one. The game feels like an average FPS rather than a true FEAR game. Most of the time you will be fighting soldiers and it doesn't feel too scary, although as you get closer to the end, the more "FEARy" the game gets. There are  a total of 8 missions , which brings me to the next unfortunate bit, the length of the game. It took me and my mate a little bit over 4 hours to complete the game which is a bit sad because, in general, the world felt awesome and I would've loved to continue playing it. What is a huge + to the game is the  co-op portion . The game is really fun to play together with a friend, which is where the difference of the two playable characters comes into play. You often find yourself in a situation where you need to rely on your mate. You get a decent story in a beautiful environment and after a long coop game you and your mate face a sudden twist that will make you either smile or frown,  the one who gets the highest score gets his characters' ending cinematic, Anna lives or DIES .  Based on all these points, I think this game is  worth to buy  from a steam sale if you've got a mate to play with.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												Unshackled from original developer Monolith, FEAR 3 was always going to come up against resistance.  Early impressions seem to justify this – the graphics are terrible (with a poorly optimised PC port),  the story is now more preposterous and impenetrable than ever, and there’s a bizarre focus on co-op that sits poorly with its horror themes. It’s hard not to draw comparisons with Dead Space 3, another horror franchise taken in a direction nobody asked for, that became more and more action orientated in an ill-conceived bid to make the franchise more accessible.Of course, calling FEAR a horror game is stretching it a bit. Even the excellent original was never truly scary – while it was tense and oppressively atmospheric, being armed with a machine gun and having the ability to slow down time was always going to take the edge off things. However, the horror elements were always fairly subtle – a girlish laugh here, a flitting shadow there. FEAR 2 largely abandoned this sadly, though it did contain the amazing elementary school level – probably the most creepy and sinister level in any FEAR game. FEAR 3, even forgetting the co-op elements, has horror elements so obvious and poorly considered that it is borderline parody. Alma, the series’ resident lank haired J-horror ghost (several years too late to the party even back in 2005) seems like she can barely be bothered even when she does deign to appear. There is a section late on where you’re on an escalator, and the Alma is just going in the opposite direction. You maintain eye contact as you pass, and it’s probably the least scary thing ever – you can just imagine her giving a half hearted shrug or honking a comedy horn.The core of the game, FEAR’s kinetic slo-mo combat, is thankfully still present and correct. The biggest change is that the game has dispensed with the armour and medpack system of previous game. My initial thoughts were ones of revulsion, but honestly it does work – supplies were so plentiful in the first two that you might as well have had fading health anyway, and your ability to pop medkits like skittles during combat made the normal difficulty a cakewalk – FEAR 2 in particular was almost insultingly easy.FEAR 3 is significantly harder as a result which is a welcome change, but the difficulty is uneven with some pretty horrible spikes later on. It’s obvious that some of the encounters were built with co-op in mind – there does not appear to be any concessions made to a single player. There’s a bigger variety of enemies compared to previous games too, but unfortunately these enemies are pretty one note compared to human opposition. I’m not sure that FEAR, known to for its excellent AI, really benefits from throwing zombies into the mix.But when you are fighting human opposition, the game sings – the gunplay is heavy and sharp, and the AI seems to have got its edge back after the lightweights of FEAR 2. The slo-mo gauge both empties faster and charges up more slowly, and though this can be improved with a poorly considered CoD style levelling system (why?), unlike previous games this ability is something you use when you need it rather than just clearing whole rooms. This is mainly down to enemies coming in waves, which adds a welcome level of resource management to every fight.I should probably cover that co-op mode as well. The game is built from the ground up to support this, which is a bizarre decision in a single player horror themed franchise. There’s a competition element that determines the ending of the game, but psychic ghost Paxton Fettle (still sporting his fetching bullet wound in his head) is so much more powerful (and entertaining) that it makes this part of the game a little trivial. Sadly in the single player you are limited to scowling mute beard-on-a stick Pointman until you have finished the game, and I don’t see this being a favourite to revisit.So then. Is FEAR 3 worthy of your time? Despite this review being something of a laundry list of complaints, it’s testament to the game’s core appeal that the whole package is still an enjoyable enough diversion. It never strays into greatness, but nor is it the abomination that it is often portrayed as. It’s just a shame that this will be how the series ends – a confused grab at the mass market that dilutes the appeal that made FEAR popular in the first place.

												This game is quite possibly one of the worst games I have ever played. Even Colonial Marines was more fun than this. I'm doing Coop and so far my experience has been having a completly useless ghost partner that for about 45 seconds can do stuff and me stuck killing everything else. Now this would be fun if the ai weren't shooting hitscan projectiles with pinpoint accuracy with an incredibly ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cover system and terrible controls. Ontop of if the AI is literally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and the only reason the game is slightly hard is the hitscan. You can grab a riot shield and just melee the base commanders (a super strong boss that is super original totally not just another human with a blue shield) and take literally zero damage and just click for 45 seconds. I killed 4 like that and that was probably the most fun I had in the game was how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and broken it was. Hell I'm writing this because the game has given me Vietnam style flashbacks of horrible Voice Acting, game play, level desing and bugs. So my useless ghost friend as we walk across a huge interstate above the ocean is battle mechs that blow up but oh wait if you get out of them they get full health instantly and don't actually blow up, he got out to revive me and got stuck in a wall forcing us to fight 2 helicopters for 5 minutes again in a fight that takes zero skill since you just hop out and get full health again. This game is pure♥♥♥♥♥♥and anyone that disagrees has even worse tastes in Video Games than people that liked COD Ghost. The fact that Colonial Marines is better than this♥♥♥♥♥♥is just sad. Oh and literally none of the game was scary it was just horrifically unfun, unchallenging and a waste of 5$. Oh I also forgot it has cool interactions like opening doors or pushing through revolving doors all the ♥♥♥♥ing time to slow down the game play even more.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Tight combination of scares and creepiness with basic but solid first person tactical shooter.  A few jump scares and a creepy little girl are the main plot points, and they work although get repetitive by this the third installment (FEAR 2 is my favorite of the series).  Has slow motion time which helps make the game playable for people like myself that don't have great fast twitch reflexes, but if you like a more challenging shooter just don't use the slow mo ability and FEAR 3 will then be plenty challenging.  I’m not a big FPS fan myself, but even so I found the story and scary atmosphere along with the slow mo powers intriguing enough to have played all 3 games in the series, for what its worth.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2012
												FEAR 3 seems to get a rough review from PC players as opposed to the generally positive reviews from the press, which is sometimes the case.  I personally enjoy FEAR 3 and love the series.  Yes this game is very different from FEAR 1, no med packs, armor... you have regen health and so on.  I was not a fan of the cover system in this game, nor holding "e" to open items and such.  This said those issues are minor complaints for this game.  The graphics, granted are not state of the art but I loved the atmosphere and style.  It is bloody for sure, not a whole lot of scares but some good scenery and interesting locales.  The sound and music were awesome, I really enjoyed the soundtrack for this game.  FEAR 3 brings to the table co-op and mutiplayer.  I have played several rounds of the off line multiplayer mode which is similar to wave style format and though it was clever and well done.  There are different modes to the multiplayer which mix it up.  FEAR 3 was a fantastic purchase at $5 back in the summer I have no regrets.  ...Did I mention you get to play as Fettel - how cool is that?, you unlock him after each interval is cleared with "Point Man". ✓Recommended.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
												F.E.A.R. 1 was brilliant. The following expansion packs added a good punch to the storyline. F.E.A.R. 2 was also pretty good, while adding a ton to the wonderful story.Then came F.E.A.R. 3. This game is from a different development studio. The engine appears to be different, the models and environments have a new artistic style, and the gameplay isn't even close to the original. If you like arcade-style games, then you will enjoy this game. Between each "mission", you get a stats page showing you how well you did in the previous mission, as well as what items and rankings you unlocked. This is not at all what I had hoped for. I was looking for a more seamless storyline, like what F.E.A.R. 1 & 2 had. Granted, I would put up with the arcade-style of gameplay for this new game in order to learn more about the F.E.A.R. story arc. But it appears that the new studio had no interest in the previous storylines, and went in their own direction. This game almost feels like an "inspired by F.E.A.R." game, as opposed to the officially sanctioned game that it really is. Warner Bros. should be more careful with this IP in the future; it has so much potential, but F.E.A.R. 3 was a slap in the face of the original story idea.

MP modes are varied and interesting.Cons: The plot barely progresses(as usual), and there's no chilling background info this time. MP is(or was, when I played) bugged beyond playing, and thus dead. Even mech-use feels as scripted and linear as it is.My recommendation: Skip this one. Read the plot online, if you must know it.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												F.E.A.R. 3 is a third part of F.E.A.R. - first person shooter horror series. You have to get scared, you have to shoot, no exact point of the game.Gameplay / StoryI've played all F.E.A.R.s - 1,2 and finaly 3. Well, I enjoyed first and second part much more than the third. Maybe it is a good story, but the game developers made it look and feel WAY too bad. Seriously, the story is shown very bad - a voice acting is bad, cut-scenes are bad and.. basicly how is story tolerated is bad! Gameplay dissapointed me even more. I cannot say its unplayable, but taking cover, runing, jumping, shooting - it all SUCKS in this game. I mean its so messed up, that it makes camera shake and bug. Speaking of bugs, this game has A LOT of them. I bearly finished the whole game. I thought its the end of the nightmare, but no! There is also a cooperation mode which is EVEN WORSE THAN SINGLEPLAYER. Seriously, its even more unplayable. They shouldn't have even done it. Oh, I almost forgot - I finished whole campaign in 3 hours ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥it.Sounds / Atmosphere / Level designWhole game sounded like a good game.. but from 5 years earlier. Sounds were more like for a sci-fi game, in a space, on a spaceship - not for a horror game, on Earth, on our freakin planet. Global atmosphere was fatal. Game wasn't scary at all. I finished this during one night and gone to bed with no nightmares. Level design is slighty better, and I can say the best of these three. But the 'open areas' were realy 'closed' sometimes, cause developers were too lazy to make some skyboxes in some locations.GraphicsHere is what is as bad as gameplay is. I mean, its not THAT bad.. sorry... graphics... BUT YOU LOOK SO MAINSTREAM. Seriously, was that supposed to be a sci-fi game or a horror game? I must say though - models are made very good, and animations are also good (not these for weapons), but everything looks bad because of lame shaders. Damn, developers, that was THAT hard to make a Lens Flare shaders, that you included a fake ones in the sprites? Come on, guys...So...as I said - I enjoyed FEAR 1st and 2nd more than 3th part. I do not recommend buying this game if you've got a slow PC. I recommend buying it when its on a bargain, cause 20 ♥♥♥♥in Euros is WAY TOO MUCH for this game.4.5/10

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												Background: I'm a very casual shooter fan and pretty undemanding on story while more interested in mechanics and overall experience. Originality certainly helps and appreciate memorable elements of any kind. I rate Crysis 2 as one of the greatest of the genre. I liked FEAR but was indifferent to part 2. Played Fear 3's campaign to the end but little of the multiplayer.Impressions:The engine looks ok and the shooting mechanics solid. There's a lot of realism in the world and gun play.. but that world is also drab and the enemies not particularly fun to shoot. The sound is really solid and the grunts chatter is situation appropriate and appears to intelligently adapt to how you engage them. However they also appear to be psychic calling your moves without eyes on you and are impossible to flank as they always seem to have a bead on you which dampens the fun of being a superior soldier, it feels like the game wants you to only ever take on frontal assaults in slow-mo and rely on your healing to save you every time. Makes 'Dead Space 3' feel like a a masterpiece of horror (another sadly tamed down, but still superior game) as it utterly fails to pull off scares, none are original or unexpected. I noted several early scripted jumps were totally mistimed as I was looking the wrong way or had already moved past the location. Overall there is a lack of polish and placeholder elements are all to obivous, for example flapping fabric elements are replaced with static 1 pixel thick sprites that jut out at as if they are stiff as a board.The Good:*Decent graphics and general audio.*The cover mechanic works well and gives some options.*Magic healing is handy but almost too handy.*Gun play is decent but unimaginative.*Linear route stops you getting lost.*Grunt conversations are pretty realistic and dynamic.The Bad:*Seriously disliked the Main menu interface, found it confusing.*World is very drab in the early stages and the grunts too hard to see.*Some textures and locations lack detail that jar in an otherwise more impressive world.*Gun sights actively make it harder to see the intended target.*For a cover game you rely on slow-mo far too much.*Grunts track you too well limiting flanking options.*Cover mechanic gets tedious and slows down the pace too far.*Weapons are boring standards and lack oomph or impact.*Fails at attempts at horror.*Slow-mo reveals the slack quality as, on a massively overspec'd machine, grunts jink making you deadeye shots miss. *Stealth seems to only apply when the developer wants you to use it.*Collectibles, upgrade points break immersion and other console tropes.*Linear route and narrow locations spoil exploration and experimentation.*Environment is destructible but rarely has any impact.*Story is too silly and becomes campy as cut-scenes lack impact and detail.Recommended for:3rd person shooter fans not looking for anything special to fill a gap, think more Call of Duty over Bioshock.Conclusion.5/10. Seriously disappointing shooter that seems confused by its realistic world and weapons attached to weak fantasy horror setting and characters.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2012
												Assai lontano dalla magnificenza del primo F.E.A.R, questo terzo capitolo non convince molto.La Campagna perde quasi totalmente la verve narrativa e le inqutanti scene horror che avevano caratterizato il brand,virando verso un stile molto "coddaro" ed a volte completamente no-sense.Detto questo la campagna si lascia godere, complice un gamplay caratterizato da bonus contestuali  che valorizzano molto il proseguo dell'avventura.Il multiplayer invece svolge il suo compito senza infamia ne lode, proponendo delle modalità co-op godibili e divertenti ma che non cattureranno il giocatore tanto allungo.Questo F.3.A.R è senza ombra di dubbio il titolo peggiore della serie. Paradossale come cosa visto che era stato annunciato come il grande capitolo conclusivo della serie, ed è un vero peccato che le avventure di Point Man, Fettel ed Alma terminino così.Voto 7,5\10

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												TL;DR - If you like co-op games and have friends to play with, get this game! 9/10 on the co-op scale. If you are a lone wolf type, move along.This game is great. Not because it is scary, but because the fun that can be had with others. If you were expecting a scary game just try the original F.E.A.R.. It was the only one in the series that was even remotely scary. Otherwise play Amnenisa.The story is somewhat forgettable but you never feel like you don't know what is going on (I'm looking at you Dead Space 3). The main reason to buy this game is for the co-op. This isn't your standard co-op run and gun either. Each player has their own abilities. While the hardest difficultly isn't extremely hard, you'll have to coordinate who uses what powers to help progress. I really did find this to be one of the best co-op games to date.F.E.A.R. 3's multiplayer modes also include co-op so there are things to do after beating the main game. "Fu**ing Run!" is by far my favorite! This mode has three maps which have you running from a wall could of death. You'll have to maneuver through the map and even enemies as they try to stop you. If one player dies, it is game over. So you can't leave anyone behind. Even on easy this is really hard to complete! "Contractions", another co-op game mode, has you holding up a building as waves of enemies try to kill everyone. The mode is fun, but can get a bit boring after awhile. The other two modes are death match style games that I do not care for and more than likely, you won't either. The downside to the multiplayer, it's kind of dead. No one hosts a game and you can't join mid-session. The online co-op game modes only allow up to four players but can be done with two.(If my time playing this game is low at the time you are reading this it is because I played through on the Xbox 360. I bought this for PC because I liked it so much.)

												While as a solo experience, it's just a disappointing followup to the previous games in the series, the inclusion of a second playable coop character with unique powers elevates it to a worthwhile use of your time. It's not especially interesting or polished, but the mechanics of the two player characters together makes it an enjoyable campaign to go through with a friend. It also tends to go on sale for very cheap, so if you're looking for a more coop stuff and have a friend to play with, you could do worse. Not my highest recommendation, but I had a good time playing as a ghost who can possess enemies and use their guns against them, because of course I did.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												I think Monolith are trying to run their business to the ground. I was certain that they had done the worst game that they possible could with F.E.A.R. 2, but lo and behold, they have proven me wrong. Amazingly, F.3.A.R. does the impossible and manages to be even worse than its predecessor. The horror elements were pretty much reduced to quick-time events in F.E.A.R. 2 and have been binned altogether by the third game; the gameplay is as uninspiring as ever with most enemies taking all of one headshot to kill; the story is completely nonsensical even if you ignore the first game and worse still if you do take it into account; and instead of the perplexing abortion of an ending that we got in F.E.A.R. 2, we now have TWO of the bloody things. Happily, the third game is even shorter than the second, taking only about three and a half agonizing hours to trawl through.Avoid like a crotch rot.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												♥ Diverse levels.I'm not one to mind repeating levels/maps in games however it's clear that they put effort into the design of Fear's world. I quite liked how each chapter was a change from the last...you explore a variety of buildings and are put into a number of situations, instead of facing the same boss over and over again, or being forced into a series of mazes. Diversity in its design is a strong virtue of Fear 3. ♥ Made me jump.Though Fear 3 isn't nearly as scary as the past titles, it did have several spooky moments in it. Granted I'm a total scaredy cat yet who wouldn't jump at an angry little girl leaping at them while they're climbing up a ladder? ; _ ; ♥ Enjoyable co-op.Whenever someone has wanted to play a co-op game with me, I used to always suggest playing Fear 3 together. Why? For one the co-op is balanced, a fact that I appreciate. Unlike other games it has both players doing equal amount of work and requires teamwork without going overboard.For another, I liked how the average time to beat the game, at least for my friends and I, was around 8 to 12 hours. I liked having a game to invest time into without having to play it week after week with someone. I understand others have found the main story lacking time wise yet this was never a problem for me.In case you're bored or finish the main storyline, there are four, multiplayer, mini games to play. Very fun! ✘ The story IS lacking. I can understand people who value games by looking at all aspects - the sound, the story, the graphics, etc. I can also understand people who have the view of looking for one thing, excellent graphics, beautiful music, and the like above all else. For me what matters most is the story of a game. Compared to the other Fear titles, I agree that Fear 3 is lacking in its story. They could have taken it so much farther than they did - I found the relationship between the two main characters was filled with possibility that they seemed to purposely shove aside. I don't believe we need to be pirvy to every aspect of a character, however they made them seem like cardboard cut outs, instead of real...Humans, ghosts, aliens, there was no difference for they all acted flat and emotionally frigid. Not once when I've replayed Fear 3 have I ever felt a connection to any of them nor have I felt pulled in by the story. As scary as I found the first Fear to be, it DID pull me into the story and the world of Alma. The dev team had so much they could have worked with backstory wise, relationships between characters, etc. and used none of it. I'll stick to fanfiction to get an emotional high... ' - ' ✘ Very hard to play with motion sickness.As my motion sickness has gotten worse, I've had to give up playing many games, Fear 3 among them. Despite its flaws, I have always enjoyed the game, and would replay it every few months. If anyone suffering from motion sickness is thinking about buying it, I would strongly advice you to think twice, for the game isn't kind to those who suffer from it! ✘ I think the main reason people are let down with Fear 3 is when they buy it thinking it's going to be a horror game. Does it have jump scares? Yes. Is it spooky? To me it is. However unlike the others in the series, I consider Fear 3 a shooter/survival game more than anything. It's wonderful if you're looking for a co-op game, no fault there, but as a horror game? Not so much. Still it might give you a spook or two!Overall if you're looking for a co-op game, Fear 3 would make a wonderful choice. If you're considering it from the aspect of loving the Fear series, I'd skip it.

Review:You can play as Point Man, a genetically enhanced soldier with superhuman reflexes and the ability to manipulate time, or the undead spirit of his brother Paxton Fettel, a paranormal entity who possesses incredible psychic powers. content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
												Bite Size Review - FEAR 3The Good:- The slowdown mechanic is still satisfying in this game- A good variety of guns to play with- The setting (horror mixed with call of duty) is still interesting- Big robot sequences are some of my favorite partsThe Bad:- The story is very one note (need to get to Ulma)- Main character (Point Man) is unlikable and un-interesting- Some of the new mechanics like the cover system are less useful than just moving from out of cover with WASD- Less Horror levels/moments in this game, more Call of Duty- The first game in the series still has the best enemy AI and Horror inducing levels, this game takes a step back with both of these aspectsThe Verdict:This game is a bit of a mixed bag for me. On one hand if you are looking for a cheap 6 hour romp through a semi interesting game, this is a good choice. But the story is very linear and boiler plate, and the main character is a silent killer that has no personality at all. If it is on sale and you have played the previous two games, I would recommend it. Other wise, if you want to buy a game, buy the first one, it's better than this one and the second game.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												Full disclosure. I played this game before playing F.E.A.R. 1, it's DLC's or 2, and while I do recommend it, there are several large caveats and it's a tentative recommendation. Pros:- Looks pretty good, nothing extraordinary though- Co-op is fun- Multiplayer is pretty alright- Story was fairly interesting to me, if rather cliched. But perhaps it only interested me because I had no idea what was going on....ever.- Gameplay is ok- Multiple endingsCons:- 5 hours long, I was bloody awful at it and my co-op partner carried us, we respawned a LOT and it still only took us about 5 and a half hours.- Extremely linear, linearity isn't bad but Fear 3's linearity is similar to being on rails- Co-op gameplay is lopsided. Pointman's gameplay is well worn and honestly sort of boring but much easier, or Paxton, who has gameplay that's more fun yet not nearly as solid, it's much easier to do well in the grading system each mission insists on as Pointman as opposed to Paxton- Not horror, like not even a little.- MP servers are dead in the water- Repetitive gameplay- Questionable AI(at times)- Just mediocre, neither the graphics, nor the story, nor the non-existent horror help this game stand out.Now, did I have fun with it? Yeah i did, but more in the vein of it being a fun co-op shooter with a fairly interesting premise instead of it being a Fear game. I'd expected something else and got a fairly fun co-op shooter that's easy to shoot through.I recommend this to Die-heard FEAR fans, but even then only if it's on steep discount. Otherwise with the amount of other quality games that come out, buying this game for 20 dollars isn't worth it.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												I know I haven't finished the game yet, but I'm making an exception to my recent "never write a review until I've finished the game" rule, and here's why:F.E.A.R. 3 does not cooperate with Steam Cloud, meaning that if something happens and you have to reinstall Steam then F.E.A.R. 3 will not bring over your save files, meaning that you have to start the game again from the very beginning. This happened first when I uninstalled then reinstalled Steam to clean my disk space of all the redundant files leftover from Steam's updates. Afterwards I had to play F.E.A.R. 3 again from the very beginning, since I took a break from the game after reaching a particularily frustrating boss fight. Then just last week I sent my computer away to get an operating system upgrade, which also meant that I had to reinstall Steam, which coincided with another temporary F.E.A.R. break as I have hit another frustrating point in the game. Now that the game has reset a second time I actually have no intention of replaying everything again up to that point, so I am now writing this review to hold over until some time in the distant future when I decide to revisit the F.E.A.R. series.From a basic and simple list of pros and cons written during my experiences in the game, I have generally mixed feeling about F.E.A.R. 3 (herein referred to as F3): The game has a vast improvement on the story, which I felt was really lacking in the previous titles, I'm able to follow it better because I actually somewhat care about what's happening, which was not the case before. Previously the exposition for the story tested my patience because it distracted from the gameplay and wasn't particularily interesting. F3 is better here because the environments showcase the events going on, I actually see and feel the world tearing apart at the seams, and without saying too much, that is exactly what is happening and it is up to the player to stop it with some unexpected help. This is made even better because that annoying little girl who'd always jump out and go "ABOOGABOOGABOOGA" is barely around. Alma, you aren't scary, you're just wierd. Get lost and let me shoot things. But the drawback with story is that instead of little girl jumpscares, it has cutscenes. This wouldn't be such a bad thing if not for one flaw: You play as a silent protagonist. Silent protagonists work if you have control over them at all times, giving the player control during all story exposition and making them feel like they are the hero of the story, like Half-Life 2, which did the silent hero thing perfectly. F3 however has cutscenes with supporting characters directly addressing the hero, who never responds or shows any signs of reaction, just stands there silently glaring at everything. Do you see the problem here? But at least the shooting is fun, and when you are actually in control it makes sense to keep his yak shut.Speaking of shooting, my god is the combat in this game amped up. With the tense environments and the unsettling enemies you're up against the game should have combat that's fast paced and free flowing, right? Well yes and no. The actualy gunplay is very tight, reactive and satisfying as you blow chunks out of your enemies with a good supply of firearms, that sniper rifle is a very welcome addition to my arsenal let me tell you. Enemies are varied and keep the player on their toes, ranging from simple tactical grunts who actively take cover to deranged bloodsoaked lunatics going kamikaze with explosives strapped to their chests, and it wouldn't be F.E.A.R. without the giant mech every now and again would it? The mechs are an intense fight making the player jump from aggressive force to defensive turtle in an instant, and like in F.E.A.R. 2 you can pilot them when you find an empty one, my god that part is so fun. But then there's the biggest gripe I've heard about F3. The cover system. Cover systems in a first-person game I find to be always sticky, clumsy and awkward, and this is no exception. A cover system would work better in a third-person over the shoulder viewpoint because the perspective allows it to work to it's full potential as the Mass Effect games show, but in F3 it's just not needed. When we needed cover before in a first-person game we simply pressed the crouch button behind a barrel, and let go of the crouch button to come out. We don't want or need some backend programming making us stick to the cover until we press the button, as it restricts our movement and makes things way more angering than they need to be. Keep cover systems OUT of first-person shooters. Got it? And then my biggest gripe about F3, the regenerating health system. In the previous games you could find and pick up healthkits to use when you needed them, which gave you more control over how the combat flowed while keeping you mindful of your current inventory of health, and that was fine, it was fun and made sense. With F3 however you just wait a moment and your wounds magically heal themselves, it's not fitting in the game and it made certain areas and boss fights way more frustrating (which is why I took my breaks from this game before I punched something). The big boss battles are in an arena with not as much cover so you don't often get a break to let your cuts and bruises fix themselves, you have to be always on the move, most of the time being in the direct line of fire of the boss enemy. With the healthkits system you could drop a few grenades and heavy weapons fire on the tanky enemy, using your healthkits as you do so, that way you can tank more damage which also made inventory management so much more important because popping first-aid like tic-tacs would screw you over in the inevitable boss arenas. With F3 however the arenas follow the same guidelines, leaving you open more often than not, but you can't tank damage. This is a major problem with the game, the boss fights aren't intense and challenging, their infuriating and kill the experience. Even the limited cover you have won't help you because some bosses have smaller allies that flank you and others can walk through the freakin' walls and get right in your face. It's not a fair challenge and I cannot play these boss fights without getting angry at the game, hence why I took these breaks that ultimately forced me through a series of unavoidable events to play it all from the beginning.There is also an in-game levelling and perk system that rates your performance in each level, giving you optional challenges to complete while playing such as "kill x amount of enemies with melee" and whatnot with the reward for levelling up being a buff in either the player's max health, reflex bar (which slows down time while in use, giving more delicious gunplay goodness) and other things. The only problem is that the game selects what to upgrade for you, you have no choice. If you want more health? Too bad, more reflex. It would be so much more engaging if you could choose what to level up, but for some reason you're not allowed to.So with all my mixed feelings about F.E.A.R. 3 I had to ask myself, do I or do I not recommend it? When the game gets something right, it gets it right. But there are equal moments of B.S. that make F.E.A.R. 3 take a massive step backwards from the last game which is by and far my favorite game in the series. So to be completely and utterly honest? No, I cannot in good conscience give F.E.A.R. 3 a positive recommendation. It's flaws are so game-breaking and the direction the developers want to take it is so confused that the whole experience suffers as a result. If you were able to follow and pay attention to the storyline unlike me then you'd probably want to play it for the closure of the series' finale, but otherwise I'd say just play up to F.E.A.R. 2 and leave it at that.

												A great climactic way to round out the series.It doesn't really try to frighten you so much as the first one did, but then again at this point in the series you should be used to what is going on.As the first one touched on the supernatural and the second installment delved further...this third one goes balls deep.Non-stop adrenaline all the way through - two storylines to play through - one for each brother.That's right, play as not only Point Man, but his brother Fettel for the first time ever.Decimate waves of enemies with your psionic abilities and view the alternate ending!Recruit, Commando, Fearless & Insane difficulties to playthrough.9/10 - Thoroughly enjoyed it, I recommend it.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												F.E.A.R 3 is one of those games that takes an old classic game and tries to transform it into a new Battlefield or Call of Duty. I would sum what happens in F.E.A.R 3, but the story is so forgettable that I can't remember what happened in it, and I beat it twice. Apparently the two brothers have to go and stop Alma's baby from being born, but the game throws in a multiple ending that rewards whoever was the "best brother." That means A. you need to beat the story mode twice to get all endings or B. Play the whole 6 HOUR story mode in co op. Gameplay is dumbed down from the last 2 F.E.A.R games. There is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cover system, you can only carry 2 guns, health regenerates, and F.E.A.R's top of the line AI has been reduced to standard FPS AI.The worst part is that the game isn't scary. F.E.A.R 2 wasn't all that scary, but it had great gameplay to make up for it. F.E.A.R 3 has nothing going for it besides a co-op that, once again, doesn't make it scary. I don't know what went through WB's head to get rid of Monolith [Creators of F.E.A.R] and replace them with some unknown studio that never heard of F.E.A.R. If you really love the F.E.A.R games like me, just make up in your head what happens in the story, it would probably be better than what they came up with.Also F.3.A.R... really guys?

												I'm pretty easy to please with FPS's, but this together with Perfect Dark Zero and Red Faction 2, is one of the worst sequels I've ever played. I first tried this on the 360 and then got it for pennies on a Steam sale or something apparently, well I want those pennies back. I am a huge fan of the first two games because of the amazing combat, cool atmosphere, and fantastic level design. This fails on all accounts plus more, even the new engine somehow feels chunkier and like a backstep from FEAR 2. The levels are small, the game just spams you with enemies with no time to take in any atmosphere whatsoever, the story and music is dryer than sand, and this game simply does nothing good. Surely there is another FPS you could be playing instead of this. Gotta love those ninja zombies who throw rapid firing silent knives or something at you.

												Get this game not if you're inexperienced with the F.E.A.R universe for its been more of a let down for fans. The game is hardly horror and more of a Co-op experience on campaign. Get two copies of this for you and your good buddy/partner to play for it does offer a great competitive coop experience. In short, you play as alma's two sons, competiting against each other for stats, and your overall performance impacts the ending as who's the "Favourite Son". So its all sibling rivilary.Multiplayer modes are great! sort of the zombie suriving experience call of duty delivers.Overall, must play if two people are willing to play together. But if you're looking for spooks and real fear, go for F.E.A.R 2

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
												F.E.A.R. 3 is a linear shooter that could be summerized as a bunch of arena like rooms filled with enemies and bound by empty corridors. Scripting is minimal, story is disjuncted, but the environments are well made and interesting to wander through. The game isn't an horror game, but it is spooky in places. The real meat of the experience is combat: great enemy AI, sections with mechas you can control, conventional but efficient weaponry, and most of all a great coop campaign. With the addition of a new playable character that has rather original ways to kill or assist the first player, this coop mode is more than just singleplayer campaign with two players. As both characters complete each other or compete for the highest score, one is more like a grunt shooting in traditional fashion his way through the enemies while the second is more like a tactician able to seize control of an enemy of his choice and thus creating a mess in enemies' ranks, but also able to single enemies out for the first player to kill swiftly. There are other tricks you can use in tandem, but possessing enemies of various kinds never gets old.All in all this coop mode makes an otherwise conventional game extremely worthwhile for coop afficionados. Be advised that the game is rather short though (5-6 hours long).

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												This game is an insult to the original FEAR. The AI has been dumbed down, the guns feel weightless and sound dull, the atmosphere has been gutted to be another action FPS, the HUD is a cluttered mess, a completely pointless XP system has been added, the lighting and effects are not as impressive as they used to be, the list goes on and on. I've seen people say the co-op makes this game bearable, but I found this to be completely untrue. My first playthrough was co-op with my best friend and as my Steam hour count shows, we couldn't make it past the first few hours. What we played was just another mass-manufactured action shooter with none of the attention to detail of the original.The original FEAR was not perfect. However, what in lacked in level design and enemy variety it made up for with superior gunplay, spectacular effects and lighting, and a haunting atmosphere. FEAR 3 has none of that. It's a homogeneous clone of every other popular FPS on the market to appeal to widest common denominator. Such a damn shame.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												If this game was released as its own title, it honestly might have done a lot better. As a fear game it is quite unfaithful.The game itself is actually pretty fun to play, and the multiplayer contractions mode was really cool. Basically you fight waves of illusionary soldiers/creatures, and between waves you can repair barricades and collect weapon caches.The single player is trash, almost entirely due to the fact that it's so unfaithful to the original. From the mood to the guns and atmosphere, it's weird. Like uncannily weird. You spend a lot of time fighting in spaces like suburbs, supermarkets and airports. Where as in FEAR 1 and 2 the game was  more localized around industrial areas and downtown cityscapes, it feels very weird to spend your time fighting in these much less industrial areas.This game is also not scary at all. I really don't remember anything in the game that was legitimately scary in the same vein of the first two games. But to be fair I also feel like the game ended up way past its prime, I think the original theme was already played out to death, the way the story pans out in this last game makes light of the entire supernatural threat from the first two games.So basically, it's call of duty with spooky stuff, except the spooky stuff is on your side. Or something.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
												F.E.A.R 3 is one of those games that takes an old classic game and tries to transform it into a new Battlefield or Call of Duty. I would sum what happens in F.E.A.R 3, but the story is so forgettable that I can't remember what happened in it, and I beat it twice. Apparently the two brothers have to go and stop Alma's baby from being born, but the game throws in a multiple ending that rewards whoever was the "best brother." That means A. you need to beat the story mode twice to get all endings or B. Play the whole 6 HOUR story mode in co op. Gameplay is dumbed down from the last 2 F.E.A.R games. There is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cover system, you can only carry 2 guns, health regenerates, and F.E.A.R's top of the line AI has been reduced to standard FPS AI.The worst part is that the game isn't scary. F.E.A.R 2 wasn't all that scary, but it had great gameplay to make up for it. F.E.A.R 3 has nothing going for it besides a co-op that, once again, doesn't make it scary. I don't know what went through WB's head to get rid of Monolith [Creators of F.E.A.R] and replace them with some unknown studio that never heard of F.E.A.R. If you really love the F.E.A.R games like me, just make up in your head what happens in the story, it would probably be better than what they came up with.Also F.3.A.R... really guys?

												This is problably the most weak game of the trilogy, and for the ones who played FEAR when it was released, its shame that even having better graphics, still doesnt give you the same feeling of the first one, at some point this story lost its direction and right after the first FEAR, the only thing they all have in common is the name, nothing else.There are so many changes that didnt make the game stand out, one of them, problably the most important is the enemy AI, the lack of reaction to player behiavor and interaction with the scenary, made all the realistic feeling go away, their interaction with each other also changed and most of the time they end up talking trash killing the little imersion the game build with players.Another strong point of FEAR, was the ambient around the player with Alma making short but memorable appereance betwen levels that always keep players on their toes and that horror feeling that many games simply cant deliver, specially when we are talking about shooter.Dont take me wrong, was a shooter, FEAR 3 is good shooter, fun and entertaining enough to be recommended and good game to have in your library, but with FEAR label, is just another failed project that couldnt keep up the pace with expectations players had after the sucess of the first one, all the problems around VU Games/Sierra and Monolith maybe killed one of the most important games that redifined shooters completly combining horror with action.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												Day 1 Studios gave the new F.E.A.R. game the refreshing stimulus the franchise has deserved after the second entry. While F.E.A.R. 2 was a solid FPS it was also old with ageing mechanics that couldn't held up against the best in the genre. The latest game became modernish with updated gameplay mechanics. On one hand it was a good decision (it had to be done), on other side it isn't unique enough to separate itself from the competition.F.3.A.R starts off 8 months after the second game. Point Man is our protagonist once again and he has to team up with his long gone brother, Fettel to get out of a prison and find his squad mate, Jin, who is in danger. Paranormal activities are a big part of this game too. Only this time around Alma isn't the antagonist, but something called the Creep. The story of the game won't leave any deep marks in you. It's flat and uninteresting. It's hard to take the story seriously when it doesn't prove its worthiness. Your personal goal will be reaching checkpoints after checkpoints to beat campaign. And it will be done after just around 6 hours. It's a shame really because with a more intriguing story this game could have made a mark.Luckily F.E.A.R. 3 isn't short on content. Not at all. After completing the campaign you can kill your time with various game modes. Many of them are essentially a modified version of the original campaign, but the changes made in those modes are not only worth a try but also great fun. The campaign is made of 8 intervals, each of them takes around 30-45 minutes to complete. After completing an interval you can replay it as Point Man or Fetter with all its unique psychic abilities. He has the ability to posses common enemies. You'll appreciate the change of pace. Also, you can hop in a co-op campaign with your friend. One controls Fettel the other Point Man. It isn't a novelty at all, but great to see the developer putting in the game options like this. When you exploit everything the single player modes can offer there is a multiplayer option in the game. Sadly the multiplayer of the third game was never as popular as the first game's MP. If you want to try this option most likely you have to play with your own friends as very few gamers are left playing F.3.A.R. over the internet.Moving to different territories, the looks of the game are passable. It's isn't a beautiful, nor a bad looking game. To its defense they put more emphasis on minor details, so this time a book on a table will actually look like one instead of a bunch of blurred pixels. The gameplay has been completely refreshed. The previous game in the franchise was getting old and set back by wrong decisions during the development. Not this game though. It feels like a modern shooter where you bullets do matter. When you shoot a soldier in this feet he grabs it or tumbles and the gunfight is much more vivid and powerful. Day 1 made the right decisions to cut the useless features and refresh the remaining ones. It's a great shooter, but beyond that it offers nothing more. Nothing that could differentiate this game from the others. Fear in F.E.A.R. 3 is almost non existent. There are moments here and there when you'll look around suspiciously, but that's about it. The franchise has switched genres over the years. From psychological horror it became a solid action oriented shooter. We can't say it was a bad decision, but we can say that there isn't many horror games in the market while there's a legion of action shooters to choose from; good, bad or worse. It's a pity that in this era a franchise has to get more action oriented to survive, and sometimes even that might not be enough. Again, F.E.A.R. 3 is a great shooter and it definitely benefited from the changes made around it, but the industry and the gamers might not.Rating: 80/100; Replay Value: 3/5; To Beat: 6 hours; Played on: normal.

												Not your daddy's FEAR. It's a step down from FEAR1 and definitely a huge change of pace.
