content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												After giving it multiple goes after reinstalling it, and finally just sticking with it, I just still can't really recommend it for multiple reasons.It is obvious that much of this game was made to simply just try to jump onto the success of more modern shooters like Call of Duty, even though the series originated from much of the opposite. Almost every gun except for the shotgun has Aim Down Sights, no more collecting and using med-kits because your health regenerates, only two weapons max, and instead of leaning left and right you press a button to glue yourself to nearby chest-high-walls.There are so many things wrong with this game not only from the point of an original F.E.A.R. fan, but even when stood on its own.-Annoying and unrealistic Bloody Screen when wounded, accompanied with fast acting health regeneration.Completely slows down gameplay, makes certain areas extremely easy due to being near invincible, and makes some areas extremely hard due to not being able to heal instantaneously via med-kit and having to find a spot not being hitscanned into oblivion.-Kung-fu moves have been chopped out. No punches, just a knife. No bicycle kicks, just one dinky kick. These simple animations made the last games so much more fun, even if the new moves do exactly the same purpose. The aesthetic just isn't the same.-The first 2 or 3 level designs are ripped straight out of Modern Warfare. "Escape the Prison!" "Escape the South American Favela!" Truly takes you out of the F.E.A.R. universe, and it's a shame that they thought opening with such unfitting levels would be a good idea when it only helps make an even worse first impression.-No more finding health and slowmo upgrades throughout the environment. To improve your health and slowmo, you have to rank up with the new score and challenge system. You can still find hidden dolls and certain bodies that give instant extra "score" (XP really), but it's such a strange decision to add a rank and score system into a game that was basically the opposite of an arcade/points based game...-The horror aspect of this game was weaker than ever before, even though it was never my favorite part of the games before these. There are a lot less times where the game tries to jump scare you, and even when they do you don't get caught off gaurd because they try to pull one off in the middle of a warzone.-They gave Point-man a face. A boring, bearded, scowling face. Yet he still never talks... As if it wasn't enough that he couldn't do badass psychic kung-fu anymore.-The enemies are just not intimidating anymore. The AI is still OK, but it just does not seem as good as the AI in the first game. The voices for them don't have the badass radio static that the first game had, and they spend 90% of their time completely behind cover.-The new cover system is ok, but having the ability to lean like we used to is much more handy as it gives the player to make useful cover out of anything, whereas now you can only lean out from very certain few pieces of scenery. Half of your head seems to be poking out of cover most of the time as you can still get torn to shreds, enemies are able to hide in cover better than you.The game overall is OK, but as a F.E.A.R. game, or as an olds-chool shooter, it is just so underwhelming and hard to enjoy. Even if I was a completely blank slate on the series, I would still feel very unfavorably for this game, as it seems to attempt to merge the newer Modern Warfare type shooter with older Doom (3) type shooters, and it just becomes such a clunky mess. There are an annoying amount of out-of-character cutscenes, there are an annoying amount of context actions like going through doors, or turnstiles, or over chest-high-walls...It's just a shame that the series that helped make PC gaming PC Gaming was obviously developed for more of the younger console crowd involved, but only managed to sort of make an experience not very enjoyable for either type of gamer, PC or console. All I can really hope for is for some sort of spiritual successor to F.E.A.R. that incorporates super psychic kung-fu soldiers in a more modern engine and graphics set, because this game just leaves me itching for more of the classics.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												After giving it multiple goes after reinstalling it, and finally just sticking with it, I just still can't really recommend it for multiple reasons.It is obvious that much of this game was made to simply just try to jump onto the success of more modern shooters like Call of Duty, even though the series originated from much of the opposite. Almost every gun except for the shotgun has Aim Down Sights, no more collecting and using med-kits because your health regenerates, only two weapons max, and instead of leaning left and right you press a button to glue yourself to nearby chest-high-walls.There are so many things wrong with this game not only from the point of an original F.E.A.R. fan, but even when stood on its own.-Annoying and unrealistic Bloody Screen when wounded, accompanied with fast acting health regeneration.Completely slows down gameplay, makes certain areas extremely easy due to being near invincible, and makes some areas extremely hard due to not being able to heal instantaneously via med-kit and having to find a spot not being hitscanned into oblivion.-Kung-fu moves have been chopped out. No punches, just a knife. No bicycle kicks, just one dinky kick. These simple animations made the last games so much more fun, even if the new moves do exactly the same purpose. The aesthetic just isn't the same.-The first 2 or 3 level designs are ripped straight out of Modern Warfare. "Escape the Prison!" "Escape the South American Favela!" Truly takes you out of the F.E.A.R. universe, and it's a shame that they thought opening with such unfitting levels would be a good idea when it only helps make an even worse first impression.-No more finding health and slowmo upgrades throughout the environment. To improve your health and slowmo, you have to rank up with the new score and challenge system. You can still find hidden dolls and certain bodies that give instant extra "score" (XP really), but it's such a strange decision to add a rank and score system into a game that was basically the opposite of an arcade/points based game...-The horror aspect of this game was weaker than ever before, even though it was never my favorite part of the games before these. There are a lot less times where the game tries to jump scare you, and even when they do you don't get caught off gaurd because they try to pull one off in the middle of a warzone.-They gave Point-man a face. A boring, bearded, scowling face. Yet he still never talks... As if it wasn't enough that he couldn't do badass psychic kung-fu anymore.-The enemies are just not intimidating anymore. The AI is still OK, but it just does not seem as good as the AI in the first game. The voices for them don't have the badass radio static that the first game had, and they spend 90% of their time completely behind cover.-The new cover system is ok, but having the ability to lean like we used to is much more handy as it gives the player to make useful cover out of anything, whereas now you can only lean out from very certain few pieces of scenery. Half of your head seems to be poking out of cover most of the time as you can still get torn to shreds, enemies are able to hide in cover better than you.The game overall is OK, but as a F.E.A.R. game, or as an olds-chool shooter, it is just so underwhelming and hard to enjoy. Even if I was a completely blank slate on the series, I would still feel very unfavorably for this game, as it seems to attempt to merge the newer Modern Warfare type shooter with older Doom (3) type shooters, and it just becomes such a clunky mess. There are an annoying amount of out-of-character cutscenes, there are an annoying amount of context actions like going through doors, or turnstiles, or over chest-high-walls...It's just a shame that the series that helped make PC gaming PC Gaming was obviously developed for more of the younger console crowd involved, but only managed to sort of make an experience not very enjoyable for either type of gamer, PC or console. All I can really hope for is for some sort of spiritual successor to F.E.A.R. that incorporates super psychic kung-fu soldiers in a more modern engine and graphics set, because this game just leaves me itching for more of the classics.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												F.E.A.R. 3 is a fun and well polished shooter, IF you're looking for a fun casual experience a la Call of Duty, but do NOT mistake it for a sequel to the excellent F.E.A.R.. The gameplay has now become a mix of Parkour and fast paced gunfights, the goal being to make the highest score by replaying the same levels, over and over.Interestingly, the campaign can be played in co-op, but this makes the game a little too easy, so I would recommend to finish the game in solo first. The game also features some very original multiplayer game modes. In F*king Run, up to six players are tasked to escape from an ever advancing fog of death, while the players are being pursued by an increasing number and tougher enemies. This game mode is exceptionally fun and challenging. Contractions is a survival mode tasking the players to barricade themselves from waves of possessed enemies. Unfortunately, nowadays it's impossible to find anybody playing multiplayer games or the cooperative campaign.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												What can I say about F.E.A.R 3? Quite obviously, It's the 3rd game in the F.E.A.R franchise, which, one would expect, would say everything. But in all honesty, it doesn't - in fact, the third installment of the F.E.A.R franchise is much more akin to the generic first person shooter than the trouser-browning horror shooter that the F.E.A.R name is otherwise known for.The gameplay is, to put it in one word, generic. You have guns, they go bang, there are a LOT of enemies to shoot with them, same old. However, the genericness is tempered slightly with a very nice cover system, the slow-mo mechanic which is a mainstay of the F.E.A.R franchise, and the occasional creepy moment, though undoubtedly nothing as trouser-wetting as the previous games in the series, which I have admittedly not actually played a lot of. There is also some geo-mod, but this is needless and hinders more than it helps. However, the game is still relatively fun despite the genericness and shortcomings.The story is confusing. Whilst playing through the game I had little idea of what was actually going on, but from what I could gather, Alma, the creepy little F.E.A.R mainstay, has become pregnant for whatever reason, and the main character, the "Point Man" and his brother Paxton Fettel, who was killed in F.E.A.R 1 and who has somehow returned, have to find her and... well, Fettel wants to eat the child and Point Man wants to destroy it. That's as much as I could gather.The game takes about 6 to 7 hours to beat, though this is somewhat artificially extended by the game's difficulty. I was playing on "Commando" (Normal) difficulty, and some areas of the game were heavily confusing and others were incredibly difficult, particularly one section where I had to defeat a massive mech which could kill me in a few shots and tear any cover you might choose to use to pieces, and also another where I was attacked by TWO of the most annoying enemy in the game, which needless to say was frustrating.To summarise, F.E.A.R 3 is generic, difficult, short, confusing and has stupidly large numbers of incredibly annoying enemies. I'd reccommend this game only if you're a fan of first-person shooters in general and like a challenge, in which case you may find it quite fun (Though you may find yourself not wanting anyone to mention phase casters to you ever again), otherwise save your cash and buy another good FPS, or better, one of the prior F.E.A.R games.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												This game is an insult to the original FEAR. The AI has been dumbed down, the guns feel weightless and sound dull, the atmosphere has been gutted to be another action FPS, the HUD is a cluttered mess, a completely pointless XP system has been added, the lighting and effects are not as impressive as they used to be, the list goes on and on. I've seen people say the co-op makes this game bearable, but I found this to be completely untrue. My first playthrough was co-op with my best friend and as my Steam hour count shows, we couldn't make it past the first few hours. What we played was just another mass-manufactured action shooter with none of the attention to detail of the original.The original FEAR was not perfect. However, what in lacked in level design and enemy variety it made up for with superior gunplay, spectacular effects and lighting, and a haunting atmosphere. FEAR 3 has none of that. It's a homogeneous clone of every other popular FPS on the market to appeal to widest common denominator. Such a damn shame.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												If this game was released as its own title, it honestly might have done a lot better. As a fear game it is quite unfaithful.The game itself is actually pretty fun to play, and the multiplayer contractions mode was really cool. Basically you fight waves of illusionary soldiers/creatures, and between waves you can repair barricades and collect weapon caches.The single player is trash, almost entirely due to the fact that it's so unfaithful to the original. From the mood to the guns and atmosphere, it's weird. Like uncannily weird. You spend a lot of time fighting in spaces like suburbs, supermarkets and airports. Where as in FEAR 1 and 2 the game was  more localized around industrial areas and downtown cityscapes, it feels very weird to spend your time fighting in these much less industrial areas.This game is also not scary at all. I really don't remember anything in the game that was legitimately scary in the same vein of the first two games. But to be fair I also feel like the game ended up way past its prime, I think the original theme was already played out to death, the way the story pans out in this last game makes light of the entire supernatural threat from the first two games.So basically, it's call of duty with spooky stuff, except the spooky stuff is on your side. Or something.

												I'm pretty easy to please with FPS's, but this together with Perfect Dark Zero and Red Faction 2, is one of the worst sequels I've ever played. I first tried this on the 360 and then got it for pennies on a Steam sale or something apparently, well I want those pennies back. I am a huge fan of the first two games because of the amazing combat, cool atmosphere, and fantastic level design. This fails on all accounts plus more, even the new engine somehow feels chunkier and like a backstep from FEAR 2. The levels are small, the game just spams you with enemies with no time to take in any atmosphere whatsoever, the story and music is dryer than sand, and this game simply does nothing good. Surely there is another FPS you could be playing instead of this. Gotta love those ninja zombies who throw rapid firing silent knives or something at you.

												Get this game not if you're inexperienced with the F.E.A.R universe for its been more of a let down for fans. The game is hardly horror and more of a Co-op experience on campaign. Get two copies of this for you and your good buddy/partner to play for it does offer a great competitive coop experience. In short, you play as alma's two sons, competiting against each other for stats, and your overall performance impacts the ending as who's the "Favourite Son". So its all sibling rivilary.Multiplayer modes are great! sort of the zombie suriving experience call of duty delivers.Overall, must play if two people are willing to play together. But if you're looking for spooks and real fear, go for F.E.A.R 2

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
												F.E.A.R. 3 is a linear shooter that could be summerized as a bunch of arena like rooms filled with enemies and bound by empty corridors. Scripting is minimal, story is disjuncted, but the environments are well made and interesting to wander through. The game isn't an horror game, but it is spooky in places. The real meat of the experience is combat: great enemy AI, sections with mechas you can control, conventional but efficient weaponry, and most of all a great coop campaign. With the addition of a new playable character that has rather original ways to kill or assist the first player, this coop mode is more than just singleplayer campaign with two players. As both characters complete each other or compete for the highest score, one is more like a grunt shooting in traditional fashion his way through the enemies while the second is more like a tactician able to seize control of an enemy of his choice and thus creating a mess in enemies' ranks, but also able to single enemies out for the first player to kill swiftly. There are other tricks you can use in tandem, but possessing enemies of various kinds never gets old.All in all this coop mode makes an otherwise conventional game extremely worthwhile for coop afficionados. Be advised that the game is rather short though (5-6 hours long).

												Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!This is a first person shooter game.Interface/Menu/SettingsThere is a sound volume slidebar available.There is a music voluem slidebar available.There is an environmental volume slidebar available.There is a narrative volume slidebar available.There is a voice volume slidebar available.You can play this game with a xbox controller.Controller has rumble function.There is a sensitivity slidebar.You can play the game fullscreen or windowed mode.You are only able to change the screen resolution size in fullscreen.There are some different resolution sizes available.You are able to toggle the subtitles.There is a difficulty level settings available.You can toggle the violence language and blood level.Has a dead multiplayerAbout the game.You start off in a solitary prison cell and you will escape from it. You will kill enemy soldiers and make your move, like in the previous versions you have the ability to slow down time, also known as "Bullet time". This will give you enough time to finish off enemies or dealing with other situations. Your gun crosshair will turn into a different color once you are aiming on an enemy. When taking damage your screen will become red. Your health will get restored overtime which means you will have to find cover and don't take any damage so that you will heal up..You can't travel back to previous areas and sometimes it is really difficult to know if you are about to move to a new area or if this is a dead end.  There are challenges and weapon Challenges. You are able to skip cutscenes. Alot of collectables. Has bullet time. Has options ingame. Okay graphics. Crosshair will turn into a different color when targeting an enemy. No health kits but health recovers overtime.Has bullet time.Has options ingame.Okay graphics.Crosshair will turn into a different color when targeting an enemy.No health kits but health recovers overtime.Other things.If you are buying this game for "Horror" Then i am afraid you are at the wrong game.The game isn't that scary to be honest. i think the older versions were alot more scarier.-------------------I Give this game a 7/10

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2015
												Rating 7/10Overview: FPS with the ability to go into slow-mo The Good+ The game features 2 main characters you can play as. You first have to complete the game as 'point man'. This character allows you to slow down time while you blast away your enemies. The other character is Paxton Fettel who has the ability to possess almost any enemy in the game. + A cover based system in a first person shooter never seems to work out, yet this game handles the feature nicely. With a single press of a button  you can hide behind cover and easily pop out and shoot your enemies. + By completing challenges you acquire experience which is then used to level up your character. Challenges include killing a certain amount of enemies with a weapon, getting headshots, staying in slow-mo for a certain amount of time etc. It's a nice addition and it helps you change up your play style so you're not constantly relying on the same tricks over and over again. + I feel the AI has improved (yet still lacking to the first FEAR), enemies flank, hide, take cover and feel like a genuine threat when facing them. +Variety of different weapons and grenades+The shooting mechanics feel good, going into slow-mo and shooting enemies is always fun. The game also introduces sections where you ride a mech to change up the gameplay.The Average:On a technical level the graphics are decent. Textures are solid, lighting and shadows look decent however artistically the game feels bland and uninspired. Poor color usage and levels that feel and look the same despite being in different environments doesn't help either. The story is decent but it really is starting to feel convoluted at this point. Game will provide around 5-7 hours for one playthrough. Multiplayer and playing through the campaign as the second character can extend playtime for a bit. The game features some multiplayer modes that can be played in single player and extend your game time. The problem is that multiplayer is dead which is sad given that some of these modes looks really fun to play.The Bad- multiplayer is dead which also means getting certain achievements is now impossible- no local co-opConclusionThe more FEAR games we get the farther we move away from what made the original so great. This game lacks even less horror elements and tactical shooting from the previous entries and is essentially a straight up first person shooter with the slow-mo ability. I don't consider this a bad game but compared to the last 2 entries it feels like it took 2 steps back and 1 step forward.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												Did you like FEAR? Did you even suffer through FEAR 2? Well, that's what you get for it. I present to you FEAR 3, the worst entry in the franchise.The good:- Gunplay is surprisingly solid compared to FEAR 2. More like the first game.- No almost endlessly respawning enemies like in F2- Sprint button- Grenades are again simply thrown and not selected. Thank you- Graphics are kinda neat- Fettel is still a badass. Kinda.And that's about it...not a lot to see hereThe bad:- Gameplay is so generic it hurts.- COVER system in an FPS...- Regenerating health- Silly "level up" system- Boring weapons- Bugs- Glitches- Even on easy annoyingly unfair at times- Story is quasi non-existant- No manual saves- Long checkpoints- You still do not talk...everyone else does...- I wonder what "we" did during FEAR 2...disjointed narration- Short, oh sooo so short, and still glad it's almost over.- Is this supposed to be scary?So, well, yeah, while the basic shooting mechanics are solid. Everything else just kinda falls flat on its face. The story makes little sense and is just boring. The scary or unsettling moments are almost completely gone. You have to run from checkpoint to checkpoint. Firefights are often protracted sequences with aiming out of cover. You die really fast in this game, but hey, regenerating health...yay.There's also an "achievement" system in the game through which you "level up". For example getting a sprint melee attack, more health, more slo mo time, etc. It's completely shallow and weird though. Not to mention you restart most achievements with every new instance. There are also some glitches and game breaking bugs, which require you to restart a checkpoint (for example, an enemy somehow dropped out of the world and was thus invincible, thereby not triggering the next set of enemies that let you advance through the level). Did I mention that this game is SHORT!? I played FEAR 1 for about 8 hours (12 with DLC), Fear 2 for about 6 or 7 hours as well, but this one? No more than 4 hours spread over 8 intervals. The different settings are also not very interesting from an artistic view point. *sigh* Just play FEAR 1 instead. It's better in every regard, except graphically.Edit: Also terrible FOV and motion blur which cannot be changed, unless you dig through Google to find out you need to edit the settings file in a certain way. That is just ridiculous. The game literally made me sick playing it without this "fix".

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
												By far the weakest entry in the F.E.A.R. series, next to the Perseus Mandate expansion. This game waters down F.E.A.R. 2 even further with regenerating health, a higher reliance on action sequences and shootouts, forgettable music, awful pre-rendered cutscenes, a decreased quality in visuals, and scares that fail to impress. The story itself returns to the series' main protagonist, but the game fumbles with its momentum, switching between action and horror sequences too quickly. The game can hardly don the style "psychological horror" as most of the scary elements are tangible, such as crazed humans or otherworldly monsters.There are no terrorizing setpieces like in the previous two games. Even F.E.A.R. 3's scariest moments are nothing compared to sequences like the school basement or the failed commander experiments from the previous game. It borrows too many elements from the typical "bro shooter", in order to strengthen the co-op. Because you know, nothing's scarier than having a buddy right next to you while you're afraid. I can only imagine the co-op was a corporate decision, and it was a bad decision. The story is interesting enough, and I enjoyed looking into the brothers' past, but Point Man isn't at all likeable and Fettel is a smug ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who has no reason to be helping his brother.F.E.A.R. 3 fell victim to trends. It's got a few scares here and there, but the regenerating health takes an enormous amount of edge off of the game, the cover mechanic is flimsy, the enemies are downright ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, and the co-op is incredibly shoehorned. This is not how you make a horror game. This is how you make a sub-par bro-shooter.

number of helpful: 21 of 42 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												This game was incredibly disappointing. The push towards console gaming is made even more apparant with the 3rd iteration in the FEAR franchise, a game that completely abandons everything that made the original such a classic. The gameplay has been oversimplified and while it's cliche to say it's like a "COD" game now, it quite literally is. I'm not exactly sure why this game is even called "FEAR" because this game was less scary than Octodad. The story is completely idiotic it could easily be compared to something like Sharknado. And the graphics have suffered a significant amount, looking worse than the original game that came out almost a decade before it. Let's talk about the gameplay in more detail though...First off, the game is much more fast paced. You're given the ability to sprint, slide, vault, and worst of all, "take cover." This game mechanic is so incredibly annoying. Basically if you are near any vertical surface and decide you want to crouch, the game will automatically snap you to cover. This will lock you into position until you hit the crouch button again, meaning you have to stand up in the middle of a firefight just to relocate your position. The game also offers a new and completely unnecessary "ranking" system that constantly gives you these big cheesy notifications whenever you kill a certain amount of enemies in a row with headshots or something. This franchise is about walking around in dark hallways, shooting enemies in slow motion, and being scared silly by some creepy girl in the shadows. FEAR 3 seems to have forgotten all of that. Every level in the game seems to take place in broad daylight, and even when you do go inside a dark building, the ambient lighting is so bright you can see the terrible textures in every dark corner. Now don't get me wrong, the gunplay is more fun than it has ever been, but because of this focus on improving combat, the game's identity has been completely lost. Even the few times that you do see the creepy girl "Alma," it's almost comical... like seeing her riding on the opposite escalator, looking confused as to why she no longer was scaring me. Another major downside to the game is the most immediate thing you'll probably notice, "health regen." That's right, they finally did away with the classic refreshing "health-kits" that make games so much more intense and opted for the "COD" approach where you can inhale bullets, take cover for half a second, and then jump out from cover good as new. This along with the near endless supply of ammo for every gun has taken away any type of suspense left in this game. I was able to cruise through this game without any real problems at all in less than half the time it took me to beat the original FEAR. So while the game is fast-paced and fun shooter by itself, FEAR fans will want to avoid this entirely due to the complete lack of horror. Now let's talk about the story. It sucks. It's just so painfully bad. Basically it starts off with the stupid ending from FEAR 2 where ALMA somehow rapes a guy (yes... according to the FEAR developers, a woman can now♥♥♥♥♥♥a man) and is now pregnant and going into labor. In FEAR 3, you take on the role of the original character, who I guess is named "Point-Man" and are tasked with trying to stop ALMA from having this evil baby. Your brother that you shot in the head in the first game is somehow, without explanation, back... and is now constantly on your shoulder the entire game, spoiling all of the mystery and suspense behind everything that happens. "Uh oh.. sounds like ALMA is here, she's probably going to jump out at you brother!" your brother will say as you walk into a new area. In addition to his terrible voice acting, your forced to listen to these frustrating loud screams that are supposed to be ALMA going into labor, but just sound like poorly done fake ♥♥♥♥♥♥ sounds and they sound absolutely ridiculous. Thankfully this train-wreck of a story ends quickly, with some completley random and unexplained player rank-based ending that I guess is affected by how well you played throughout the game? You're never given any warning about this so it was really confusing once I reached the end. If you're a fan of FEAR's storyline, I suggest you avoid this... avoid this like the plague. You're better off watching Alien 4 or something...Graphics are another pretty big deal when it comes to FEAR games. The original FEAR was one of the best looking games available in its time with revolutionary physics, shadows, and fantastic lighting. FEAR 3 is quite the opposite. I'm surprised games post-2010 can even look this bad. The lighting is all static, with hardly any dynamic nature at all to the environment in any sense (meaning no more cool slow motion physics based destruction). The gore is laughable, with enemies just exploding into tiny blood shaded explosions when you shoot them with a shotgun, and even on the highest possible settings, the texture resolutions were just painful to look at. The FEAR franchise has certainly fallen from grace in the graphics department. It's frustrating seeing a franchise die so quickly with obvious shifts towards a more action oriented, COD friendly consumer base, and the FEAR franchise is a perfect example of this. What once was a hardcore, scary, action shooter with no health-regen and some impressive visuals has now turned into a Call of Duty game with a different franchise's logo pasted onto the cover. FEAR 3's gameplay is fun, fast paced, and hectic, but this just wasn't a necessary change. The game's horror has been completely abandoned and the storyline feels like an afterthought. This along with the games lazy graphic design are all reasons I just simply can't recommend buying this game. Maybe if the entire franchise is on sale it's worth it for a short afternoon killing spree, but I wouldn't expect much that's for sure.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												One of the best co-op experiences, endings and credits song ever! Atmospheric horror shooting with two characters from which to choose – each for different playing style. Good graphics and tactical advancement. Also, F.E.A.R.3 has one of the most reasonable achievement system on Steam. The balanced, fast-paced gameplay and intriguing story will keep you going from the beginning until the end for the first walktrough, which takes only about 6-7 hours. But it's not a problem. After the first time, you can take the other character or try multiplayer. Still feels great.The multiplayer is ok, but nothing exciting.Despite some managable technical problems, it's one of my favourite games.Overall rating: 10/10.NB!There are few technical tweaks you should know, before you play this game.1. First, rename ClientRegistry.blob file to ClientRegistryOld.blob (Steam folder). This might save you from kicking out, when there are too many players on server (happens around sales time).2. Manually adjust the FOV, by opening the options.cfg file (game folder) and deleting the # tag and changing value to 85. This will save you from dizziness.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
												As far as horror goes, Fear 3 is probably the least scary and most tedious game I've ever played. Everything is so heavily scripted I'm never sure if I missed a visual cue for a "scary bit" or if I was supposed to only see the tail end of something disappearing and it was meant to be like that. In either case it's never scary and doesn't even accomplish the supremely low standard of getting a few jump scares.On the fps side of things it's all pretty standard and bland for a cover based shooter. The highlight is probably the AI soldiers being above average intelligence compared to the rest of the field but that doesn't really help as much as you'd hope when there are so few enemy types in such small areas. The gunplay has it's moments and some of the weapons you get very late on are kind of fun but that delay is two thirds of the game gone. I'd have liked to have more of that variety earlier on.And finally I feel I need to mention that I'm not even going to mention the story. It's just too stupid to actually discuss. The only thing of note is that the FEAR franchise is completely mislabeled as a horror series when really, if you pay any attention to the story, it's actually a tragedy from start to finish.It might seem strange that I'm recommending it after saying all that but it's more of a case of not saying anyone should avoid it and Steam not having a neutral option. The whole thing is just a weird experience of a blah fps with a stupid as hell story and the most tragic of figures in Alma.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												This game wasn't actually made by Monolith; it was developed by Day One Studios, the studio that was previously only responsible for making the console ports of FEAR 1 and its expansions. It shows, in a lot of ways. The levels are much more linear, you're limited to two weapons, and the graphics are arguably worse than FEAR 2's and maybe even FEAR 1's. The story is barely coherent at best (which isn't helped by the fact that despite FEAR 3 having actual cutscenes, Pointman is still a silent protagonist who only communicates through furiously scrunching his eyebrows), and you don't even get a clear goal or an idea of where you're actually going until around halfway through the game's 4 hour campaign. The only aspect of the game that's anything interesting is the co-op system, in which the two players are cooperating but still loosely competing against each other to decide which ending they get, which works a lot better than it does in games that somehow manage to be even worse than this one like Call of Juarez: The Cartel. And that's a good thing, because the only way I can recommend even considering playing this game is if you have a friend to play it with, though even then it's only a loose recommendation since this game is really only that fun under the "any game is fun with a friend" rule. This game barely has enough content to be a hard sell if it were priced at $10 or $15 like the first two games are, but at $20 it's absolutely not worth picking up unless you just really want to suffer through an evening with a friend and have expended all other available options.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												Eh, fundamentally, it works well. But really, who cares? Getting the basics right isn't exactly a hard thing to do if you've got a triple A publisher backing you. I could say alot of things about this game in particular. But what makes F3AR a particularly sour note, is that it forced me to re-examine the FPS genre of that time(COD and Halo being exempt)So, picture this. You enter a room. There are 4 enemy soldiers in that room. Thanks to FEAR's slo-mo mechanic, you drop them with relative ease. One guy suddenly comes down a ladder, and two more from a door to the left. Down they go. Just as the last guy falls, 3 more soldiers burst through a window. Once they drop, finally, a heavy breaks down far door, flanked by 3 more soldiers. After a brief 'boss; battle, all enemies are down, and you may proceed to the next area. But, did you notice something? At no point in that encounter, were you ever fighing any more than 4 enemies at a single time. This was hidden from you through cleverly placed spawns to give you the feeling of fighting off a sizable force. But you wouldn't know it by the end, because bodies aren't persistant beyond 4 either. Almost every FPS game made around that period of time stuck to this 'rule of 4'. And on top of that, most of them had a slo-mo, or something similar to make getting kills easy. The moment you realise this, the hardest difficulties stop becoming hard once you're aware that you'll never fight any more than 4 grunts at a time. I'm not downvoting this due to F3AR being a bad game. Because it's not. I'm downvoting because this was the game that made me realise how bland the genre of FPS was back then.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2013
												I have a lot of gripes with where Day 1 Studios went with the story and tone, but the gameplay of F.E.A.R. 3 is as fun as the series has ever been. F.E.A.R. 1 and 2 are much more well-rounded and sensibly designed, but F.E.A.R. 3 does have co-op. Yes, it does have co-op. Designing the campaign with co-op in mind is probably the main culprit for why F.E.A.R. 3's story/campaign isn't quite as great as the other two's. It ends weird and kind of anti-climactically too. But, it does have co-op.The combat is just about as deliciously good as the other games in the series though, so despite its odd disappointments in terms of how it concluded the series, it should still be a fun romp for anyone who liked the other F.E.A.R. games. It's mostly the same in that regard, although with rank challenges (a sort of points system) and noticeably less scary. Playing as Paxton Fettel is also a cool spin on things that adds replayability. And the rank challenges (which is in all modes) add an extra layer of fun.Also, Alma's just ugly in this one... :(

On the other hand multiplayer seems to have a lot of potential.So if you enjoyed first two FEAR games and you want to play this alone and have a good experience, i don't recommend it. But if you want to have fun with your friend in coop and multiplayer, this is definitely a game you should try.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												This is a bad shooter that barely belongs in the F.E.A.R. storyline. The second game was tolerable and even good at points but this one makes you wonder why you're not just doing anything else instead. The second mission felt like a bad rip-off of the favela fights in a much better FPS game, and the constant pop-ups for minor achievements are incredibly irritating. For what should theoretically be a relatively slow-paced shooter with bouts of action this one misses the mark completely, and it even throws in regenerating health to hammer the point home. It's like the difference between the Pripyat levels in STALKER and in Modern Warfare - despite having similar themes the feel of them is completely different. This feels barely like the second game and nothing at all like the original. After the favela mission I looked at the "Challenge board" and the "target time" of the mission and decided that it wasn't worth continuing. If I hadn't gotten the game as part of a cheap bundle I wouldn't have even bothered getting that far. I feel sorry for anyone who paid full price for this.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												I've played FEAR 1 & 2, lots of other horror games and here's what I have to say about FEAR 3....a letdown!  In a nutshell FEAR 3 feels like Call of Duty with a ghost that appears every so often.  FEAR 1 & 2 had major moments of scares and making you feel like you were always haunted.  FEAR 3 is just bad guys, bad guys and more bad guys...then Alma shows up and is gone.  I acknowledge that FEAR 3 is a shooter game but I think it concentrates too much on shooting and not the horror.  Furthermore, I'm upset that you can shoot an enemy in the face a couple of times then he gets back up and shoots and granades you a dozen times.  The AI is a bit too smart as well.  Before you round the corner they're already shooting at you!  Forget ducking for cover because they seem to have an unlimited supply of granades.  By the time I reached a "ghost moment" I was so frustrated that I was basically like, whatever Alma just get outta my way go haunt someone who cares!  The creepy moments are very brief and and they're ok but far from great.  If you like horror games stay away from this, it'll be a letdown.Pros:+Controls (after changing them from default)+Ablility to use cover during a firefight+WeaponsCons:-Graphics (worse than FEAR 2 for some reason)-Enemies keep spawning in some places-Enemies hard to kill even at point blank-No real scary moments, not a true horror game-For a shooter/horror game it's boring.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
F.E.A.R. 3 is a fantastic game trapped inside a series which developed most of its inertia from great gameplay. The game takes on a new form, almost entirely, giving the player much more room and ability with weapons, reflexes and cover shooting; the game is promiscuous about enemy design and strategy, giving a lot of the momentum of the fights away to who has the bigger gun--a lot like Halo 3, however in Halo 3, Brutes attack you without necessary consent from superiors, in F.E.A.R.3, some enemies won't be as aggressive if you are faced with a mech, or a soldier with greater weaponry. The A.I. in this game pales very clearly in comparison to the original. Most enemies run right at you, knowing you have an advantage in accuracy and dexterity. The game tries to compensate for this by throwing more enemies at you, in bigger and burlier fashion, though, your reflex mode (now almost Godmode), gives you complete superiority in nearly every situation the game offers. This game wraps up the Armacham story and hastily. Something about Paxton Fettel living on in your psyche, due to Alma's pervasive ability and extrasennsory ability, allowing you direct psychic link with Fettel and some dead clone soldiers. Knowing that, it seems like a very indirect way to tie up a story about encountering a hellish creature, given that Fettel was the primary antagonist of the original game up until the end, and Harlan Wade was your antithesis, it would have made more sense to undermine the future of Alma, and give her a much desired explication, of her past, who she possessed and how she survived so long, giving necessary closure to a series that basically, revolved around her.The game is gorgeous, parallel to games like Left for Dead 2, and Tribes Ascend. There's a great attention to detail and even better presentation, if you're up for that sort of thing but this game is no Metro 2033.As a sequel, this game falls flat on its face. As a game, it's amazing and should be played by anyone who enjoys Call of Duty, Serious Sam or any FPS that's mildly hectic. A must play for F.E.A.R. fans, to figure out what exactly makes the original games so good.

Posted: July 3, 2014
F.E.A.R. 3 is a fantastic game trapped inside a series which developed most of its inertia from great gameplay. The game takes on a new form, almost entirely, giving the player much more room and ability with weapons, reflexes and cover shooting; the game is promiscuous about enemy design and strategy, giving a lot of the momentum of the fights away to who has the bigger gun--a lot like Halo 3, however in Halo 3, Brutes attack you without necessary consent from superiors, in F.E.A.R.3, some enemies won't be as aggressive if you are faced with a mech, or a soldier with greater weaponry. The A.I. in this game pales very clearly in comparison to the original. Most enemies run right at you, knowing you have an advantage in accuracy and dexterity. The game tries to compensate for this by throwing more enemies at you, in bigger and burlier fashion, though, your reflex mode (now almost Godmode), gives you complete superiority in nearly every situation the game offers. This game wraps up the Armacham story and hastily. Something about Paxton Fettel living on in your psyche, due to Alma's pervasive ability and extrasennsory ability, allowing you direct psychic link with Fettel and some dead clone soldiers. Knowing that, it seems like a very indirect way to tie up a story about encountering a hellish creature, given that Fettel was the primary antagonist of the original game up until the end, and Harlan Wade was your antithesis, it would have made more sense to undermine the future of Alma, and give her a much desired explication, of her past, who she possessed and how she survived so long, giving necessary closure to a series that basically, revolved around her.The game is gorgeous, parallel to games like Left for Dead 2, and Tribes Ascend. There's a great attention to detail and even better presentation, if you're up for that sort of thing but this game is no Metro 2033.As a sequel, this game falls flat on its face. As a game, it's amazing and should be played by anyone who enjoys Call of Duty, Serious Sam or any FPS that's mildly hectic. A must play for F.E.A.R. fans, to figure out what exactly makes the original games so good.

Same thing. 4. 2 weapons?? Really! What the cr@p is that about? And a max of 175 rounds for a machinegun? This game is total trash and not worth even the $10 I paid for it. content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												I am not going to compare to the original F.E.A.R. If i were to do that, this game should not be recommended at all.The first game was a fps horror that was not good at horror. I give it props for trying but there is nothing scary about soldiers and enemies that require a bullet sweep to clear. If i were to not compare the first game:This game is a solid shooter with tight shooter mechanics. I enjoy the gunplay as it was tight and gave me little problems while the cover system was easy to use and wont make me stick to surfaces like glue. The levels however don't appear to have been balance for single player. Multiple robot encounters on hard wipe my face on the floor a painful amount of times till I found a way to defeat it.The last mission was the hardest; there is a need for reflexes to use your reflexes to survive. Overall hard game but enjoyable.If i were to compare it to the first game:Completely horrible. The game does not follow the gameplay of the first game ever. It is suppose to be a direct sequel so the gameplay should have been improved or left the same. What started out as a first person shooter horror with survival elements is now a first person shooter that I will praise as being more complex than call of duty and nothing more. The horror level to me went from "Horror house roller coaster" to "generic shooter number 117". Try and get this game dirt cheap if u wan your money's worth. I gurantee u will enjoy the 8 hr game but forget it as soon as you start playing a true fps horror game like bioshock.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												the only good thing about this game is the weapon aesthetics, and maybe for the fact it ties up a few lose ends and gives an ending to the series. sadly, this had to be the end of the series. everything in this atrocity is♥♥♥♥♥♥by♥♥♥♥♥♥standards. anything you loved about the original F.E.A.R. games, forget it, it isnt in this game. there is not a single scary or even remotely tense moment in this game, just look at the screenshots above. that is about as good as it gets with scare and atmosphere. the AI is as bland and mediocre as they get, even the Replica forces (who are now somehow allied with ATC???) are easily dispatched and only challenging by the fact they carry weapons that do a good bit of damage, and take a little bit more to kill. all of the genius, god-tier AI from the original game is nonexistent, even F.E.A.R. 2 had better AI. Paxton's voice, though done by the same actor, is somehow just terrible to listen to in this game, but that may just be me, it sounds like he is trying way too hard to sound bad and it ruins everything. no immersion whatsoever, no health bar, just that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ regenerating health system which only makes this game EVEN MORE like CoD. thats what this game is. its a very bloody CoD clone.playing as Paxton is actually quite dumb and doesnt make any sense at all. how can he die if he is already dead? hes a ghost and still takes damage and can be killed, and all he does is tickle enemies with a stupid little red ball for "range" or he can possess enemies for a brief time. not worth it.another crime this game does is it completely ignores the canon that was previously set by the first F.E.A.R. expansions, Extraction Point and Perseus Mandate, meaning that the entirety of the events in those games never happened.just dont buy this game unless you actually want to see just how bad it is. youtube the cutscenes or something and be happy with that.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Every FEAR game has been a step backward from the one before it. FEAR 3 brings some coop to the table through 2-sided mission design (play as Point Man or unlock/visit-another's-game as the ghostly Fettle) at the cost of extremely linear environments and dumb enemies. Any pretext of horror is gone, replaced by a mix of interesting "scary" environments and corridor-shooting. The game itself is WAY TOO SHORT (6 hrs).However, I still recommend FEAR 3 for two reasons: it finishes the "story" of the series and features first-person cover mechanics. I can't think of any other shooter that offers first-person cover on PC, and it's an interesting if limiting design choice. The shooting is also decent, although the gun models are too big (I usually don't care about that sort of thing).If you want to see the end of this sadly reduced series, just get the game.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2012
												Why am I reviewing this with only 3 hours of gameplay in (at this time)? Because I pirated it, and I bought this on sale for eight bucks which is roughly what I'd say this was worth. The graphics are pretty dated, the physics are very buggy, and the enviorments are insanly linear. Most of the fear is gone with only a few sections in the very beginning which were filled with pop out scares. The leveling system is dumb and god help me it feels like I have tunnel vision. This game makes you feel like you have a fov of 30. Fettel (the unlockable character) is basically a silly rehash of the main character with little added that's worthwhile. The story is cliche, dull, and feels irrelevant to the rest of the game. Who are these people? Why is she helping me? I only see them once the entire game? I will say, the action in the game is pretty decent and the game can be fun at times, but overall this game is a consolized let down. 6/10.

												Nowhere, I mean nowhere near as scary as FEAR2 (akin to FEAR2 being nowhere near as scary as FEAR1), but probably the most solid of the series in terms of gameplay.  The guns have impact, the maps are well-designed, non-linear and lengthy, and the core mechanics work as a tactical shooter. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												Unlike seemingly every other reviewer, I actually much preferred this game to FEAR2 (it's been so long since I played the first FEAR I can't compare them).  If you forget about the horror element, what you have here is an extremely accomplished shooter - cover system is great, slo-mo works well, enemy AI is good.  The horror elements are basically limited to lots of melee-type characters that try and swarm you.  Although the warehouse/shop level did doa  pretty good job of buidling suspense before the actual bad guys turned up.There is a bit of replay value to be had here as well, you can replay the game as the murderous ghost once you've completed a level as point-man.  I did a couple of levels with Fettel before I decided that while being novel, that character didn't add enough for me to replay the same story with a different set of abilities - those with more time on their hands may well feel differently.Summary: forget the FEAR back story and enjoy a polished shooter.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
												Buy it! Play it! Don't regret it! :)This 3rd and final installment of the series completes everything... and more!Sooooo not only can you play this game by yourself... you can do it co-op with a friend if you would like! The gore is phenomenal, the fear factor is back, the entire atmosphere created for this game was remarkable, and added features like being able to toggle slow motion were very nice additions, Being able to play as fettel or even being able to have him as your co-op partner to get further insight to his character was a very well thoughout feature that they did perfectly. The storyline all comes together and was brilliantly written! The upgraded graphics, physics, and weapons made this game the modern F.E.A.R that no one was expecting to be realeased (after that F.E.A.R 2 release haha). Finally... adding achievements and competition between you and your friends made this game able to live on longer than simply the single player storyline. All around awesome game!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												Went in expecting abject♥♥♥♥♥♥ just based on the Metacritic reviews. First and second one were good, I figured the third couldn't be that bad, and I was right. This is a middling quality modern shooter. You still get the slow-mo mechanics from the first two games, which is always fun, and a variety of weapons strewn about for you to mess around with. The AI is some of the most aggressive I've seen in an FPS in the past few years, and it will really punish you if you try to hide and take potshots. Enemy soldiers will flank and converge on your position, and regularly toss grenades to scare you out. Even with the slow-mo it was a moderate challenge. The reasons this game scored so poorly I think, were that it's not really a F.E.A.R. game, and it's short. It's about a 6 hour playthrough in full, double that if you play through again as Paxton Fettel, but most people probably won't bother. As for not being a F.E.A.R. game, it comes down to the fact that the game is not scary or even atmospheric. It's not even creepy. Sometimes it'll do the standard "Alma shows up in little girl form to spook you" but she's just there and disappears when you get close. It's like it was a line item on a checklist of things they needed in order to slap the F.E.A.R. brand on it, and has no care put into how it is done. Excepting the actual gameplay (which is definitely passable), it's easy to see why this was basically the end of the series. It feels like a Modern Warfare clone instead of what the rest of the series was. I can't imagine it was anything but reviled by fans of the series up to this point, even if the shooting was still competent. It still gets a "Yes" from me because it regularly comes bundled with the other two games, which are certainly worth playing, and overall it's cheap. Being short means it doesn't overstay its welcome. So to anyone wondering if they should get a combo of all three games, or just the first one, pull the trigger on the bundle. They're all worth playing.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2016
												Pros:You play as Point manYou get to see his face.You get to play as Faxton Pettel.Faxton and Pointman team up.The cutscenes are really cool.Melee has a knife now.That asian chick makes a return.I don't understand why people say it has a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ storyline, it's actually pretty good.Like F.E.A.R. 1 & 2. it is missed jumpscare simulator. EVERY ♥♥♥♥ING JUMPSCARE I'M LOOKING AWAY BECAUSE THERE IS SOMETHING GOING ON IN THE ENVIRONMENT, PROGRAM THE ♥♥♥♥ING GAME JUMPSCARE WHEN. YOU. ARE. LOOKING. AT. IT. This game, much like F.E.A.R. 1&2 has a clear separation of creepy moments, from action moments, making the scares predictable and the only sound coming from my mouth is a yawn. They clearly haven't learned much from the previous installments. This game is too action oritented, the name is F.E.A.R. not CALL OF DUTY 74 GHOST BUSTER sp00ky WARFARE. There are in-game action achievements that reward certain kinds of behaviors, like hiding in cover for 200 seconds, spending 90 seconds in slow-mo, getting 3 headshots in slow-mo. Keep in mind that these are mandatory if you want to "level up" (Yes there is leveling now) and get more slowmo time/  be able to carry more ammo. Keep in mind, these achievements aren't one time, you can get them every single level. So instead of appreciating the game for what it is, you're going to be replaying checkpoints just so you can get some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t achievement to level up.You can't shoot through walls, but enemies can.Alma kills NOBODY. Except one random enemy who exploded in a house, but even then you can kill him before Alma does.This is not a F.E.A.R. game.Not scary at all, hhell they barely even try, it's almost entirely action oriented.

content:
Posted: February 4
												The best thing I can say about F.E.A.R. 3 is that it was over quickly, the gore was plentiful, and the slowdown effect has lost none of its charm.The worst thing I can say about F.E.A.R. 3 is that the "Horror" tag is completely unjustified. Where the other F.E.A.R. games left a sense of dread. F.E.A.R. 3's tactic of scares seems to involve tacked on, sometimes cheesy moments you can shrug off. Even the jumpscares feel forced, and can be spotted from a mile away defeating the purpose of a jump scare.If you like FPS games that involve slowdown, and scrapes of horror...get this game. Otherwise, avoid at all cost. Get something better like the original F.E.A.R., Bioshock, or Metro: Last Light.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												FEAR3 isn't meant to be played Solo. If you have a friend you can CO-OP with this is a brilliant game. I played as Fetal on my play through and the different tactics opened up to me made a very good impression on me. The Campaign is not long which kind of works as a CO-OP game I think at one stage we will swap over and I'll play Point Man and will be a differen't experience. Between the mechs and the horror mechanics I think this is a solid co-op game but I imagine it would not of been as fun single player. As Fetal I was able to capture and hold enemies for Point Man to kill, Possess Snipers at the other end of the killzone and then between us take out everyone in the middle. Being bound to Pointman was limmiting but that mechanic made it more interesting like I had to be within range of him to exist.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												Average game, horrible sequel. The gameplay is reasonably fun and does have some qualities, same for some environments. As mentioned in the key features of the game : "F.E.A.R. 3 delivers all the hallmarks that define the F.E.A.R. brand". Indeed, it's all about the “coolness” and the “attitude” of what F.E.A.R is supposed to be rather than what made it great in the first place, because the marketing derpartement always know what is good for us. Long gone is the atmospheric shooter with tense combat, welcome to a shootfest with generic AI and the usual corridor missions. You'll get the shallow experience you've probably seen somewhere else, not terrible not great either, good fun for an afternoon perhaps. On the other hand, the second character is quite interesting due to his unconventional “ghostly” gameplay, making it worth replaying the game or convincing/fighting your coop partner to get a chance to play as him. Its just a shame you cannot use him right from the start in single player.When I said it is a bad sequel, I'm mostly mentioning its worst offence to the spirit of the series made manifest into the achievement system popping up every five seconds to tell you how great you are, increasing your level but more importantly, your score. Why ? Because the game's design is centred around competitive coop, who gets the best score, gets the ending associated to his character. While it isn't a bad idea on the paper, having the scoring in mind and constant pop-ups definitely breaks the atmosphere that used to be a hallmark of the series. This is even worse if you play in single player since the competition becomes irrelevant as you get the ending of the character you are playing.This competitive idea, also serve a purpose in the story, since both involved characters are competing to show their pregnant mother who is the most worthy while at the same time completely disempowering her because of that pregnancy that is about to bring an apocalypse. Its good to remind that she decided to be pregnant and stalked and then♥♥♥♥♥♥♥the second game's protagonist for it. So we have a sudden 360° reversal, destroying all that was powerful and creepy about her, transforming her into a passive reward that gets ditched away no matter which character wins. The two main protagonists writing is also incredibly weak. If they were supposed to be unfortunate companions hating each other, it never shows, as one is completely silent and never seems to not care, making all the snaky comments of the other guy who is bent on trying to be edgy and dark even more pointless and annoying. The ending is definitely puts the last nail in the coffin to the F.E.A.R franchise, because F.E.A.R online never existed.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Day 1 Studios heard the name "Point Man", got confused, and started trying to lick their elbows vigorously while attempting to figure out what it meant.This game was their answer.Press E on a dead body!Here are some points!Shoot bad guys!Here are some points!You have ranked up! Congratulations!Here are some points!Hey look! A spooky spooky little man crawled accross tha- Hey look a dead body! HERE ARE SOME ♥♥♥♥ING POINTS.F.E.A.R. 1? Fun and occasionally scary.F.E.A.R. 2? Fun and interesting, has it's spooky moments.F.E.A.R. 3? You seriously might as well get Call of Duty. It does whatever the hell this game was trying to do better and leaves the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t ranking/points system out of Single-player and has better multiplayer too.The only thing it really has going for it is Co-op, but there are again, better games for that too.Save your money.Edit: I finished the campaign in 3.7 hours. Far too short. The story was random and I didn't really know the purpose of anything I was doing for the most part. The only character that actually adds anything to the story is Paxton, he's also pretty much the only actual character in the story, Point man is a walking gun and the other female character from the first game (i'm assuming) is just kind of there, telling you the same exact thing over and over. Barely any unique Alma encounters or scary/creepy happenings that weren't random jumpscares (half of which are either just loud random noises or extremely easy to miss). Combat was typical of a F.E.A.R. game as Point Man, not a bad thing, but feels a lot cheaper due to the point system. Point system is downright intrusive and immersion breaking at times. Especially during the final boss. Recommendation stays the same, save your money.

number of helpful: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
 Short but fun coop FPS with horror elements, great controls and some minor flaws What is very important with regard to the third episode of the F.E.A.R. universe is actually that you should not fall for a direct comparison to previous titles. The present episode builds on and has its strong points when it comes to the coop element. Concerning storyline, concerning horror / scary moments, it might let you down or even disappoint hardcore F.E.A.R. fans. Take the game as it comes. Take it as a storydriven two-player coop FPS. A rare genre actually and what makes F.E.A.R. 3 definitely an enrichment in your library.  What I liked   Story driven coop FPS  Great, direct controls, good input feeling, good weapon handling  Two different playstyles which complement each other   End bosses and mech gameplay  Graphics are good and serve the purpose; very fluid performance  Some nice gore effects   F.E.A.R. universe / story is brought further  Coop horde survival mode  Level-up system  Plenty of achievements  Replay value together with a friend What I didn't like  It is short (5 to 6 hours) and gameplay feels a bit repetitive  It might get boring in a pure solo party  Blurry cutscenes which do not justice to a sharp display  Repetitive enemies  Horror effects are not scary enough for F.E.A.R.   Annoying connection issues with Steam  Dead multiplayer, so organize yourself well in order to play coop (neutral)  No 3D vision support. It has been abandonned im comparison to previous titles, which is a huge let down for fans of VR. It is overall a great coop experience. If you play merely solo, I would say there are plenty of better FPS. If you like the F.E.A.R. universe, do not get too much disappointed that the game is not that scary. But it complements well the storyline. Grab it together with a friend and have some hours of fun.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												SP ReviewDifficulty Played on: Fearless (Hard)FEAR 3 is a solid action game. It has times were the atmosphere is quite disturbing, but it is nowhere near as scary as the original. For those of you who have completed the original and all its expansions, this will be kind of a rehash of the 3rd expansion Perseus Mandate, only instead of fighting the merc group Nightcrawlers, you are fighting ATC corporate commandos. The story is of course different and like Project Origin, FEAR 3 ignores the original expansions  (Jin is still alive and such, Jankowski is not mentioned, but strangely your FEAR CO is still dead as he was in the Extraction Point Expansion)   You play as the Point Man from the original FEAR, and you fight Armacham as they struggle to cover up everything that went wrong in Fairpoint. You travel alongside your psychotic brother Paxton Fettel as you try to stop your mother Alma. Like I said, the game is a very solid action game, but it feels similar to many modern FPS shooters to were it feels like a shooting gallery. Enemies come at predictable patterns and can be easily outflanked and outmanuevered. You get rank ups for completing different challenges such as time spent in bullet time, weapon kills, and performing various manuever or enviromental kills. For each rank, you get a bonus in the form of more ammo, more health, etc. There are soul links hidden throughout the levels as well as dolls to get you additional XP. Finding them is not to difficult if you take the time to look around, but it kind of breaks up the actions a bit. This is similar to the original FEAR power-up system were you find health and reflex boosters. There are times in the game were it pulls you out of the action to deal with various paranormal entities in the game (The Creep being a noteable one). I did not find this scary as much as annoying getting routinely cheapshotted in a random part of the level. This does not serve to build much atmosphere as the monster itself is not to frightening and dampens the flow of gameplay IMO. There are some nice scary moments particularly in interval 3-5 when you go back to Fairpoint. The ambience here is great and the disturbing denizens bring back memories of the psychos from the Condemned series. These were my favorite parts of the game by far. Toward the ending intervals... The action became more tedious then rewarding. Using Power Armor was fun when it was first introduced, but it becomes fustrating during the Bridge interval. I should also point out that you cannot initially play as Paxton Fettel and can only play as him if you beat an interval as the Point Man. Paxton Fettel can suspend, possess, or use his psychic powers in a variety of cool ways, which does add something new to the game. There are two endings depending on who you beat the game with obviously, and Paxton Fettel's abilities do warrant a second playthrough. If you do play CO-OP through the whole game, whoever has the highest score determines the ending adding some competative play to CO-OP. Overall, the SP was fun and despite its hiccups was solid. The story wrapped up kind of weak and left me somewhat confused regarding the future of the series as well as other questions such as  why did Alma die after giving birth to her child, and why would she even consider Point Man a choice to be her successor. Paxon Fettel seemed to share her  goals and had a special link with her mother growing up. I also felt that it was a missed opportunity to not fight Paxton let alone Alma instead of Harlan Wade (who died in the first game). Alma has become quite an iconic horror figure, and it is a shame she went out with such a dull roar given how she laid waste to any and all who stood in her way  All in all, story aside, the game is definately fun and disturbing. Wait for a sale and pick it up.SP Score: 7.8/10Pros- Good gunplay- Great Atmosphere in some levels- Solid action game- Phase Commanders are a nice addition to the opposing force- Rank Up System is fun for completionists or people who like challenges- Multiple endings and CharactersCons- Becomes repetative- ATC soldiers aren't as interesting or threatening as the Replica Forces- Not as impressive of an arsenal compared to the previous titles- Some ingame events break up the action and can become fustrating- Though disturbing and creepy, the story is rather weak and the wrap up was phoned in- Monsters are nowhere near as disturbing or creepy as the original FEAR games- Missed opportunity: ending boss battle

Posted: November 15, 2016
												So, the question is....Would I reccommend THE 3RD game? I wanted too, I really did, but as the others have explained....It's not FEAR. If, I wanted to play BATTLEFIELD? I would've played that, instead of this duck-and-cover, generic, false advertisement this was. It's not a horror game, by any means. Blood and gore, doesn't mean you get to classify it as such. The others, got me to jump clear out of my skin. This one, didn't do so at all. The only reason, I kept on....Was the story. I wanted to know what was to become of them. Now that I know, I'm done. Difficulty, Fearless? Yeah, right. Gameplay was super easy. Oh, and I never used the "duck-and-cover" BS, unless....The game shoved me there, by accident. Nearly, killing me in the process. Also, Fettel should've had his own AI, and or vice versa, so you could've had cpu playing with you, and we should've had different choices in the end. (IMO) (Keeping the ending vague)]Instead, of trying to shove online play down our F3cking throats.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												3 OUT OF 5. recommend.but not very enthusiastically, and NOT for full price.  I really liked the first games, and the add-on packs. I was disappointed by this one. Definitely not up to the usual F.E.A.R level.  I don't like losing weapons after almost every interlude. , Also weapons have stupidly low levels of max ammunition. I wouldnt go into combat with only 150 rounds in my primary weapon, and I died quite a few times scrambling to try to find another weapon that had ammo.    The rendering isnt the most accurate. By which I mean you can be behind a barricade, and since this primitive game doesnt allow the lean feature, the only way to shoot from cover is to try to shoot over or expose your whole body shooting around.  If the center of a sandbag barricade is 4' high and the sides are 3' high, you cant shoot over the sides unless you aim higher than the center. You can SEE but you can't shoot. Also if throwing a grenade, the trajectory is as if you're tossing from your testicular level. I never carried 'nades by my 'nads. .        The worst part is the new "Captain?" who somehow craps out enemies relentlessly so that you need to try to kill him (and he takes a lot of killing), while dealing with attackers spawning from all around you.  THen at one point when you're low on ammo two of them spawn. They can appear anywhere, you cant escape them, so you die over and over.  Since they've gone the ever-popular console route, there is no way to save manually so you'll have to replay over and over to get past the areas where the enemy keeps respawning 5 and 6 at a time. One other criticism. When mapping keys, you cant reuse keys for different functions if in a mech suit or on foot. So you have to try to find keys you can reach easily and remember what they are, or remap every time you switch from armor to foot. Yes, it's a minor criticism, but most good games have a separation between vehicle key mappings and on-foot key mappings since you obviously wont be doing the same actions in a vehicle as you would on foot.          This isn't the worst game ever as some have said, it's just not fun enough to put up with the negatives. When the bogus (I"d use something else that has B and S in it) level got too high, I just stopped playing. I'll wait before buying for any future "Day 1 Studios' games, checking online for HONEST reviews and not reading reviews posted by the seller.     TWO GOOD THINGS: the challenges to level up added in single player are a pretty cool feature,. Even better, and the reason for the third start, is that the long cutscenes in between levels ARE SKIPPABLE! (pay attention Fart Cry duhvelopers). NOTE: I didn't try multiplayer, just single, campaign.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												TAKE ON THE ROLE OF "Point Man," A MUTE, CONSTANTLY EXTREMELY ANGRY BROTHER OF A GUY WHO LOOKS DISTURBINGLY LIKE NICOLAS CAGE. AS YOU MOVE FROM ONE GENERIC LEVEL TO THE NEXT, YOU MAY FIND YOURSELF OCCASIONALLY STOPPING MIDGAME TO THINK ABOUT HOW LITTLE SENSE THE STORY NOW MAKES, COMPARED TO FEAR 1 AND 2, WHICH WERE BOTH OKAY. FIGHT YOUR WAY THROUGH HORDES OF DEMONS, HOMELESS PEOPLE, (I THINK THEY'RE HOMELESS? I HONESTLY DON'T KNOW. THEY TAKE A LOT OF DAMAGE AND FOR SOME REASON ONLY SHOW UP FOR LIKE, ONE LEVEL. THE STORY NEVER REALLY CLEARS UP WHO THEY ARE, BUT IT DOESN'T CLEAR UP A LOT OF THINGS.) AND THE GUYS THAT YOU WERE WORKING FOR IN THE FIRST FEAR GAME BECAUSE, SCREW PROPER STORYTELLING, RIGHT? OH, AND I HOPE YOU DIDN'T PLAY EXTRACTION POINT FOR FEAR 1, BECAUSE THROW EVERYTHING THAT HAPPENED IN THAT OUT THE WINDOW. EXCEPT FOR YOU AND NICOLAS CAGE TEAMING UP. AND HOLIDAY DYING. AND ARMACHAM THINKING THAT YOU TURNED ON THEM. THAT'S RIGHT, FOLKS, JIN IS STILL ALIVE, EVEN THOUGH YOU WATCH HER GET ♥♥♥♥ING MERKED IN EXTRACTION POINT. SO ANYWAYS: YOU AND NICOLAS CAGE ARE NOW BROS, AND YOU TWO GO AROUND KILLING STUFF. AND THINGS. THINGS THAT ARE NEVER REALLY EXPLAINED IN THE STORY. LIKE HOMELESS PEOPLE. YOU START THE GAME OFF IN A PRISON LIKE ANY GOOD SKYRIM GAME, AND FOR SOME REASON YOU HAVE A KNIFE IN YOUR CELL. YOU START OFF WITH A KNIFE. YOU ARE HOLDING A KNIFE IN YOUR PRISON CELL. AM I THE ONLY PERSON WHO NOTICED THIS? ANYWAYS. YOU FIND OUT THAT JIN IS STILL ALIVE, EVEN THOUGH SHE OBVIOUSLY DIED IN FEAR 1. SO YOU AND PAXTEENI FATALLOONEY SET OUT TO FIND HER. AND YOU DO. AND SHE LIVES, I THINK. AND THEN YOU BECOME A FATHER, AND NICOLAS CAGE GETS DOMED BY YOU. OH, AND IF YOU PLAYED FEAR 2, BECKETT GETS BLOWN INTO NOTHING BY (YOU GUESSED IT!) THE CAGESTER. THERE YOU GO, I JUST SAVED YOU FROM LIKE, FOUR HOURS OF THE MOST UNENJOYABLE CONCLUSION TO ANY VIDEOGAME TRILOGY, EVER.SERIOUSLY, DON'T BUY THIS GAME.I MEAN, ON THE BRIGHT SIDE, ALMA LOOKS KINDA HOT AT THE END OF THE GAME, IN A WEIRD "YOU'RE-MY-MOM-WHO-IS-ALSO-CURRENTLY-GIVING-BIRTH-AND-COVERED-IN-BLOOD" SORT OF WAY.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												Expect a true sequel to the previous two games, and feel disappointment.Approach it as a, say, side story made by a different team (which it is) and enjoy a solid, fun, action-packed FPS that is great both on your own and with friends.It's not scary, although it tries to be at times, but atmospheric enough to hide the very much arcady shooting mechanics. That said, these mechanics are fantastic, and as a shooter FEAR 3 is highly enjoyable and, to my surprise, easily replayable.It's also hands down one of the best linear coop experiences you'll have in an FPS in terms of variety and coordination.The multiplayer oozes with original and fun ideas which sadly made it into game modes that didn't last long before the community died out, but if you have at least 3 friends who are into this game, get them together and have a blast in the surprisingly innovative multiplayer.It's been 4 years but FEAR 3 remains a highly enjoyable experience to this day. And if, like me, you were slightly disappointed with how FEAR2 turned out in relation to FEAR1, the third installment won't be MUCH of a disappointment, but rather a great time waster - be it alone or with friends.Get it. Just remember that it's not what its predecessors were.
