content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												Lets start this review with the truth. FEAR 3 is not a FEAR game at all and rather its a generic FPS. It was devd by Day 1 Studios, who handled the porting of FEAR 1 to PS3 and 360 (I originally played the PS3 version and have to say if memory serves it was a fine port that stayed true to the original game) and some games that were deemed mediocre when they came out and no one has ever talked about them since. So it makes sense that this game isn't a FEAR game aside from the name.The story is based off of what has come about from the first two games but unlike the spooky and mysterious tone of the first two games and especially the first this one just starts off goofy and borderline stupid. Something you get from a comic...book....http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Niles ....whoever hired this guy to write a story while looking at his resume is undeserving of the job they had at the time. I mean look at this guy, he wears facial hair and dresses like hes 30 or more years younger than he is and it looks terrible. He just looks like a manchild or something. Comic book stories are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, so now the FEAR story line at 3 is goofy and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like a comic book. 2 wasn't terribly great in anyway but 3 is just so so much worse especially story wise. Paxton Fettel is back and he is a ghost who helps you....this is literally the reason I don't read comic books. He dousn't help you like a beneficial all knowing god either, he just grabs you while your drowning and pulls you to safety kind of help. Steve Niles, if I ever end up near you...my fist requires a connection to your face.Gameplay wise its actually not fun at all. Its a generic fps so you just go through the motions of killing emotionless brainless AI enemies that don't follow any of the logic rules that made 1 so good. Flanking enemies dousn't do much when they are watching you through walls or just snap to you. Ammo is rare enough as to create a major annoyance and considering enemies soak up hits you find yourself with less than a magazine of ammo most the time. Its just like every other generic FPS game you played than forgot about and never cared about again. Enemies don't react quite enough to make it feel like your doing anything to them when you shoot them and shooting in general dousn't feel terribly good. The choice of weapons is very limited aswell, which in past games and especially in 1 wasn't much of a problem since shooting and all that felt excellent and still do. I was gonna throw in a COD joke since thats so trendy these days but honestly, this is more generic and worse than COD.Graphics are dated compared to the original or even 2. Overly demanding without a reason on higher settings. Its blurry diarhea in general. Sound is nothing special either, meh. Presentation wise the game comes off as if it was meant for multiplayer, I feel thats where it would shine in COOP where you and a bro arn't really paying much attention to the game itself. But honestly the way its all setup gameplay wise where one player is Paxton and the other gets the gun is really boring for one player or maybe both. Its just a crappy game. I want to call it♥♥♥♥♥♥but honestly its not really quite that bad. Its just generic and not worth much to me. It shouldn't be a FEAR game at all as its obvious they just wanted to use the name to bag bucks and screw the long term possible profits from future games.Everything from the old FEAR is here, but its not quite the same. Its like they looked at Fear 2 and tried to make it even more generic and casualised than 2. So now that makes Fear 3 miles away from Fear 1 and in the wrong direction with one shoe and no pants. Its just not a good FEAR game and a generic FPS in general. So basically its♥♥♥♥♥♥ but its not really♥♥♥♥♥♥because you can't tell if its♥♥♥♥♥♥because you will probably just get bored in an hour and just quit so you will never know if its really♥♥♥♥♥♥or just boring as watching trees grow in slow motion.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2013
												The storyline in this game dosen't make a whole lot of sense in context with fear 1 and 2. The reveal that Alma is pointman's mother in fear 3 seems to cheapen the scares in fear 1 since you now know she is your mother and dosent want to hurt her own son. It also makes no sense that spooky pants cannibal Paxton Fettel would help pointman all of a sudden after being killed by him in Extraction Point. For the first time ever in a fear game you can only carrry two weapons.. In fear 1 you could carry 3 weapons and in fear 2 you could carry 4. Why regress back to two weapons? You miss out on all the fun guns since the ammo for them is so rare they arnt worth picking up. There are no longer any competitive multiplayer modes like deathmatch or capture the flag, however i'll admit the co-op is a lot of fun. F.3.A.R. isn't a bad game, it's just a bad F.E.A.R. game. Hopefully one day we will get Fear 4 and possibly play as Alma's new baby or another original character.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2013
												FEAR 3 is particular in its way. Its most unusual feature consists in the fact that there's actually no fear - just anger, and irritation, and tiredness. It's not a thriller anymore - just a shooter. It still bears certain resemblance to Crysis, but I'd say that the latter is more 'paranormal' when compared to this certain game. And the bosses. sure, like in good old times. Damn, I hate bosses, really. (That was a reason why I liked the original FEAR, for instance.)What's on the positive side of it? Well, that's fine graphics, some new battle enhancements (such as the possibility to take cover behind certain objects and shoot from your hideout - previous FEARs lacked that function), and the gameplay fork that lets you play either with Pointman or with Fettel. And self-restoring health, yes.What's negative? Simplification, the common disease found in modern games. FEAR and (to some extent) FEAR 2 were more interesting; they were not merely about shooting people, there was room for investigation, for some exploration, and for some mystery. Now that's more trivial: here are some Armacham troops, here are you, you must kill them all and advance further. The same enemies, the same weapons... etc.My verdict - good, but not great. Worth giving a try, though.

Posted: April 6, 2014
												Slowpoke reviews. Game is a far weaker version of it's predecessors, to the point that it might as well not even be part of the same series. Horror elements are nearly absent, the plot is completely nonsensical, and the gameplay has become a CoD clone with achievements and a point system included.If you are considering getting this, even on a sale, don't. Trust me, even if you want to see the ending, you really don't.

Posted: November 23, 2011
												What can I say about Fear 3. I hope this is the end of the series. I really enjoyed FEAR and ever since it has been going down hill for me. Each subsequent release gets shorter and less scary. It is ripe with sequelitis. The story adds an interesting dynamic to the FEAR universe that leaves as many questions as answers. I played this through twice both in coop and we were able to see both endings, that is to say I won both times. the coop isnt that much co-operative but more competitive. you have the same goal in the story but the last scene Entirely depends on who got the most points and combos. The level design seemed to be wasted at times as many of the interval transitions were random and felt like half the game was Cut. a few levels were just there, nothing happened at all in them, again a waste. the graphics are astounding but why wouldnt you expect them to be. If you liked Fear 2 then this is right up your alley, but its lost what FEAR was. 6.5/10

Posted: April 1, 2014
												Now, back in the day i loved the first F.E.A.R game. It was the first time in my life when i genuinely got frightened by a computer game! Now, the second F.E.A.R sucked. It was bad. It was "some FPS", without a twist in any direction.So, i had no high-hopes regarding the third instalment of the franchise.I was disapointed - at first. "Bang-bang-bang...oh, some attempt to scare me with blood and scrams...yeah right"...boring.But then, the game got the hold on me. First thing i noticed that enemies actually give you hard time. Seriously.The quality of the A.I suprised me completely. Allso, the atmosphere did eventuallyl win me over. I did felt "dread" trough the game experience.In short:It´s "better than average / good" FPS. Just don´t expect it to resemble anything like the first first F.E.A.R.This game is worth your 10€:s, if you need some easy entertainment for an evening or two.

												I was never really a big fan of the F.E.A.R. franchise, but this is too much, and not in a good way.Let's start with some good things:- the graphics in the game are pretty decent and good looking- the shooting style is good- it has co-op (favorite thing)Bad things:- the game is way to short (finished it for 5 hours)- not nearly as scary as the first two games- gets boring really soon (although it is so short)- the "story" is just stupid and almost non-existent Overall, if you can get it for a few coins and play it with a friend maybe, but just MAYBE, you should get it.If it wasn't for the co-op I wouldn't even finish the game. 												FEAR 3 (in my eyes) concludes the story from F.E.A.R.You take off where F.E.A.R. 2 stopped.Alma is Pregnant with a son from SargeantYou take on the character you played with in the first F.E.A.R, wich is Point Man ( Right ), and, with an extra character, that is also from the First One. Posted: January 29, 2012
												By now, no one should expect new iterations of F.E.A.R. to be scary. While the first installment was the spawn of pure horror, Project Origin slowly deviated from the intense and moody atmosphere carefully crafted before. F.E.A.R. 3 returns to complete this leap, surprisingly finding itself on solid grounds.First and foremost, F.E.A.R. 3 is not a single player game. The campaign was designed for cooperative play. Expect some levels to be near impossible to beat unless played on a lower, and consequently less exciting, difficulty.As a mainly cooperative game, F.E.A.R. 3 is a shining example of how games don't need a competitive edge for replayability. Playing through the campaign with a buddy is a good experience, but it's in the various other game modes that this purchase becomes worthwhile.If you're looking for a horror game, you'll want to skip this. But, if you're looking for a thrilling experience to share with a friend, this instantly becomes a must-buy.Grade: B

Posted: November 25, 2013
												F.E.A.R 3 is a game I got in a pack from the Humble Bundle and is the first of the series I have actually completed, this review will focus mostly on a co-op playthrough experience. I'll start with the positives, since there aren't many. Firstly, the Fettel (Ghost guy) character had some interesting powers and I thought it made him a little different to the Point Man character, which was good to make the experience a little different for each player. Secondly, the Mechs were fun to run around in for the little while you really had to use them. Now, on to the negative aspects. The game is incredibly repetitive, tossing the same enemies at you level after level, having very little weapon variety among other things. Another aspect which didn't work as intended was the cover system, as enemies seem to be able to hit you from behind the "cover" you can take with a key press, making it a useless option to even have within the game. The final negative point I need to bring up is the lack of horror, the game contains no real "scary" moments at all, making little to no attempt to include some of the creepy atmosphere you might have found in older F.E.A.R games. Overall, I'd say to give this game a miss. Its around six hours (on nightmare difficulty) of repetitive timewasting, with little to no redeeming factors or unique features. If you are looking for a horror game, try the older F.E.A.R games, if you are looking for an FPS game, there are plenty of better examples, if you are looking for a co-op game, try something like Borderlands 2 or a gamemode for Garry's Mod.

Posted: April 1, 2012
												It's jarring how much F.3.A.R. is not a F.E.A.R. game. It drips of hubris, disregard for the franchise, and the fundamentals that distinguished its predecessors.The cyberpunk elements are just all but gone. The time to crate is about 3 to 6 seconds, whereafter the first level is room upon room of crates, and that sets the quality bar for the remainder of the game.The horror has switched from visceral and psychological to grotesque and gory. And the writing... It's subtle like a kick to the nuts.Not to mention the awards mechanic that replaces the hypo sprays. You get constant feedback about your actions, not unlike Bulletstorm's skill shot system. Of course,  they make no attempt to pretend that the system has any possible link to the world itself. Hell, they didn't even bother to keep the same key mappings. It's like the designers never even bothered to play F.E.A.R.

Posted: January 7, 2014
												I feel I should start by stating that I've enjoyed the F.E.A.R. IP for a long time. I played FEAR, its expansions, FEAR 2, and even FEAR 3 plenty on PS3, and I enjoy the series so much I chose to re-buy the entire collection on Steam so I can play it in its original format. I've played through FEAR three times, FEAR: Extraction Point three times, FEAR: Perseus Mandate twice, FEAR 2 five times, and FEAR 3 three times. 		Let me make this clear: FEAR 3 was not developed by the development team that made the other FEAR games; that was Monolith Productions. FEAR 3, on the other hand, was developed by Day 1 Studios. Sometimes games/franchises can turn out bad because of a sudden developer change, but sometimes the new developer works it well (like how 343 Studios did with Halo after Bungie stopped developing it). It all just depends on how the new dev team works.	It is in humble opinion that Day 1 Studios managed to screw up the entire FEAR universe across the span of a single game. I doubt this was their intention, but FEAR 3 is a mosh pit of disappointments, and it hardly ever stops going downhill. It's rittled with plot holes, has busted gameplay, and none of the oppressive atmosphere or well-paced scares that made the FEAR games so enjoyably devious. It's almost ALL uniformly gone.	Let's start with FEAR's thematic elements. For example, FEAR games have a theme of never taking the player's view away from the eyes of the protagonist; you always see what the character sees and nothing more, like with Valve's Gordon Freeman in Half-Life. On the off-chance you (and therefore the protagonist) see something that's not in front of your face, it's probably a vision induced by Alma. Another element to this theme is keeping the player (metaphorically) in the dark, leaving the player to explore the levels of the game to find more information (which was done by means of voicemail messages and readable documents) about their current situation. Other things about their situation are revealed to the player as their character sees them.	You protagonist was also silent, which was done so that the player felt as though Alma is haunting them, not the Point Man.  As such, whenever characters talked in dialogue scenes, your character is never directly asked a question, since silent protagonists can't answer them. Another theme was Intervals. Similar to the way Half-Life uses Chapters to break up its story, FEAR uses Intervals. Intervals were an important part of the structure of the game because they separated story divisions from gameplay levels, and these intervals were always a single word, ending in -tion (like Inception, Devastation, Isolation). These themes are completely dismantled in FEAR 3, as I'm about to explain.***THERE ARE SPOILERS HERE, AS I'M ASSUMING YOU'VE PLAYED FEAR, FEAR: EXTRACTION POINT AND FEAR 2***	FEAR 3 starts off in a prison; there is no explanation as to how Point Man got there. Paxton Fettel also apparently chooses to work with Point Man, even though there isn't any logical reason for him to do so. Point Man escapes from this prison (which is apparently in Brazil) and goes after his mother, Alma. What is already a weak plot start gets worse when Jin Sun-Kwon appears five minutes into the game.What's so ridiculous about this is that Jin Sun-Kwon is dead.	You actually hear her screams right before she dies in Extraction Point, then see her bloodily bludgeoned body five seconds later, with her blood all over the room, then get even more confirmation of her death by having the next loading screen say “Jin Sun-Kwon is dead”. Why Day 1 Studios thought retconning Jin Sun-Kwon was a good idea, I'll never know.	The plot doesn't get better. Intervals lose their importance as cutscenes tell most of the story, and the intervals (which are now blandly named “prison” and “store”) simply describe where the level takes place in. The interval names sound like they're still in development and Day 1 Studios simply hadn't thought of a real name for them. The cutscenes themselves are bad. In order to keep Point Man true to his character (I assume), Day 1 Studios kept him silent. This makes sense, but in nearly each cutscene another character will gesture towards Point Man or otherwise beseech him with questions, expecting an answer. Obviously, he doesn't give one. Because of this, cutscenes felt awkward, and most of the dramatic build-up was gone just because of how badly they were scripted. Many character deaths feel as if Day 1 Studios was just trying to create outrageous scenarios to kill characters so there wouldn't be any loose ends in the plot by the time the game ended. The worst example of this is very late in the game and happens to a protagonist from another FEAR game. The two endings to the game are mildly satisfying, but feel rushed. And with how badly the rest of the plot was executed, there was no dramatic build-up when the plot finally climaxed.**SPOILERS END HERE**	As for the atmosphere of FEAR 3, it's an opposite of what previous FEAR games did. FEAR games were about oppressive atmospheres, darkness, destruction, desolation, well placed scares and high mortality rates caused by an angry woman, coupled with a constant feeling of being hunted by said woman. In FEAR 3, environments are bland despite a graphical overhaul, scares are essentially nonexistent (and not scary when they do happen), and aside from two or three areas, there's a ton of light. The atmosphere is simply gone.	To make mattters worse, FEAR 3's co-op (which lets you play as Point Man or Fettel) is a train wreck. See, the game never makes it clear that this co-op is meant to be COMPETITIVE. The ending of the game is dictated by whoever gets the most points at the end of the playthrough. This is given by total kills, how you kill them, etc. While that's fine from a gameplay standpoint, the game never bothered to explain that it's competitive, which made many people perplexed at what ending they got, especially if they played co-op the first time through, because it felt arbitrary. If you're in co-op, why would you be competing to steal kills or headshots from each other? And how would you be expected to know that THAT affects the ending?That's not even including the fact that these points (which are accumulated by challenges) make the game feel like an arcade shooter, which only does more to undermine the atmosphere.The gameplay as Point Man is imbalanced. For example, some guns (like a pair of TMPs that he dual-wields) are incredibly weak, and their ammo drops are so rare and stupidly placed (why give a player TMPs if you're throwing a heavily-armoured mech at them right after?) that they're rendered useless. Other weapons, like the G3A3 assault rifle, are so over-powered that they render the game boring. The G3A3 is just the worst example: the G3A3 fires in a three-round burst, has a giant mag, barely kicks, and kills all non-heavy enemies in one-two bursts. From the point this rifle enters the game, the rest of the game can be watered down to aim the G3A3, use slow-mo, and massacre helpless foes. Playing as Fettel wasn't better; he's a god for most of the game, and even when I did have a challenge, it was because I was outnumbered ten to one, and still won handily.Finally, those points you accumulate do more than affect the ending; they help your in-game profile rank up. This is how (as Point Man) you earn more slow-mo, get higher mag capacities, or (as Fettel) get higher possession ranges/duration times. This means your character gets stronger as you play (which is cool), but it doesn't reset; it's permanent. I actually had no challenge in the second playthrough becauase I had tons of slow-mo and buckets of bullets all the way through.The only bright spot to FEAR 3 was its co-op multiplayer, especially the mode "F***ing Run", but it was just a nice distraction from an otherwise awful game. I sincerely hope FEAR 2 gets a REAL sequel someday.

Posted: April 4, 2014
												I played this game because I was in the mood for some scares, but ended up with a bunch of feels that I didn't know what to do with.Honestly, I see a lot of people poo-pooing this game for having a bad plot, messing up the series, blah dee blah...But I absolutely loved it.The strange love/hate relationship between the two brothers is something I found to be very tragic and engaging. Unlike the past two games, this one humanized Alma and Paxton to the point where I actually sympathized with them, and the final scenes (both "good" and "bad") left me torn. Both brothers have been deeply wronged, and it was fascinating how each one dealt with their past... With Paxton choosing vengeance no matter the cost, and Point Man choosing to not give up on mankind, which in turn gave way to mercy.Maybe I'm just a sap, but this game is going to stick with me for a long time.

												This sequel to FEAR 2 is not quite as "shocking" or "scary" as the first two and ops for a more action/sci-fi story with occasional occult references. The SP on its own is decent, not mindblowing, but where it really shines is playing coop with a buddy. The SP is incredibly fun with a friend and it feels that the way the game was designed. Unless you've played the other two, the story wont make much sense either. Multiplayer modes arent explained very well, but they are fun provided you have people. Unfortunately it suffers from P2P Matchmaking, thus its technically dead. Great coop game if you have a buddy! 7/10

Posted: August 20, 2014
												Such a great game, the new controls from the original FEAR took me by suprise and I felt kind of weird about it but everything felt so smooth and worked so well together that I began to love it. Love to see more of this game engine in the future (Despair Engine) I was amazed with graphics, interactions and physics. Unfortunetly this is basicly a single player game now adays and you'll need to find friends to play with, the online is dead. The game does have alot of replayability to it tho. Do to achievements and a fun scoring system for the campaign and fun solo challenges.Still completely worth the ride if you ask me.

												 am about done with this game. It has been fun. The graphics are very good, the sound is better than that. I have never liked games without real save game systems. Checkpoint saves are lazy. The voice acting was better than OK but repititous. The weaponry was effective even the grenades. Having to start each "interval" with no weapons was silly and I have never seen more helicopter/plane crashes in my life. As far as the FEAR factor it takes more than a game to scare me. The game does give "starts" but if you want to be afraid watch The Exorcist home alone at age 10. I like that I can play as Fettel if I want. Maybe I will. Point Man looks like the dude from Just Cause 2 or is it the other way around. Chin Ho or Kam Fong or whatever her name is has a nice butt but beyond that I am tired of games with chicks that disappear but call me on the "phone" regularly. Just so no one FREAKS !!!! Chin Ho is a character from Hawaii 5-0. I liked the combination of indoor and outdoor locations. The Mechs were OK but if there had been more mech I would have liked the game less. They make too much noise. The game has not crashed on me and I play it with all graphics pumped to the MAX. I captured different parts of the game using FRAPS. It is a practice of mine. There is full frontal nudity in this game. Overall I give it 8 out of 10. Will there be a FEAR 4?

Posted: February 23, 2013
												F3ar is a strange beast.  It tries to be a horror game and fails miserably by overwhelming you with cliche horror imagery.  It lacks the atmosphere to drive the point home even if this wasn't the case, however.  The game tries to tell a story, but it's so confusing and poorly explained that I still can't tell you what the point was supposed to be after finishing the game.  I couldn't tell you how it's supposed to be connected to the previous games either, other than the fact that Alma is here again.The graphics are pretty bland (though the blood looks good!)  The game is further let down in this department by motion blur that seriously blurs the screen even while standing still (you can disable this in a config file) and a poorly implemented depth of field effect that can't be disabled.  Levels are filled with lots of arbitrary contrived obstacles that detract from the game atmosphere and only serve to make your passage through the level slower.The gunplay in the game is pretty good, which at least makes it tolerable to play.  They also added a pretty cool dynamic crosshair feature where the gun sights will change color when pointed at an enemy.  The game also uses a cover system which you will die quickly without.  It works pretty well most of the time but occasionally it'll leave you aiming at a wall when you try to pop out.Fortunately the multiplayer is more interesting, though it is poorly explained and some modes are extremely difficult.  I doubt anyone's still playing so you'll need a group of friends to try it out.While the game tries to be something different, it just manages to be one of the most generic shooters I've ever played.  There's lots of better single- and multiplayer FPSs out there, so I'd recommend buying one of them instead.

												Not F.E.A.R. No real horror elements, no I-threw-away-my-mouse scares. Solid shooter, with a bit dumb AI that is the norm these days. Graphically it is also not the best. (Even F.E.A.R. 2 might be better in this aspect, amongst others) The ending is botched at best.Where it shines would be the multiplayer: the new game modes are innovative enough, but lack one crucial factor: number of players. Four is more than enough for a coop campaign, not nearly for a complex multiplayer mode like Soul Survivor or F**king Run.

Posted: May 23, 2012
												F.3.A.R. continues the story of the second game and plays the character of the first game (you can use a second character after you finish each interval) The game is a decent port to the PC, could use a little more optimization but it's not bad, I got a Steam redeemable key for $4.99 and it's worth it for the SP alone. MP seems dead though as I couldn't find many coop matches. The game seems harder compared to its precedessors and the AI is smarter and not dumbed down. Good game overall, finished the campaign in about 5 hours. Many questions are answered and many new ones arise, wonder if F.E.4.R. is in the works.

Posted: January 31, 2012
												This game is NOT scary... That said, if you liked F.E.A.R. and F.E.A.R. 2 because of their spookey elements, then you will probabally NOT like F.E.A.R. 3.The reason I like F3 is mainly because of the gameplay.  This game plays almost exactly like F2 does.  You get similar guns and you get another few levels with the MECH.  The gameplay is extremely fluid with really really cool special effects. One gameplay change that I liked is there is a lot less collection involved.I think I'm going to finish this game (currently around 50-75%-ish done), but so far it does not have a lot of reasons to replay it (other than the really cool feature of co-op mode, which I haven't been able to test).  Once you complete a level, you "unlock" Paxton Fettel (your brother) and you can replay the level through as him.In the end, if you loved the "Slom-Mo" killing-storm you can become, then this is the game you were waiting for.  For die-hard F.E.A.R. fans, be ready to be disappointed.

Posted: April 3, 2016
												You know a game's♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥you off when you've gone out of your way to reinstate "Family-Share" JUST to condemn it via review.Rating: 4 out of 10, this game features dated graphics, derivative "MMS" gameplay, repetative level-designs and encounters, a spit-in-the-face narrative, and a stagnant multiplayer community. If you're looking for the tactical-shooter/psychological-horror experience this game promised, go play FEAR, its expansions, and its first sequel. If you're looking for the wannabe-COD experience this game delivered, go play FEAR Online...you're gonna' LOVE it...

Posted: April 6, 2016
												1) New to Fear ? If so, then start here. If you've played any F.E.A.R game before go on to section (2).     Fear is a combination of "Bullet Time" shooter and walking simulator. So there will be sections of each level that are arenas for gunfights, and then there will be areas that are you walking around while "spoooky" things happen. A few sections combine the two, but they are mostly segregated experiences.     I would reccomend you don't start with this game. Instead you should play FEAR 2 (which does everything this game does but better) or F.E.A.R (The original) because its has the best enemy A.I that you will EVER find in a fps game. This game was mainly built for Co-Op play. The problem is that these Co-OP systems are only semi-optional. They are very intrusive in the single-player experience. If you're looking for a co-op fps , this isn't bad, (though it is a bit buggy, but nothing too horrible). 2) I avoided this game for a long time because of the common wisdom that it just wasn't good compared ot the previous 2 games. That is true...butThe campaign is about *half* ish as long as the second game. You're meant to replay the game as Fettel (the ghost brother) . But his gameplay experience isn't so much different that you'd want to replay the game over again. The co-op and multiplayer systems are not bad,  but they aren't really anything special either. The game does have some very nice "scary" sections in some places. It also does *try* to provide a satisfying conclusion to the *story*Everything is in service to the multiplayer systems however, including the story. I could only see this being reccomended if you can get it for a very low price or if you want a decent 3-8 hour multiplayer experience. RECOMMENDED FOR CO-OPT ONLY

Posted: April 22, 2016
												There was no fear to be had in a game called 'Fear'. But then again, it has a lot of dots between letters (not sure how many exactly, hey, not everyone is into quantum mathematics or geometrical algebroids, ya know), and it also got a number (I think it's a sequel to the second one, which was a sequel to the first one, and the first one had a prequel about Uncle Fred and his good friend - a talking German banana named "Leutenant Mattias Von Gruber"), so it has A LOT going for it. Just like my doctor always says: "if you cannot handle something, just calm down and try not to choke on your vomit'. Which is a perfect analogy for this game and our life in general. 10/10.

Posted: March 11, 2016
												After the disappointment that was F.E.A.R. 2, Monolith decided to hand over the torch of mediocrity to Day 1 Studios, who in turn, dropped it into the ocean of incompetency, and drowned trying to retrieve it. The shooting components are noticeably weaker, nice to see the highlight of the series rammed even further into the ground. Mech sections make a return, because they worked so well in the second game, now a lot longer and more painful to plod through. The narrative is one of the worst I have seen, it started with an interesting premise in the first game and now has mutated into a despicable mess, devoid of any redeeming qualities. Giving the Point Man a voice and developing his character would have been a wise choice, engaging in dialogue with Fettel and expressing his thoughts and feelings about the chaos erupting around him. Instead we have Fettel trying his hardest to be unsettling and failing dismally, while Point Man gives him this hilarious look of contempt, which never leaves his face. I'm absolutely disgusted with how it ended, I didn't expect much but it really is abhorrent. As far as horror is concerned, Day 1 thinks that displaying butchered corpses and splattered blood in every corner is an effective way to drum up the scares, newsflash, it's not.A miserable way to end a trilogy.4/10

Posted: September 21, 2014
												After noticing that their price during the sale was FIVE DOLLARS, I actually had to delete my previous review because after playing F.E.A.R. some more and watching clips of it and Project Origin in another person's review, I felt I'd not explained ENOUGH just how much of a trainwreck this game is. The F.E.A.R. feeling is entirely gone. The gameplay is derivative and uninteresting unless you play as Paxton and they should have set it up like that in the first place instead of making you have to unlock him. Game looks, feels like dogshit compared to its predecessors.There, there's the whole game review. But that's actually less of the point. This game is like a cruel joke to those who liked the series. It has nothing to do with it gameplay wise. It's possibly the WORST ending to a trilogy in video game history. There's so much lore and story details that could make a person want to like it, but it honestly seems like the developer (not Monolith) was having a laugh at fans of the series. It literally feels like this was made in spite, and it's baffling considering Day 1 has made good games. They should have never made this game. They should have just made another Mechassault. For a moment, WB Games became the dumbest publisher ever. They reduced two silent, strong, badass protagonists to two uninteresting character, one of which has an extremely dull personality when he wasn't supposed to have one at all and one of which is a little ♥♥♥♥♥, making it seem like all of your actions were utterly in vain. Do not buy this game, even if it's really cheap, if you're a fan of the F.E.A.R. games and want to see how it ends. The only people this would probably appeal to are those who have never played any of the games in the series.Picture a clown laughing at you for ~5 hours before you whack your nutsack with a pool cue. Then, sticking your head up against the wall and don't STOP. DON'T. For another hour.That's F.E.A.R. 3.

												Pretty alright, though the campaign could've been a bit longer. The plot is err... sufficient, atmosphere is alright though far from FEAR 1 goodness, gameplay is pretty fun (though shotgun is atrociously bad) and there is potential replayability due to there being second character who plays a bit differently. There's also coop and a few interesting multiplayer modes, but there is no alive community and you can't get into a match "on the fly". If you want multi, you'll need to grab a friend. All in all it's ok, if you enjoyed FEAR 2 then you'll like 3 as well.

Posted: March 18, 2016
												A well made game in all rights and I will say that this is an ACTION game before it is a horror game unlike its predecessors.Multiplayer is good and feels well made but again it is DEADThe games story mode is done well yet short with only a few hours of gameplay to run through yet the leveling and point system creates competition during co-op gameplay which two players control two polar opposite characters. Player one takes on the role of Point Man which is pretty much that, he is the point man who goes in head on and guns down enemies with an arsenal of firepower and slow-mo gunplay. Player two plays as Fettel the main antagonist from F.E.A.R.: First Encounter Assault Recon who plays more as a support class with possessing enemy soldiers and using them for a limited time to use their weapons and back point man up.On the topic of the story is that there are two endings one is for Point Man (good ending) and the second is for Paxton Fettel (bad ending) and depending on which player has the highest score at the end of the game gets their ending but the solo campaign is solely Point Man's ending7/10 points needs a bit more horror to feel fearful of Gameplay 8/10Story 6/10Controls 8.5/10Multiplayer (If you can find a game) 7/10

Posted: December 7, 2013
												Well i got this game in a HB, so if you got it in a good bundle or with a hight discount, this game is a good way to get some fun with some friend. Cooperative campaing will look crazy if you did not played Fear 2 & 1, but it's still a good FPS.I missed some puzles in the game, since each player has his own power and it could make the game way more rich than it is in that way. Not either me or my friend understood much of the story-line, but we both had a good time with this game. Also, I just was waiting for lot of scary things or monsters, and we just got a bit at the end, but it was really dissapointing if we just look at this.Anyways, I'd say that this game is higly recomended if you have one friend to share with and you like FPS.

Posted: April 17, 2015
												I bought this game on HumbleBundle for around five bucks and I even finished the game. Here's my final verdict, splitted into Pros and Cons :)Pros:- The graphics are pretty good- Cutscenes are very decent- In-game cutscenes are seamless- Animations are smoothly, like the enemies' movements- The game runs extremely smoothly, no framedrops etc- The blood and gore is decent and there (but there could be more)- Fights can be pretty intense. Hard, but fun!- The weapons have a great impact and it's very satisfying to decapitate a enemy with a sniper rifle.- There is no direct safe / load option, but there is a checkpoint system. Normally I absolutey dislike a pure checkpoint system, but here it's done very well! Thumbs up.- Some levels were plain awesome. Like the one in the store with all those TVs. Awesome! I also liked it that there were same parts of levels where I was able to mount a Mech. Nice.- Auto-regnerating health. While many players hate this, I welcome this. Because I'm a bad player with no skills, so thanks for that.Things I don't judge:- Levels are very linear. I don't mind linear gameplay as long as the action keeps going.Cons:- Very few (but great!) weapons- No akimbo mode for pistols (but for Uzis, somehow)- The ranking system. Do I really need this?- The story. I didn't followed the story of any FEAR game. Same here, never was interested in.- Enemies are invulnerable while animated (while they are jumping over a crate for example)- The boss battle in interval 8 ist plain boring.- Even for me as a bad gamer, the game seems kinda short.- What the hell can I do with Fettel after I unlocked him for a mission? I never found out, to be honest.- Same with those zombies. They're still standing after three close range blasts of a shotgun. What the hell? And those knive throwing idiots in the beginning of the game, I felt like I'm in BIOSHOCK.- I got REALLY tired of those moments where you automatically start to walk slow, your slomo-option is disabled and you know that something will appear. Bored the hell out of me.- The later levels, screaming Alma and always that babbling Fettel. I know, it's probably part of the story but it annoyed the hell out of me.In conclusion, FEAR3 is a good ego shooter which will serve a few hours of fun. Don't expect much, because you won't get much.

Posted: March 29, 2016
												Despite a too-short campaign and repetitive levels, FEAR 3 is still a good finale to one of the most unique first-person shooter franchises I've ever played. The weapons are fun, blowing bad guys away in slow-mo remains satisfying, the scares are lethal and the graphics are still quite impressive, with a lot of really beautiful lighting effects. When it comes to the FEAR series, one thing that I've always loved about them is how the genius of each instalment lies in the mixing of cinematic elements of Asian horror with 80s action films. Perhaps the series as a whole could be best described as The Ring meets Die Hard. However, this wouldn't do it justice, these games are well worth playing, both for the casual gamer and the survival horror aficionado. Hopefully someday we can see a fourth one!

Posted: April 8, 2016
												Just finished F.E.A.R 3 for the first time and have played through the whole series with its DLCs this game really ties up the whole story very well.I love how the story is told in the game and it is very nicely presented.If you haven't played the other F.E.A.R games I would recommend strongly doing so as you will understand more and also other aspects of the whole story.If you have played the other F.E.A.R games just be prepared that how you fight in the game is somewhat different. You still have your slowmotion combat but how you take cover and such is different. It is in a good way thou.Combat in the game is fun and good! The melee is fun with the powerslides. Pick your weapons and some are better for certain combat situations then others.As I always do I recommend playing on Fearless difficulty level to get the best enjoyment and challenge in the game. It isn't that bad since I made it through ;) Dying isn't that bad!I do recommend this game and do play the other F.E.A.R games in the series before is my recommendation.

												If you play this game, please play it with a friend.  It was FANTASTIC to play it with someone I know.  The game is quite short if you go straight through the campaign (5-6 hours), so I would recommend getting it on sale.  This game has jump scares, it has camp, it has a terrible pun.  It was SO FUN that I have a new love for the F.E.A.R. series.  I was cracking up throughout the game on voice chat with my friend.  If you play it with someone you know, I think it has some good replayability.The co-op is alot of fun!  Very different play styles depending on if you are Point Man or Fettel.  There are also opportunities to compliment one another as well as opportunities to compete against each other.  Seriously, I had a great time with this game.

Posted: December 29, 2014
												This game hasn't really improved upon F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin but is still a fun game to play. You basically play as Point Man, whom was the protagonist in the first F.E.A.R. game that was considered to be the best shooter of 2005. This game starts off by you being tortured in a jail cell by two gaurds and you have to escape to find Jin Sun Kwon. Here's where the plot problems come into play. The game doesn't tell you where or how you got to where you started, it just puts you there out of the blue, with no relation whatsoever to extraction point.The gameplay is like a basic first-person shooter with mechanics such as taking cover and jumping over obstacles. It's good but I hardly used it at all since how that controls is just hard to get used to. You also posses bullet time which allows you to slow down time and shoot at enemies much quicker and easier. This makes the game realitvly easy in the beginning but you will be greatful that you have it since the game gets realitvly hard and frustrating near the end.The major complaint I had with this game was that the game's difficulty is completly unfair when playing solo. Here's what I mean by that: When you have to fight the two commanders near the end of the second last level, you will die probably 10-20 times at least untill one of them gets hung up on the wall while you kill the other. Seriously if it wasn't for that I would be stuck here still trying to beat that part; it's just impossible.It's not a very good game but it's still a good game so I would still recommend you play this.

Posted: February 6, 2016
												I just finished this game after having it in my backlog for quite a long time and honestly part of me wished I didn't play this game at all because of how much I love F.E.A.R and F.E.A.R. 2. Don't play this if you loved the previous F.E.A.R. games, which sucks to say, but this is not the experience you'd want for a sequel.Performance/graphics:Performance is ok in the sense that I was able to play at 120fps most of the time, but did have dips on occasion, There aren't as many graphics options compared to the first two games, but there are still some. What really bothered me was the forced Motion Blur the game had and the only way to turn it off is via an options.cfg in the game's local folders. Not too big of an inconvenience, but definitely something they should have added in the game's options menus especially when it was toggable  in the previous two games. Graphics themselves are ok, still good looking, but honestly F.E.A.R. 2 looks way better, at leas to me.Combat:F.E.A.R. 3's combat is 100% different compared to the first two. Obviously they're all FPS games, but the actual weapon combat(aiming, weapon firing/response, etc.) is completely different and I don't think it was for the better. You're limited to only two weapons at a time, no medkits/armor pickups(regenerative health), but there is still slow-mo and vehicles in the game. Also there are still around the same amount of weapon variation in the game compared to the first two, but you're just limited to only two at a time which I think is a huge negative, but might be because of the co-op mode the game has, so to balance it out.Atmosphere:Still "scary", but compared to the first two games F.E.A.R. 3 is more action than horror and that's bad. I'm not sure if it was because of the co-op addition so they couldn't account for player positioning for jumpscares or scene build ups correctly, but the games are suppose to be scary, but this game probably only scared me once out of the four hours I played it.Story:I appreciate the closure the game has given me for wanting more after completely F.E.A.R. 2, but I wish I didn't experience this closure exactly. The game has two endings, one considered "Good" and one "Bad", but I'd say both are pretty bad. I won't post spoilers, but if you love F.E.A.R and F.E.A.R. 2, don't play this.Price:This game is not worth $19.99, not even close to that. I got it for $4.99 a while back and that's honestly all I would feel comfortable paying.

Posted: February 6, 2016
												Altough I recommend, be warned. This almost feels like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ cousin of Farcry, the Farcry that was hidden under the sofa from the neighbours. I would only suggest this for big fans of the series.Graphics:- Good, rich environments and very varying techniques. I thoroughly enjoyed the visual quality of this game. But it clearly looks like a console game. The performance is good, but I did have to drop my Antisotropic Filtering slightly which baffles me?Sounds:- Good, realistic and believable but suffers from the same problem as Fear 2 in that the music is cued and sometimes kicks off in strange intervals during a fire-fight.Gameplay:- This game is not scary. It is deviod of scares and just doesn't have the same element of fright as 1 & 2.- The environments are varied, and are done justice. Altough I do not like the fact that the game starts in Brazil, it was believeable.- Not all of the guns are useful, I hated the Combat Shotgun and only used the pistol when I was forced to. SOme weapons were absolutely useless.- The AI sucks, it seems to have gotten worse as the series has progressed.- The game is riddled with FMVs. FMVs? Is this the 90s? Is this Final Fantasy? I don't want FMVs in my action-shooters, I want action.Story:- Load of crap. It feels like multiple people had their opinions and ideas added and removed as the story progressed and the full view was just hard to follow and uninteresting.- I do like that they included The Point Man, Paxton Fettel & Becket, but the weaving of the characters together is so forced it feels like it's being helf together by super-glue and band-aids.- The protagonist (The Point Man) is so unlikeable it's ridiculous. He looks like a serial-killer and acts like someone who would NEVER have been accepted into the F.E.A.R. operatives in the first place.- The game starts in Brazil. Brazil? of all places, why Brazil? It's so far removed and misplaced. Guantanamo Bay, I could still believe, but a random slum in Brazil? WTF?

												This game blows. Was a huge fan of the original FEAR and it's expansion packs (got the platnium edition in 2007). It was like COD MW meets The Ring. Unfortunately it all went downhill from there.In the original game your character was a heavily armed badass trading punches with the bad guys. Posted: October 25, 2015
												Finally got around to beating this.Negatives: - storyline is stupider/less scary than FEAR- campaign starts really weak- have to unlock ability to kick/slide- enemies are less responsive, ai is less interesting- shotgun is meh, nailgun is super rare and meh- not enough tight spaces fighting vs soldiers, where FEAR really excelled- sexist in a kind of sad, they don't even get it kind of wayPositives:+ co-op that is interesting+ weird points system encourages various styles of play+ levels are genuinely varied+ mechs are cool, useful, can be skipped+ bosses are challenging but not unfair+ backstabs added to melee moveset+ helicopter always explodes+ pistol use encouraged/rewarded+ sewer section short+ laser cannon is great, dual submach's are great, rifles are great+ get to fight every annoying bad guy to the finish Overall? If it is in a bundle that you are buying to play through the original, or you want solid 2 player co-op campaign, or you want a shooter campaign that is genuinely different from COD knockoff BS (after level 1), go for it.

												С каждой частью F.E.A.R.теряет статус хоррора,однако все боьше удтверждается как один из лучших экшенов от первого лица.И F.E.A.R.3 тому подтверждение:много экшена и лишь жалкие попытки припугнуть игрока,которые представлены в игре традиционными клише для жанра horror.Имеется отличный кооператив и несколько режимов в мультиплере,которые точно недадут вам заскучать.Минусы:графика игры базируется на том же движке,что и вторая,что выдает устаревшую картинку;продолжительность игры недолгая.

												Rage like in terms of gunplay. Unfortunatly the missions were divided into cutscenes, but the the story makes up for that. Maybe if you read the other reviews you will see a lot of negativity about the sudden change of gameplay but I liked the change it become a lot more fast pace now.7.8/10

Posted: February 20, 2015
												I'm going to start off by saying that I loved the first F.E.A.R. and all of its expansions.  Never had I been so scared of a little girl in a red dress or so saddened in a video game by learning what was done to her.  The sci-fi elements were futuristic, but still grounded in the feel of being the kind of thing a military black ops unit would keep hidden from the 21st century public.F.E.A.R. 2 just didn't have the same punch with either the atmosphere or the gameplay.  I remember the slow motion horror  when the first mechsuit came bursting through a wall at you in F.E.A.R. 1.  Then F.E.A.R. 2 had them shooting down from space.  Just felt like going overboard to me.Then we have F.E.A.R. 3.  The sense of horror, that fear of the unknown that got triggered whenever the lights flickered.  You just don't feel it anymore once you realize that Alma is pretty much on your side at this point.  This is quite simply a run and gun game.  In addition, the sci-fi elements border on Star Trek with enemies teleporting in via portals.  And changing over to that regenerating health model just makes it feel nothing like the first F.E.A.R.  The only thing that kept me playing was that I've wanted to know how this trilogy would end from the get-go of F.E.A.R. 1.I wanted to like this game.  I hoped it would undo some of the minor snafus that came up with F.E.A.R. 2 and give us a dark and unsettling finale to one of the best horror games I've played.  Not a total let down, but a let down none the less.

Does literally nothing but limit your mobility and awareness. Give me a break."evolutionary slow-mo modes", what? ITS THE SAME AS IN EVERY OTHER ♥♥♥♥ING GAME WITH SLOW-MO, INCLUDING THE LAST 2 IN THIS VERY SERIES."Generative System", I never noticed it, except for shotgun guys randomly spawning behind me with no indication and killing me in 2 shots.

Posted: February 15, 2015
												It's been 10 years since I played the first Fear game but I remember liking it. I only played a demo for the second one but it seemed cool too. This third game is something else. The story is just non interesting and at least half of the time I don't even really know what's going on. The gameplay is really just:Take coverPop up and fireTake cover so health can regeneratePop up and firerepeat until shooting gallery is emptyMove forwardRepeat shooting gallery processrepeat repeat repeat until level is overIt's a competent shooter, sure. I don't really know why it used the Fear name though. I guess if you like the Fear series and you wish it was actually Call of Duty then you'll dig it. It's OK but I wasn't really looking for Call of Feardy.I hear the multiplayer aspect is cool but I don't care about that stuff. I probably should have passed on this game but it's not completely horrible. It's just "meh" really. The FOV needs to be fixed right from the get go. It's pulled in way too tight. There's no option for it either . You will need to edit a config file. Also the graphics are muddy. There are no hi-res graphics to be found anywhere. This game really isn't that old. Sheesh. Typical console port.

Posted: February 24, 2015
												Despite all the hate coming from people, F3AR is enjoyable in its own right. Granted, gameplay was streamlined too much compared to the sequels that it feels too much like Cowadoodee (but not completely).For one, medkits are gone and regenerating health is the new heals BUT unlike COD, regenerating health can bite you in the♥♥♥♥♥also as enemies do like to punish you hard (as in if they're not understrength, they WILL push towards you while trying to regen health). So no medkit abuse to get out of a fight where you're guaranteed dead.Gunplay is a bit generic, but still enjoyable. You do have a destructible cover system that allows you to shoot from side to side, allowing for limited tactical gameplay. Its not original, but workable enough. The martial arts that the first game had and the second game downplayed, are now gone, however, which is a huge damn shame, because ♥♥♥♥ knives, I wanna punch and kick every person I can find like John Woo from hell.There's also a unique feature in F3AR in that you can play as the pointman's sociopathic brother: Paxton Fettel. On his own, he can only throw out telekinetic bolts and levitate thiungs and can't use guns. He can, however, posses certain enemy troops for a limited amount of time, allowing you to have your meat puppet wreak havoc on the enemy lines before doing it again. He can also make people's heads explode like in Scanners. If you can find a friend to play Co-Op with, the prospect is quite good.The atmosphere (after the first level) has to be one of the best features of the game. You do feel like in an apocalyptic wasteland after a psychic/nuclear disaster. It's not "depressingly beautiful" or "adrenalin-pumping beautiful" but just creepy. The more you progress, the more you see how horrifying Fairport has gone down under. People are crazy. Cannibalistic crazy. And the locations you venture through will reveal how high the level of crazy went into this place.As for difficulty, F3AR does have it. ATC Black Ops and the Replica troops are tough that they usually take a few hits to take down, have a kiiiinda decent set of tactics. Though, the AI does kinda shift from Competent to Call of Duty at times, but most of the time, they remain competent and will give you a run for your money. Cannibal AI is not that far from your everyday zombies from L4D and the likes, but they will try sneak attacks as much as possible.As for multiplayer. Its pretty much dead. Unless you have friends. Its dead.Overall, F3AR might be a bit shifty with its price of $10, but is a definite buy if its on sale. It'll give you some decent enjoyment for its price.

Posted: February 27, 2016
												A F.E.A.R misses the point from the original games. What a mistake!GameplayI can see why people would find it fun if this is the first time they are playing a fear game. It has a lot of action and is overall an average shooter. What made the first game great is gone in this one. For an FPS the game is boring and it is just another genetic FPS game. It overall fails to deliver its own name FEAR!You can play as two different characters this time. One with awesome supernatural powers and one without. To unlock the character you have to complete it. No one is playing this game twice. The levels are boring and I cannot differentiate the levels from eachother. They are mostly based around small corridors and in general just lazy game design.GraphicsThe graphics are heavily outdated and looks awful for a game that came out in 2011. Think of Skyrim for god sake. It looks like the graphics from Doom 3! There's almost no details in the levels. Pathetic! It has this dark grainy Instagram filter on, which you, by the way, cannot turn off. Speaking of things you can't turn off is the mouse acceleration and motion blur.SoundThe sound is pretty good. The music is scary as it should be. The voice acting is not best, but it's alright. The ambient sound is pretty cool too. VerdictThe game is incredibly frustrating and is overall not a good game. If you're thinking about buying this, please spend your money wiser.

Posted: January 27
												This is a dumb game. It has a stupid story, a stupid narrative, a weird exp system, and all sorts of weird ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that just seems at odds with the franchise. I love it though. The gunplay is by far the best in the franchise with responsive, accurate, and powerful weapons.  The combat is a ton of fun as long as you avoid playing it like a cover shooter. The cover system stills allows you take damage behind cover, so it's an ultimately pointless mechanic. However the enemies die fast enough and your weapons hit hard enough that sprinting between cover and jumping over tables while enabling bullet time makes you feel like Neo. For reference, here's how the games rank:Best Combat: F.E.A.R.F.E.A.R. 3F.E.A.R. 2Best Gunplay: F.E.A.R. 3F.E.A.R. 2F.E.A.R. 1Best overall gameplay: F.E.A.R.F.E.A.R. 3F.E.A.R. 2Best Plot/Narrative:F.E.A.R. 2F.E.A.R. F.E.A.R. 3F.E.A.R. is still the best in the franchise, but F.E.A.R. 3 is so much fun i can't help but recommend it. Game multiplies its entertainment value by a factor of 5 when you finally unlock the overpowered monster that is Paxton Fettel. Overall F.E.A.R. 3 is a bad game that is a ton of fun. Highly recommend.

												Compared to FEAR 2 this game is quite a bit more fun, mostly because you can play with a friend. Posted: April 29, 2015
												Alright, let's get this out of the way: F.E.A.R 3 is NOT a bad game. It does what it does in a competent manner and there are some elements of it that are actually pretty good such as some of the art direction. But is it a great game? Not so much. While the core combat is decent, it is nowhere near the standard that F.E.A.R 1 introduced and F.E.A.R 2, to a extent, continued upholding. Guns no longer bite massive chunks off walls, particle effects are WAY downscaled and everything just feels a bit...off. But again, F.E.A.R 3 is not a bad game. If you want to see how the story ends or just want to play a decent FPS to tide you over until "the next big thing", then F.E.A.R 3 might just be worth picking up...during a sale.

Posted: May 10, 2015
												FEAR and it's sequel were really good games, both managed to be scary in their own way and have some really fun shooting in it. Heck, FEAR 1 has some still impressive AI behind it. FEAR 3 is a dumbed down shooter, player 2 gets some different mechanics if you're playing co-op but honestly the game is weak all the way to the lame last boss. I'm not being overly harsh either, I've played some dumb shooters and enjoyed them but FEAR had some bite to the combat, this game frankly doesn't. You have regenerating health...and a cover system, seriously that's how far they've dragged this game down. Deadspace 3 was pretty butchered, it was at least a fun co-op experience this game got pretty dull, the good news you won't be bored long, it's less than 5 hours on hard mode. The game has some neat visuals but that's about all it's got going for it. They just straight up seemed to forget to add any actual horror in it. It has none of the jumpscares of the previous ones, the tense atmosphere. The final boss was as generic as you can get, without spoiling it? Big slow monster beyond a 'fence' that you shoot at chipping away parts of it till you win. I don't know what they're bragging about on the steam page, they didn't bring any of the hallmarks that deliver anything from previous FEAR games. If you're a fan of the FEAR series? Don't bother, this could have been a totally different game they renamed to FEAR and I'd believe it.  If you're just a fan of a good shoot-y game? STILL don't bother, there's better games for cheaper. If you got this in a bundle? Gift it to someone.

Posted: January 25, 2012
												FEAR 3 is a fairly good installment into the series but it isn't scary, not at all scary. What it lacks in a scare factor is makes up in its disturbed storyline, since its mainly focused on the "brothers" and their past, what they went through ect. I feel that it was pretty disturbing at times. Visually the game looks good, and it will play on most modern day computers so you do not need a fancy graphics card, which isn't a bad thing. Day 1 Studios has made a good installment into the Fear series, I do think if Monolith developed it, they would have spent more time, and would have done a better job. As for game play Fear 3's strongest feature would be the co-op mode. Which of course you can play with your friends, one thing I didn't care for much would have to be the little Achievement boxes -so to speak- popping up every five seconds to let you know you did something unimportant. 8 out of 10.

Posted: July 10, 2015
												You know, this is not a terrible game. Good graphics, decent action, and I absolutely must compliment the audio people for that part where you have to fight with your hearing impaired. That was cool.But, when you come from the previous FEAR games, you surely expect something different than this. The game mechanics are now "modern", that is, ripped from COD:MW (the favela level makes the inspiration even more obvious). With the regenerating health and hand-to-hand combat, the once essential slow-motion system became almost unnecessary. The very mood of the game has changed, lacking that oppressive atmosphere that made the original FEAR so cool. Even Alma, who previously had nuked a city and sexually abused a soldier, now much more tame and passive. This game has traded true edge and psychological horror for cheap scares and gore.Worst of all, the endings are very unsatisfactory. You won't get much closure here.Ultimately, FEAR 3 was some decent fun, but definitely lacking. It's not good enough for me to recommend, but not bad enough for me to tell people to avoid. It's just average. And after two excellent games, it should have been much better than just average.

Posted: October 4, 2015
												It's nothing like first and second FEAR games, it's more COD type shooter with little horror (mostly jumpscare). You can feel and see how clearly this was made for consoles, the menus and controls are slow and clunky when using keyboard and mouse, with FEAR 2 they at least tried to make a good PC port but with third game they didn't even try. Usually I play FPS games with keyboard and mouse, but FEAR 3 is much more enjoyable with XBox360 controller, the controls are much easier to use and even the targeting is more responsible with gamepad.The story continues right from where the second game ended and this time you can even play as Fettel after completing the stage. FEAR 3 is fairly easy just like the second one so I reccommend to play on Fearless if you are looking challenge. Also this time there is some kind of leveling system like on the COD series, where you get bigger ammo clip, longer motion control, more health, etc. after getting enough points from completing small type of challenges (like get 10 headshots, use motion 10 times and so on). The main game is short, only around 5-6 hours to complete, but you can play the levels as Fettel and there are some colletable items, so these will make the game little bit longer.The granades are useless they have small area of damage and don't do much damage even when exploding next to the enemy. There are some walls that are scripted to break down, but anything else will not move even little bit when blasting them with missile launcher, game like this needs destructible environment, you can shoot oil and other spesific cans that will explote when shooted but it's not enough for a game that was made 2011.The multiplayer seems dead, I'm not sure if they have shutted down all the servers, but it didn't find any games.If it's on sale or in bundle I can reccommend it but I wouldn't pay over 8$ for it

Posted: October 4, 2015
												F.E.A.R. 3 follows directly after F.E.A.R. 2 but has very little of a connection to F.E.A.R. 1 since certain events never happened due to the Monolith and Vivendi timeline of F.E.A.R. being a bit different. In short, it's two different story lines, but none the less a good idea to play the predecessors in order to have an idea of what is going on in the game. The developers did an excellent job when it came to playability. I've spent hours playing this game over and over again, doing achievement hunting and completing the game in Co-Op mode (probably the best feature) with my friends. The greatest disappointment (in my opinion) is that fact that they moved away from the horror elements of the game. Don't get me wrong, there are a couple of scares in the game, but it's not nearly as intense as its predecessors. This shouldn't discourage you to play the game, because what lacks in horror the game makes up for in playability. A few multiplayer modes have been added that makes it so much fun to play. Like its predecessors, I highly recommend that you give this a shot, it's a great game with a great story line!

Posted: May 26, 2015
												The inaugural F.E.A.R was amazing. Blending FPS action with a hint of Japanese supernatural horror, which was a winner in my view. But can F.E.A.R 3 keep up with the hype? First of all, I never played F.E.A.R 2, but thanks to Google, I knew what happened as far as the plot is concerned. Gameplay wise, I would have to pass.I would just concentrate on the horror aspect of the game, since the gameplay mechanics is pretty much the same, with the "bullet time" system taking center stage. On a short note, the cover system can be a nuisance sometimes. Though, the ability to play as Fettel is a nice addition. I would also like to note that I've never played any of the multiplayer modes just yet, so I would have to pass.This third installment tried to live up the standards as set in the first game, well it tried(with emphasis). The signature Alma scares which was omnipresent in the first game isn't up on par here. The scares were freaky at best, with little fright value as compared to the first game. Remember the part where Alma was waiting at the top of the ladder? Yeah, nothing like that here. Although the sense of vulnerability is still present, much thanks to the survival horror themed inventory system. As for the enemies, well, they are fairly challenging, especially those high up in the ranks. Boss fights are straightforward, so nothing big about that. To sum it all up, F.E.A.R 3 doesn't live up much to its expectations. The relatively short campaign is a turn off. Couple that with a rather awkward ending. I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone who's never played any F.E.A.R title just yet. As for those who follow the franchise, well try to keep your expectations low.

Posted: January 15, 2015
												Do yourself a favor and don't pick up this game. ESPECIALLY if you're a fan of the first 2 games in the series.Disclaimer: I have not finished the game, despite trying repeatedly over the course of about a year. I just couldn't enjoy it.Pros:-Nice visuals, such as skin falling off enemies.-Solid shooting mechanics-Can get pretty spoopyCons:-Enemies, weapons, everything has been stripped from the previous games and replaced with very generic stuff.-Piggybacking on the above comment, the setting and pacing of the game do NOT fit in the franchise.-Terrible A.I. You'll run into two basic enemies, Armacham grunts who aren't a challenge even on the hardest difficulty, and what are essentially very poorly done zombies. Sometimes they have bombs strapped to their chests. The A.I do not react to gunfire or anything. You do fight these soldiers that are electrified? And they somehow shoot electricity and spawn more soldiers? I don't ♥♥♥♥ing know. The mechs are insanely easy to fight, just take cover and spam since they pretty much only use machine guns.-Regenerating health and endless amounts of ammo, effecting the pace of the game-Absolute♥♥♥♥♥♥tier story. Honestly feels like it was written by a child. Fettel and Pointman are a joke, you don't feel nearly as connected with either as you did with F.E.A.R 2's protagonist, or even Pointman himself in the first game.-Dead multiplayer-RPG elements CONSTANTLY popping up on your screen. 'LEVEL UP!' 'FASTER RELOAD!' 'DOUBLE XP!' 'FIND THE BODIES FOR MORE XP!'. It's absolutely ridiculous how intrusive it is.Overall it just feels like one of the most generic games I've ever played, and definitely one of the least fitting in its own franchise. It's a horrible disappointment. If you loved the first two games, just pretend this doesn't exist. It's what I'm desperately trying to do.Also, I know I constantly compare it to the other two games. If you haven't played the others, play them. If you want to play this on its own, buy it for less than 5 dollars, but don't buy it full price. It isn't fun, and it's definitely not worth putting on your backlog.

Posted: October 30, 2015
												This game deviates from everything that made the original FEAR and it's expansions great. It includes regenerating health, cover system, extremely weak AI compared to the original, and I can't do my favorite thing anymore. That is kung foo replica soldiers to death. All of the fun has been stripped out to and replaced with call of duty elements in an effort to stay relevant, your melee attack is even a knife swing. But the FEAR series didnt need to buy into these tropes the gameplay in the first two was tense and had consequences. You were the ultimate bad♥♥♥♥♥but you had to think and use all the tools available to defeat the smart AI. Levels in the original have branching path ways and felt like real places with boosters to collect to make your health and reflexes better. Now we have a market point system that breaks the immersion of the game as an excuse to have customization. Varying enemy types had a heavier pressence in a battle, HEavy troopers would come through the wall while grunts out flank you. Now we have wave after wave of dumb always reacting the same soldiers. In every firefight i could run right up to the enemies with a shotgun and shoot them. It doesnt matter how much damage I take because I wont take enough to die and it regenerates anyway. Plus I have slo mo which is just a cop out in this game. Sometimes there are a few supernatural monsters thrown in, but it's all forced. I believe that during the production meetings they developed all of the shooter elements and while making the horror someone said, "Just throw some scary crap in there. The game is called FEAR right?". So sorry to say but FEAR 3 is lame, buy the original and its expansions Extraction Point and Perseus Mandate, for shooters that actually feel good to play.

Posted: March 1, 2015
												There's not much I can add that other reviews don't already state. The gameplay seems more like C.o.D. than anything. The health kits are gone and replaced with a throbbing, veiny, red outline until you take cover and recuperate. The slow-mo kits are also missing and instead you search for radiating corpses and Alma dolls that increase your psychic ability.The storyline is lacking and transisition from mission to mission isn't as smooth as prior games due to the odd plot readers and post-mission point totals. I do not care how many points I earned in said mission. The game seems better geared towards co-op and maybe this was planned in anticipation of F.E.A.R. Online, which I've yet to play.There are two possible endings, depending on who you play as: Point Man or Fettel. Point Man's ending seems more fitting but still leaves you feeling lacking. Fettel's ending feels forced and doesn't really fit imo.On a positive note, the ragdoll effect is amusing. So is blowing off an enemy's limbs and half of their face with a shotgun. The mech missions are by far my favorite missions in this game and possessing a Spartan for a few seconds is slightly rewarding.Aside from the weird meth-zombies, (Halo) Spartan cross-overs, and shoddy Fettel gameplay, it's worth playing once if only to unravel the little bits of backstory fed to you over the course of the game and to conclude the♥♥♥♥♥♥of Becket in Project Origin.

Posted: February 24, 2015
												Despite all the hate coming from people, F3AR is enjoyable in its own right. Granted, gameplay was streamlined too much compared to the sequels that it feels too much like Cowadoodee (but not completely).For one, medkits are gone and regenerating health is the new heals BUT unlike COD, regenerating health can bite you in the♥♥♥♥♥also as enemies do like to punish you hard (as in if they're not understrength, they WILL push towards you while trying to regen health). So no medkit abuse to get out of a fight where you're guaranteed dead.Gunplay is a bit generic, but still enjoyable. You do have a destructible cover system that allows you to shoot from side to side, allowing for limited tactical gameplay. Its not original, but workable enough. The martial arts that the first game had and the second game downplayed, are now gone, however, which is a huge damn shame, because ♥♥♥♥ knives, I wanna punch and kick every person I can find like John Woo from hell.There's also a unique feature in F3AR in that you can play as the pointman's sociopathic brother: Paxton Fettel. On his own, he can only throw out telekinetic bolts and levitate thiungs and can't use guns. He can, however, posses certain enemy troops for a limited amount of time, allowing you to have your meat puppet wreak havoc on the enemy lines before doing it again. He can also make people's heads explode like in Scanners. If you can find a friend to play Co-Op with, the prospect is quite good.The atmosphere (after the first level) has to be one of the best features of the game. You do feel like in an apocalyptic wasteland after a psychic/nuclear disaster. It's not "depressingly beautiful" or "adrenalin-pumping beautiful" but just creepy. The more you progress, the more you see how horrifying Fairport has gone down under. People are crazy. Cannibalistic crazy. And the locations you venture through will reveal how high the level of crazy went into this place.As for difficulty, F3AR does have it. ATC Black Ops and the Replica troops are tough that they usually take a few hits to take down, have a kiiiinda decent set of tactics. Though, the AI does kinda shift from Competent to Call of Duty at times, but most of the time, they remain competent and will give you a run for your money. Cannibal AI is not that far from your everyday zombies from L4D and the likes, but they will try sneak attacks as much as possible.As for multiplayer. Its pretty much dead. Unless you have friends. Its dead.Overall, F3AR might be a bit shifty with its price of $10, but is a definite buy if its on sale. It'll give you some decent enjoyment for its price.
