												This wasn't made by Monolith, instead being made by Day 1 Studios who worked on the console ports of the original FEAR titles. Outside the title, slow motion and returning characters from past games (You play as Point Man again) it's FEAR only in name. To begin with there's a two weapon limit, regenerating health, a focus on co-op and almost no horror. This makes it sound like it's a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥but I enjoyed it way more than the second and like it as much as the first FEAR since while it's not the same it has a better idea of what it wants to be than the second title which went for shooting and horror again but wasn't very good at either. It has the most varied and colorful locales in the series, some extremely statisfying combat, good co-op modes and the campaign itself is very good and made better if you play it with a friend. First player controls Point Man who can slow down time like he did in the first game, do fancy melee moves (slidekicking an enemy, entering slow motion and gibbing him with a shotgun blast rules), and ride mechs in certain areas. The second controls Fettel who can possess enemies such as soldiers (who control similar to Point Man but without the slow motion) and other more exotic ones who control differently, he can also just run around in ghost form killing enemies with some weird projectiles he shoots from his hands, or lift enemies into the air for Point Man to shoot if you want to share kills with your partner. Point Man can also do something similar by activating slow motion which will also give the ability to Fettel for as long as he keeps it active. Leaning is back in the form of a cover system that lets you peek around corners and shoot enemies. It works surprisingly well.Expect most of the game to revolve around the combat as there's very little downtime unlike past titles in the series.The co-op modes are the standard Horde mode where you barricade the area you start in similar to COD Zombies, ♥♥♥♥ing Run where you and 3 co-op partners must escape an approaching wall of death by running to the exit while killing enemies that try to slow you down, Soul King which is 4 players with Fettel's abilities trying to possess and kill as many AI enemies as they can, and finally Soul Survivor where one player must turn the rest of their team into monsters while they fend off enemy waves with the last surviving human player being given the option to escape.Like I mentioned above there isn't much horror in the game, there are some randomized scares in each playthrough of the campaign but almost every single one of them consists of things appearing when you open doors for a second then vanishing after the musical stinger plays. The final level is kind of ~~spooky~ the first time but that's about it.In the end it's not FEAR but it's still a pretty good game. I really enjoyed playing through the campaign both online and offline, playing the multiplayer modes and watching the surprisingly well done cutscenes that try to wrap up the mess of a storyline the series has.

Posted: May 16, 2015
												FEAR 3 (or "F.3.A.R." if you are so inclined) is an odd game. It's a horror FPS with a coop campaign, that grades you on play time and CoD style challenges. None of those things are exactly helpful when trying to establish a scary atmosphere. However, this doesn't stop the game from being an immensely fun shooter on it's own terms. All the important parts like weapon feel, movement, AI and enemy variety are solidly executed. If that would have been it, I would probably have played through the game in single player mode once and left it at that. The reason however for why I keep returning to this entry into the series and not the others, is the totally unique, totally awesome Paxton Fettel ghost mode. Using the (un)dead brother's ghost abilities feels just as satisfying as pulling of a really cool slow-motion moment, except with a much higher frequency. Possessing enemies across the map, shooting their squadmates and then bursting out of your unfortunate host practically never gets old. Why none of this gets unlocked for single player before beating the campaign once is beyond me.As much as FEAR 3 is the sequel, that nobody asked for, it's quite an underrated game. If you don't actually care about the story in FEAR and are looking for an, in many ways, unique shooter, I recommend it.

Posted: August 22, 2014
												This is not a bad game. As someone who doesn't really like First Person Shooters, or ever thought they would, I was entertained by this game for the most part. The cinematic mini-movies and cutscenes were very well done in terms of graphics and art and all that good stuff. Overall the soundtrack was good as well and really heightened the tension...well, where tension was SUPPOSED to be, I suppose.See I probably went "Oh!" in surprise/shock once in the entire game. Once. For a horror game that isn't a very good track record, yes? I feel that, compared to the other games in this series (of which I have seen people do walkthroughs of on YouTube) this one is the weakest in terms of scares and horrors. Of course, if you only played FEAR 3 and didn't play the other games, it wouldn't seem that scary because you haven't really dived into the universe that this story takes place in, with psychic soldiers and a handsome cannibal (cough) and a mute main lead that you control. And of course, Alma.Compared to the other installments this one also felt a little forced and the ending was anticlimactic. Despite dying quite a few times in the beginning and being stuck on where to go, this game went by fast. In terms of the story this series had to tell, this was the "Falling Action --> Denouement" portion of it, which we all know is the quickest-going part of any story, as that's what makes it entertaining, the speed and the tying of everything together.But since this was a separate game, separate from the events that occurred in FEAR and FEAR 2, it feels flat, much like you only read the last few chapters of a book instead of reading the whole thing. I know it's because I haven't played the games in order (ha..haha) but from the very first level there really isn't any...set-up as to why and where and who and how. You just have your mission, you do it, with Fettel snickering and most likely floating by your head with each event (Oh my God shut up I'm doing my damned job alright?!). It's not very strong on character development, at all. We know our players and we know what everyone is capable of so go go go go!! I will say that I very much enjoyed all of the weapons in the game and it made me feel good seeing the little pop-ups of achievements and points being made as I did certain things like killing this many dudes with an SMG or meleeing 30 dudes, etc. I did find the level design to be a little frustrating as well as my jumping abilities. Oh I can jump on THESE boxes but not THESE boxes? Getting stuck is also a small worry I have in the back of my head since sometimes the environment is climbable and other times it's all "♥♥♥♥ your parkour, you ain't going ANYWHERE".So I guess all-in-all this game was a little lackluster compared to the rest of the series which, while not having personally played it, know the capacity of horror and action possible; but if you like shoot-bangs and an awesome slo-mo ability as well as very well-done cutscenes I'd play this if I had nothing to do.

Posted: December 29, 2014
												This game hasn't really improved upon F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin but is still a fun game to play. You basically play as Point Man, whom was the protagonist in the first F.E.A.R. game that was considered to be the best shooter of 2005. This game starts off by you being tortured in a jail cell by two gaurds and you have to escape to find Jin Sun Kwon. Here's where the plot problems come into play. The game doesn't tell you where or how you got to where you started, it just puts you there out of the blue, with no relation whatsoever to extraction point.The gameplay is like a basic first-person shooter with mechanics such as taking cover and jumping over obstacles. It's good but I hardly used it at all since how that controls is just hard to get used to. You also posses bullet time which allows you to slow down time and shoot at enemies much quicker and easier. This makes the game realitvly easy in the beginning but you will be greatful that you have it since the game gets realitvly hard and frustrating near the end.The major complaint I had with this game was that the game's difficulty is completly unfair when playing solo. Here's what I mean by that: When you have to fight the two commanders near the end of the second last level, you will die probably 10-20 times at least untill one of them gets hung up on the wall while you kill the other. Seriously if it wasn't for that I would be stuck here still trying to beat that part; it's just impossible.It's not a very good game but it's still a good game so I would still recommend you play this.

Posted: April 13, 2015
												I bought this a while back on sale and quite enjoyed it, but ultimately I was left dissapointed by the length of the campaign.  F.E.A.R 1 still remains the best of the series (by quite a stretch) but I'd say this is an interesting diversion.The missions are replayable due to the score/challenge mechanics and the controls are fluid  Most of the campaign missions are enjoyable with very little downtime for exposition and cutscenes, meaning the pace remains fairly solid throughout.  Combat is fast paced, sometimes chaotic, but most of all fun with all the trade mark sillyness that comes from F.E.A.R's melee combat and wonky ragdoll physics.Both of the main characters have different play styles which does just enough to make each individual playthrough unique.  Although the linier paths through the missions are almost identical for each, they play very differently due to the mechanics.The multiplayer scene was dead before it even hit the ground.  The netcode is absolutely atrocious and even using direct P2P connections it would only connect on a handful of occasions.  It's a shame because the multiplayer had a chance to be genuinely enjoyable, with both co-operative and competative game modes.On the plus side you can still play these co-op missions solo via "training", but obviously it's not quite the same.The reason I'm reviewing this now is because I only recently came back to it and had an absolute blast playing through the campaign.  It's extremely silly, fast paced and mindless and if you can get it for under £5 I'd say it was money well spent.

												Alright, let's get this out of the way: F.E.A.R 3 is NOT a bad game. It does what it does in a competent manner and there are some elements of it that are actually pretty good such as some of the art direction. But is it a great game? Not so much. While the core combat is decent, it is nowhere near the standard that F.E.A.R 1 introduced and F.E.A.R 2, to a extent, continued upholding. Guns no longer bite massive chunks off walls, particle effects are WAY downscaled and everything just feels a bit...off. But again, F.E.A.R 3 is not a bad game. If you want to see how the story ends or just want to play a decent FPS to tide you over until "the next big thing", then F.E.A.R 3 might just be worth picking up...during a sale.

												I bought this a while back on sale and quite enjoyed it, but ultimately I was left dissapointed by the length of the campaign.  F.E.A.R 1 still remains the best of the series (by quite a stretch) but I'd say this is an interesting diversion.The missions are replayable due to the score/challenge mechanics and the controls are fluid  Most of the campaign missions are enjoyable with very little downtime for exposition and cutscenes, meaning the pace remains fairly solid throughout.  Combat is fast paced, sometimes chaotic, but most of all fun with all the trade mark sillyness that comes from F.E.A.R's melee combat and wonky ragdoll physics.Both of the main characters have different play styles which does just enough to make each individual playthrough unique.  Although the linier paths through the missions are almost identical for each, they play very differently due to the mechanics.The multiplayer scene was dead before it even hit the ground.  The netcode is absolutely atrocious and even using direct P2P connections it would only connect on a handful of occasions.  It's a shame because the multiplayer had a chance to be genuinely enjoyable, with both co-operative and competative game modes.On the plus side you can still play these co-op missions solo via "training", but obviously it's not quite the same.The reason I'm reviewing this now is because I only recently came back to it and had an absolute blast playing through the campaign.  It's extremely silly, fast paced and mindless and if you can get it for under £5 I'd say it was money well spent.

												What can I say about Fear 3. I hope this is the end of the series. I really enjoyed FEAR and ever since it has been going down hill for me. Each subsequent release gets shorter and less scary. It is ripe with sequelitis. The story adds an interesting dynamic to the FEAR universe that leaves as many questions as answers. Posted: April 4, 2014
												I played this game because I was in the mood for some scares, but ended up with a bunch of feels that I didn't know what to do with.Honestly, I see a lot of people poo-pooing this game for having a bad plot, messing up the series, blah dee blah...But I absolutely loved it.The strange love/hate relationship between the two brothers is something I found to be very tragic and engaging. Unlike the past two games, this one humanized Alma and Paxton to the point where I actually sympathized with them, and the final scenes (both "good" and "bad") left me torn. Both brothers have been deeply wronged, and it was fascinating how each one dealt with their past... With Paxton choosing vengeance no matter the cost, and Point Man choosing to not give up on mankind, which in turn gave way to mercy.Maybe I'm just a sap, but this game is going to stick with me for a long time.

Posted: March 2, 2013
												F.E.A.R. 3....... this is a love it or hate it type of game. It is completely different from the previous games. It doesn't play like a FEAR game, it plays like "just another FPS game". The suspense and scare moments aren't here at all. The story is terrible, filled with plot holes. No character development or proper believable narration to speak of. There are a total of only TWO NPC you will have a conversation with in the whole game. It feels like I'm in a game killing hundreds of faceless and nameless enemies for no reason. There is no story immersion.There is no more health&armor points either. The game is so consolified it dilluted the F.E.A.R. experience. Just hide and wait for the redness to disappear from your screen. This type of health works with some games but it shouldn't have been used on a F.E.A.R. game. As an FPS game, it's fine. Especially if you haven't played the previous games. But if you did play them, you will feel like you're playing a very watered down sequel that doesn't take the last games seriously.I did not play the co-op mode but they say that is quite enjoyable.

Posted: April 24, 2014
												Sorry F.E.A.R. fans, and sorry for myself :(Remembering FEAR 2 goes back in time, FEAR 3 episode goes Forward in the story again.Acording to the story events: FEAR 2 > FEAR (and expansions) > FEAR 3Just like any blockbuster, this game lives out of the previous successes. I have seen many bad reviews, unfortunatly they were all well fundamented. The story goes around the "Weird Family", just like any cheap TV show, now formed by: Alma the♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off dead Mum, her violent sons (we can play both), her new GI-Joe-boyfriend, and her new baby (Good Job Mr. GI Joe!!)Ok.. lets skip for goodies and badies..[Goodies]- Being able to replay the game with both brothers and use tactics according to their skills- Some visual improvement over FEAR 2 (but not much)- Some interesting "bosses" and get to drive a mech again =)[So so]AI: The AI looks ok, sometimes they move and change hideouts. I think FEAR 1 and 2 had a lot more fun AI. This ones just hide too much. They are predictable and we can be confident nothing fancy will happen. They do behave more realistic because I also wouldnt go out of the hideout if I was watching all my friends die =)[Badies]Where am I supposed to get chills and jump from my chair? It DID happenen in the other episodes. This game moves out of the thing that made it so interesting. Creepy stuff that wouldn't stop surprising me ( aka "gotta-change-pants-again factor")Sound: You dont know how I missed the comments from the enemies, full of courage or.. desperating in fear. In FEAR 3 they just say the same GI-Joe stuff through the whole game without any emotion.[Horrible!]Last the not least, the main reason for the score..I expected to play an FPS-creppy game and I was presented with a HUD full of fancy cheerful RPG stuff.Please keep the "Mission Score", "Found Items", "Play Style scores", "Achievements for shooting", "Achievements for camping".. bla bla bla FOR YOURSELF! Just give me a damn creepy game.Believe me, its hard to jump out of my chair at the same time a pop-up saying something like "CONGRATS! YOU'RE RANK IS NOW PIKACHU 7" comes on the screen. But despite falling behind in the FEAR series, its still a nice shooter.PlayTime: 13 hours (As pointman) + 1 hour (a few speedy levels with Fettel)Score: 6 / 10

Posted: May 10, 2015
												FEAR and it's sequel were really good games, both managed to be scary in their own way and have some really fun shooting in it. Heck, FEAR 1 has some still impressive AI behind it. FEAR 3 is a dumbed down shooter, player 2 gets some different mechanics if you're playing co-op but honestly the game is weak all the way to the lame last boss. I'm not being overly harsh either, I've played some dumb shooters and enjoyed them but FEAR had some bite to the combat, this game frankly doesn't. You have regenerating health...and a cover system, seriously that's how far they've dragged this game down. Deadspace 3 was pretty butchered, it was at least a fun co-op experience this game got pretty dull, the good news you won't be bored long, it's less than 5 hours on hard mode. The game has some neat visuals but that's about all it's got going for it. They just straight up seemed to forget to add any actual horror in it. It has none of the jumpscares of the previous ones, the tense atmosphere. The final boss was as generic as you can get, without spoiling it? Big slow monster beyond a 'fence' that you shoot at chipping away parts of it till you win. I don't know what they're bragging about on the steam page, they didn't bring any of the hallmarks that deliver anything from previous FEAR games. If you're a fan of the FEAR series? Don't bother, this could have been a totally different game they renamed to FEAR and I'd believe it.  If you're just a fan of a good shoot-y game? STILL don't bother, there's better games for cheaper. If you got this in a bundle? Gift it to someone.

Posted: January 29, 2012
												By now, no one should expect new iterations of F.E.A.R. to be scary. While the first installment was the spawn of pure horror, Project Origin slowly deviated from the intense and moody atmosphere carefully crafted before. F.E.A.R. 3 returns to complete this leap, surprisingly finding itself on solid grounds.First and foremost, F.E.A.R. 3 is not a single player game. The campaign was designed for cooperative play. Expect some levels to be near impossible to beat unless played on a lower, and consequently less exciting, difficulty.As a mainly cooperative game, F.E.A.R. 3 is a shining example of how games don't need a competitive edge for replayability. Playing through the campaign with a buddy is a good experience, but it's in the various other game modes that this purchase becomes worthwhile.If you're looking for a horror game, you'll want to skip this. But, if you're looking for a thrilling experience to share with a friend, this instantly becomes a must-buy.Grade: B

Posted: December 1, 2013
												Whilst I don't recommend this game what I'm not saying is that F.E.A.R. 3 is a bad game or something you shouldn't spend your money on, but rather that you shouldn't expect to be blown away by what you find here. Picked this game up for the 2 player campaign co-op which I played through over 2-3 sittings (approx 6.5hrs) - during which I found the game to be a hum-drum shooter with uninspired opponents and a story which made zero sense to me. I couldn't follow it. Some co-op mechanics are present but ultimately these are unnecessary and lack the polished execution of say, Left 4 Dead 1/2. Perhaps the biggest let down here is the horror (supposedly this is meant to be a scary game) which is lackluster throughout. The closest thing I can approximate this title to is a Call-of-Duty esque linear shooter without the production value. All this said, it wasn't so terrible we stopped playing - and there is a co-op scene with mechs which is a highlight. Give this one a whirl with a friend to pass some hours - but don't part with too much cash or you will be disappointed.

Posted: December 1, 2013
												F.E.A.R. 3 makes me fear one thing and one thing only: having to play it any more.This game manages to make a generic shooter that is so generic I feel like I'm experiencing perpetual deja vu.Playing the campaign with a friend is, to some degree, fun. I use that term loosely.The idea is simple: here are some guns. There are some soldiers. Every once in a while, you'll see a monster. Shoot them with the guns.I will concede that some people can be scared by FEAR 3, but only those who are scared by jack-in-the-boxes.In co-op, the second player can take over the bodies of enemy soldiers and use various psychic powers, but that basically just means that they spend 5 seconds looking for a body and then return to the generic shooter playstyle.There are very, very few weapons- a rifle, a sniper-rifle, a shotgun, an smg, a pistol, and dual smgs (as far as I can tell. There might have been others, but they all really handle the same.)Enemies are unvaried: There is normal soldier, heavy soldier, sniper soldier, normal monster, knife monster, and exploding monster. Though there are six, you only fight three in most levels.All in all, F.E.A.R. 3 isn't awful, but it's definitely not good.Average Playtime: 5 hours.Price: $20.00$/hour: $4.00/hour.Final Score: 5.0/10Letter Grade: FVerdict: "Worse than mayonnaise."

Posted: September 28, 2014
												While not all that scary, FEAR 3 makes a decent FPS. The gunplay is well done; guns sound heavy and powerful. The pistol alone has a great feel that will make you want to use it over more powerful weapons. The enemy AI is particularly good; soldiers will dive for cover and aggressively flank you, forcing you to change up your tactics instead of camping behind cover and taking potshots. The game isn't all action however, and there are some atmospheric moments in the game that horror fans will appreciate. Once the main campaign is complete, the second character is unlocked, and the game can be played again with him. This actually gives a different gameplay experience because the second character focuses more on psychic abilities as opposed to brute force. The game can also be played through in co-op with a friend, using both characters at the same time. There are also some unique multiplayer modes, but unfortunately seems to be devoid of players.

Posted: September 30, 2014
												This game was a major disapointment, but lets start with the positives. Its multiplayer and player two will have a very unique experience as a ghosty goo that can do all manor of neat tricks other then player 1 who can shoot and slow time. The shooting mechanics is decent, the graphics are decent, the gun selection and balance is... ok.Now for the cons. WEAK WEAK WEAK story telling. First 20 minutes you dont really know whats going on, you rarely know why your doing the things your doing, Fetten the ghost is the only person who talks which doesnt work if your goint to put him and Point Man in a dozen or so cutscenes together, while Point Man stares and grimaces at Fetten and well EVERYTHING else... also Pointman looks like a caveman from a car insurance comercial, you wont care a bit if either of these main characters live or die because they are both uninteresting or in Fettens case ANNOYING. He tries soooo hard to be creepy and scary, most of the dialogue in the game is him... being creepy and trying to be scary. There is nothing scary about the game minus two or three jump scares with an enemy never fully explained and it has an ending that is SURE to leave you eye rolling and disapointed... or if Fetten scores a higher ranking in multiplayer disgusted and♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥at the writers. Level design is terrible, me and my friend got lost often. There's no creepy, scary vibe. It just feels like your playing CoD and your charging through Silent Hill with little regard, stomping over any sloppy attempts to scare or unnerve you, the amature designers tried to catch you with. Alma... she isnt really in the game much. She plays a "pivotal" role in the story... but in the background, off in the details somewhere and it felt like they replaced her with Fetten... the player 2 or dialogue spewing NPC helper to be your creepy scare factor. As I stated how effective that is, it was down right insulting to the original FEAR to see her utilized so♥♥♥♥♥♥poorly. She will sometimes appear to stare at you... and thats it. She doesnt do anything else and its just NOT FEAR.So... if its on sale for 3-5 dollars pick up this game and play with a friend. If its on sale for 6-10 dollars, pass... pass pass pass.

Posted: August 30, 2013
												I don't think any of the reviewers gave this game a fair chance. There's an amazing shooter here, obscured by cheap horror tricks that failed to scare me 2 games ago and the predictable story. Day 1 Studio's take on F.E.A.R. is simply an ultra-gory action romp, and should be taken as such. When that's out of the way, the game's centrepiece comes into focus: the shooting. This is maybe one of the only games that gets the modern shooting model right. The cover system here never feels cheap or clumsy and never becomes a bore because the AI soldiers work in perfect synergy with one another to flank, frag and shoot down any cover you're trying to exploit. The shooting is tight and satisfying and kept at a fast pace because of the regenerating health. In Co-op, this game is just amazing. Pointman's slow motion allows him to take out whole swaths of enemies in between taking cover and perferming satisfying headshots while slowing time, while Fettel is a bad♥♥♥♥♥with the way he jumps into the fray by possessing people and murdering them close-up. There is a pretty deep achievement system here meant to have the two players compete and a levelling system that I've maxed out at level 21. The 4 multiplayer modes are really strong and not what you find in other shooters. In fact, the contractions (horde) mode is actually pretty intense, complete with randomnly generated Alma. A pity they are all dead right now. I've played through the campaign 4 times on increasing difficulties and somehow...the shooting keeps bringing me back.

Posted: August 22, 2014
												This is not a bad game. As someone who doesn't really like First Person Shooters, or ever thought they would, I was entertained by this game for the most part. The cinematic mini-movies and cutscenes were very well done in terms of graphics and art and all that good stuff. Overall the soundtrack was good as well and really heightened the tension...well, where tension was SUPPOSED to be, I suppose.See I probably went "Oh!" in surprise/shock once in the entire game. Once. For a horror game that isn't a very good track record, yes? I feel that, compared to the other games in this series (of which I have seen people do walkthroughs of on YouTube) this one is the weakest in terms of scares and horrors. Of course, if you only played FEAR 3 and didn't play the other games, it wouldn't seem that scary because you haven't really dived into the universe that this story takes place in, with psychic soldiers and a handsome cannibal (cough) and a mute main lead that you control. And of course, Alma.Compared to the other installments this one also felt a little forced and the ending was anticlimactic. Despite dying quite a few times in the beginning and being stuck on where to go, this game went by fast. In terms of the story this series had to tell, this was the "Falling Action --> Denouement" portion of it, which we all know is the quickest-going part of any story, as that's what makes it entertaining, the speed and the tying of everything together.But since this was a separate game, separate from the events that occurred in FEAR and FEAR 2, it feels flat, much like you only read the last few chapters of a book instead of reading the whole thing. I know it's because I haven't played the games in order (ha..haha) but from the very first level there really isn't any...set-up as to why and where and who and how. You just have your mission, you do it, with Fettel snickering and most likely floating by your head with each event (Oh my God shut up I'm doing my damned job alright?!). It's not very strong on character development, at all. We know our players and we know what everyone is capable of so go go go go!! I will say that I very much enjoyed all of the weapons in the game and it made me feel good seeing the little pop-ups of achievements and points being made as I did certain things like killing this many dudes with an SMG or meleeing 30 dudes, etc. I did find the level design to be a little frustrating as well as my jumping abilities. Oh I can jump on THESE boxes but not THESE boxes? Getting stuck is also a small worry I have in the back of my head since sometimes the environment is climbable and other times it's all "♥♥♥♥ your parkour, you ain't going ANYWHERE".So I guess all-in-all this game was a little lackluster compared to the rest of the series which, while not having personally played it, know the capacity of horror and action possible; but if you like shoot-bangs and an awesome slo-mo ability as well as very well-done cutscenes I'd play this if I had nothing to do.

Posted: October 28, 2013
												This wasn't made by Monolith, instead being made by Day 1 Studios who worked on the console ports of the original FEAR titles. Outside the title, slow motion and returning characters from past games (You play as Point Man again) it's FEAR only in name. To begin with there's a two weapon limit, regenerating health, a focus on co-op and almost no horror. This makes it sound like it's a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥but I enjoyed it way more than the second and like it as much as the first FEAR since while it's not the same it has a better idea of what it wants to be than the second title which went for shooting and horror again but wasn't very good at either. It has the most varied and colorful locales in the series, some extremely statisfying combat, good co-op modes and the campaign itself is very good and made better if you play it with a friend. First player controls Point Man who can slow down time like he did in the first game, do fancy melee moves (slidekicking an enemy, entering slow motion and gibbing him with a shotgun blast rules), and ride mechs in certain areas. The second controls Fettel who can possess enemies such as soldiers (who control similar to Point Man but without the slow motion) and other more exotic ones who control differently, he can also just run around in ghost form killing enemies with some weird projectiles he shoots from his hands, or lift enemies into the air for Point Man to shoot if you want to share kills with your partner. Point Man can also do something similar by activating slow motion which will also give the ability to Fettel for as long as he keeps it active. Leaning is back in the form of a cover system that lets you peek around corners and shoot enemies. It works surprisingly well.Expect most of the game to revolve around the combat as there's very little downtime unlike past titles in the series.The co-op modes are the standard Horde mode where you barricade the area you start in similar to COD Zombies, ♥♥♥♥ing Run where you and 3 co-op partners must escape an approaching wall of death by running to the exit while killing enemies that try to slow you down, Soul King which is 4 players with Fettel's abilities trying to possess and kill as many AI enemies as they can, and finally Soul Survivor where one player must turn the rest of their team into monsters while they fend off enemy waves with the last surviving human player being given the option to escape.Like I mentioned above there isn't much horror in the game, there are some randomized scares in each playthrough of the campaign but almost every single one of them consists of things appearing when you open doors for a second then vanishing after the musical stinger plays. The final level is kind of ~~spooky~ the first time but that's about it.In the end it's not FEAR but it's still a pretty good game. I really enjoyed playing through the campaign both online and offline, playing the multiplayer modes and watching the surprisingly well done cutscenes that try to wrap up the mess of a storyline the series has.

Posted: June 26, 2011
												F.E.A.R. 3 is an unusual yet fun installment of the F.E.A.R. series. It is focused on the online aspect so the story of the game is told in a very fragmented and overall poor way, however this doesn't stop the levels from being fun. It reminds me of Modern Warfare 2 more than it does of the previous F.E.A.R. games. Thus, if you hate Modern Warfare you may want to wait until the game is cheaper.F.E.A.R. 3 is longer than other First Person Shooters of this generation. The game has eight levels with four modes of difficulty, with two characters to select from and a scoring system similar to Call of Duty's multiplayer challenges. All of this means that there is a lot of replay value to be had from this game.

Posted: September 30, 2014
												This game was a major disapointment, but lets start with the positives. Its multiplayer and player two will have a very unique experience as a ghosty goo that can do all manor of neat tricks other then player 1 who can shoot and slow time. The shooting mechanics is decent, the graphics are decent, the gun selection and balance is... ok.Now for the cons. WEAK WEAK WEAK story telling. First 20 minutes you dont really know whats going on, you rarely know why your doing the things your doing, Fetten the ghost is the only person who talks which doesnt work if your goint to put him and Point Man in a dozen or so cutscenes together, while Point Man stares and grimaces at Fetten and well EVERYTHING else... also Pointman looks like a caveman from a car insurance comercial, you wont care a bit if either of these main characters live or die because they are both uninteresting or in Fettens case ANNOYING. He tries soooo hard to be creepy and scary, most of the dialogue in the game is him... being creepy and trying to be scary. There is nothing scary about the game minus two or three jump scares with an enemy never fully explained and it has an ending that is SURE to leave you eye rolling and disapointed... or if Fetten scores a higher ranking in multiplayer disgusted and♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥at the writers. Level design is terrible, me and my friend got lost often. There's no creepy, scary vibe. It just feels like your playing CoD and your charging through Silent Hill with little regard, stomping over any sloppy attempts to scare or unnerve you, the amature designers tried to catch you with. Alma... she isnt really in the game much. She plays a "pivotal" role in the story... but in the background, off in the details somewhere and it felt like they replaced her with Fetten... the player 2 or dialogue spewing NPC helper to be your creepy scare factor. As I stated how effective that is, it was down right insulting to the original FEAR to see her utilized so♥♥♥♥♥♥poorly. She will sometimes appear to stare at you... and thats it. She doesnt do anything else and its just NOT FEAR.So... if its on sale for 3-5 dollars pick up this game and play with a friend. If its on sale for 6-10 dollars, pass... pass pass pass.

Moments in the first game left me scared and shocked and left with an adreniline rush, I felt fear for my avatar as I was running around wtih him in part one, Fear 3 however, I could really care less if my character dies (which I think is a casuality of having a game that automatically saves at check points vs requiring you to choose when to save). 6/10

Posted: June 17, 2012
												Game is fun especially with the addition of coop to the F.E.A.R. series, however it is a VERY short game that could be beaten in a single setting assuming you have 3 or 4 hours of free time.  The ending which is determined by who has more points at the end of the game whether you played as Point Man or Fettel  (assuming you aren't playing single player) is another nice addition turning the friendly coop into a competition.  The game dives back into the origin of Alma's two sons and explains what they went through while growing up in a ward and how their abilities were acquired.  The multiplayer aspect is subpar but really where this game shines is with the coop.  I bought it on sale for $8 and honestly I wouldn't pay more than that for this game.  Not saying the game is bad, just saying that for $20, there are better choices to spend your money on.

Posted: October 21, 2014
												F.E.A.R. 3 is a game with an identity crisis. The gunplay is fun, the score attack system is actually pretty engaging, and the asymmetrical co-op is interesting, but it's just not very scary.It tries to be, doing little spooky bits where Alma just shows up, but there's not too much there. Granted, I'm glad they didn't go "Jump Scare!" constantly, but there never was a feeling of dread when I was going around like a walking armory. The campaign itself is laughably short. Which is sad because, again, the feel of the guns are fantastic. Fettel's mode of body-hopping kind of calls for a run-and-gun style that is pretty enjoyable. I didn't check multiplayer, but I tried the horde mode on my own. It's fun since it boils it down to strictly the gunplay, but it would sorely require a friend or two.Comparing to the original FEAR, it's kind of strange. Once again, you're not too worried about ghosts since you're armed to the teeth, but the use of a fantastic lighting engine and robust AI makes this game look really dull. I don't know if I'd recommend this to fans of the original, or newcomers to the franchise. After every praise I think of for this game, it follows, "but it's just not scary." Certainly don't check this out to get spooked. At the very least I would say if you're looking for an interesting Cooperative game you could do far worse. Otherwise, just go play the first FEAR.

												77 minutes into the game and I just uninstalled it... what a waste of money and time.Where should I start? 												 am about done with this game. It has been fun. The graphics are very good, the sound is better than that. I have never liked games without real save game systems. 												Excellent game 8/10, it plays smooth (played on an AMD fx 6300 CPU and GTX 970 SC EVGA GPU) and doesn't bug out. Its still gory and creepy, and still gives you that scare.  However its different compared to the last 2 games. Its implemented multiplayer mechanics into the single player campaign (collecting items for points, leveling up and receiving perks for it, ETC). 												Very fun and decently violent game. The game was interesting but if you're looking for the old scare factor that the FEAR series offers, then you're looking at the wrong game. This more or less turned into a cooperative shooter with the occasional predictable jump scares of Alma. I will admit thought it was a really interesting game and I was actually really invested into the story of the brothers and mother. Posted: October 30, 2015
												This game deviates from everything that made the original FEAR and it's expansions great. It includes regenerating health, cover system, extremely weak AI compared to the original, and I can't do my favorite thing anymore. That is kung foo replica soldiers to death. All of the fun has been stripped out to and replaced with call of duty elements in an effort to stay relevant, your melee attack is even a knife swing. But the FEAR series didnt need to buy into these tropes the gameplay in the first two was tense and had consequences. You were the ultimate bad♥♥♥♥♥but you had to think and use all the tools available to defeat the smart AI. Levels in the original have branching path ways and felt like real places with boosters to collect to make your health and reflexes better. Now we have a market point system that breaks the immersion of the game as an excuse to have customization. Varying enemy types had a heavier pressence in a battle, HEavy troopers would come through the wall while grunts out flank you. Now we have wave after wave of dumb always reacting the same soldiers. In every firefight i could run right up to the enemies with a shotgun and shoot them. It doesnt matter how much damage I take because I wont take enough to die and it regenerates anyway. Plus I have slo mo which is just a cop out in this game. Sometimes there are a few supernatural monsters thrown in, but it's all forced. I believe that during the production meetings they developed all of the shooter elements and while making the horror someone said, "Just throw some scary crap in there. The game is called FEAR right?". So sorry to say but FEAR 3 is lame, buy the original and its expansions Extraction Point and Perseus Mandate, for shooters that actually feel good to play.

Posted: April 24, 2014
												Sorry F.E.A.R. fans, and sorry for myself :(Remembering FEAR 2 goes back in time, FEAR 3 episode goes Forward in the story again.Acording to the story events: FEAR 2 > FEAR (and expansions) > FEAR 3Just like any blockbuster, this game lives out of the previous successes. I have seen many bad reviews, unfortunatly they were all well fundamented. The story goes around the "Weird Family", just like any cheap TV show, now formed by: Alma the♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off dead Mum, her violent sons (we can play both), her new GI-Joe-boyfriend, and her new baby (Good Job Mr. GI Joe!!)Ok.. lets skip for goodies and badies..[Goodies]- Being able to replay the game with both brothers and use tactics according to their skills- Some visual improvement over FEAR 2 (but not much)- Some interesting "bosses" and get to drive a mech again =)[So so]AI: The AI looks ok, sometimes they move and change hideouts. I think FEAR 1 and 2 had a lot more fun AI. This ones just hide too much. They are predictable and we can be confident nothing fancy will happen. They do behave more realistic because I also wouldnt go out of the hideout if I was watching all my friends die =)[Badies]Where am I supposed to get chills and jump from my chair? It DID happenen in the other episodes. This game moves out of the thing that made it so interesting. Creepy stuff that wouldn't stop surprising me ( aka "gotta-change-pants-again factor")Sound: You dont know how I missed the comments from the enemies, full of courage or.. desperating in fear. In FEAR 3 they just say the same GI-Joe stuff through the whole game without any emotion.[Horrible!]Last the not least, the main reason for the score..I expected to play an FPS-creppy game and I was presented with a HUD full of fancy cheerful RPG stuff.Please keep the "Mission Score", "Found Items", "Play Style scores", "Achievements for shooting", "Achievements for camping".. bla bla bla FOR YOURSELF! Just give me a damn creepy game.Believe me, its hard to jump out of my chair at the same time a pop-up saying something like "CONGRATS! YOU'RE RANK IS NOW PIKACHU 7" comes on the screen. But despite falling behind in the FEAR series, its still a nice shooter.PlayTime: 13 hours (As pointman) + 1 hour (a few speedy levels with Fettel)Score: 6 / 10

Posted: May 25, 2013
												Its quite sad to see how the infamous F.E.A.R series degenerated to such mediocrity with this entry into the franchise. This game is like the movie equivalent of "Matrix Reloaded + Matrix Revolutions" which killed the Matrix series. Yes, its that bad.The third entry into the series, it tells a story of 2 brothers who is working together to re-unite with Alma, the main antagonist of the F.E.A.R series. The entire very short 5 hours story is forgettable and an extremely poor follow-up considering how powerful and thought provoking the ending of F.E.A.R 2 was.Its a very average FPS and the only interesting thing is the character Fettel who can assimilate into enemies. Level and graphic designs are very uninspired. The graphic even manage to look worse then Fear 2 which is an achievement in itself. Enemy types are also recycled (you keep seeing the same human soldiers over and over again) and the whole thing just feels very dated.There are even sequences where they put you into Mechs and you go around blasting stuff, which IMO should have been cut. as it somehow just doesn't feel like a proper F.E.A.R game with robots blasting around the place.Compared to the first 2 games in the series, the whole scare factor is just non-existent. Unless something drastic is done about it, this franchise will probably die with this game.I really want to like this game, but i am angry and jarateed off at how low the series has sunk with Fear 3. The developers should be ashamed of themselves for producing this game.Overall Rating: 3.5 / 10Unless you are a die-hard fan and wants to know how the series ends, don't waste your money on this game.

												I barely played it and don't think I'll finish it. The game is far different from the first, and can't even match the second one. They made the gameplay easy, enemies unrealistic and ridiculous, and the story doesn't even follow suit. There's co-op if you're into that, but it's like race to the finish instead of a challenge. The guns sound like .22 rounds and the shotgun can't even aim down sights. Even more so you're limited to only two guns. They try to give you ridiculous objectives to involve the point system and they are completely meaningless. Not only that the achievements are just terrible. You can lean over cover but you have to press a key to leave the cover, which can get you stuck if you try to leave and get blasted with bullets. The worst part? A girl shows up every once in a while to say hello, and tries to scare you, but just smears blood everywhere.Verdict: 4/10, this game needs revision. Highly recommend you replay the original F.E.A.R and the add ons for the real enjoyment.

Posted: July 12, 2014
												I had a negative review of this game for a long time... having replayed it I'm changing my mind.I hate this game for the sin of not being FEAR 2. As sequels go this is terrible. It brings nothing of the tension or atmosphere that gripped me throughout the astonishingly brilliant FEAR 2... it then uses achievements constantly popping onto the screen in bright colours to kill any residual tension or psychological edge it might have. Which is all extremely irritating and disappointing in comparison to the game it is meant to be surplanting.BUT...Forget that this is meant to be part of the FEAR franchise and assume it's an action FPS not a thriller/horror and suddenly the game looks a hell of a lot better.The gameplay is fantastic with a nice variety of enemies and locations. The weapons have all the standard options (done well) and a couple of nice exotics. The 2 main characters play incredibly different and can give the solo campaign a totally different feel and then you've got the co-op campaign with all the complexities that can bring.I'm still♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥this isn't an excellent game like it should have been... but its still very good.

Posted: October 14, 2015
												I rate the game F.E.A.R. 3 4/5. Good.This is a fairly impressive FPS game which is designed to be played either as a single player game or entirely as a co-operative game. The plot supports the co-op mode very, very well. While it has some detractors, there is far more to like about this action game than to dislike if you don't mind incredibly violent, occasionally creepy, generally dark games which focus on the family histories of psychotic telepaths.+Wraps up the previous two FEAR games (and the add-ons for each) very, very well with nearly no loose ends while still leaving the way open for yet another sequel if anyone cares to bother to create one without feeling like it has a cliff-hanger ending.+While generally this is not a very creepy game (just bloody and horrific) the game does have its moments (particularly picking your way through the haunted houses in the suburbia section of the game).+The sound and the use of the sound, from the ambient sounds of creaking wood or running feet in another room to the loud gunshots are almost uniformly outstanding. Only the grenades and explosions seemed a little muffled.+Good voice acting though enemies often did end up saying fairly repetitive things during combat and one soldier often sounded like another.+Great between level movie scenes.+Interesting (though often disjointed feeling) plot.+Outstanding and shockingly impressive graphics (the bullet time mode and effects is very well done) Great lighting effects and use of shadows as well.+The two playable characters have interesting and different abilities (but playing as the Ghostly Fettel is much, much easier than playing as the flesh and blood Point Man).+Interesting and varied environments.+This game's plot causes all of the add-on packs to become canonical.+Highly replayable game with two different endings (depending on which character you use and/or if playing in cooperative multiplayer mode, who did better on all of the previous missions. FEAR 3 is Possibly one of the best cooperative FPS gaming experiences ever designed.+Excellent enemy AI and enemy variety.+Outstanding Mech battle sequences.+Your character can only pick up two guns at a time and 3 grenades of each of the 3 types causing for much more intense combat situations and requiring you to make more complex tactical choices.+Excellent controls which support five-button gaming mice.+/- Incredibly violent (and playing one of the character's this violence will often be seen in slow bullet-time motion in painfully exquisite detail. Definitely not a good game for the weak minded or easily influenced or previously disturbed. This game contains particularly disturbing situations and images throughout.-Not extremely creepy throughout. Mostly just bloody and horrific.-This game could have used longer between level cutscenes to flesh out the plot further.-Uneven difficulty. The game is fairly difficult for the point man character but much, much easier for the ghostly Fettel character.-In single player mode the other character vanishes (which, in terms of the plot, makes some sense if you are playing the flesh and blood character but not so well if you are playing the ghost). The game should have included an AI controlled character to assist you when in the playing single player mode to stand-in for an actual person particularly as the game's design and difficulty seems to occasionally forget that you might be playing the game by yourself causing some battle situations to be extremely difficult and possibly even frustrating even on the easier (recruit) difficulty.-The plot will be difficult for newcomers to understand. This game's plot does a very poor job of standing on its own and is clearly intended for those who had played not just the first two games but possibly all of the add-on packs as well.-Relatively short game with only 2 endings.-Fairly linear gameplay and level design. The mech battle sequences, while well done and very atmospheric are particularly linear.-This game has irritating HUD indicators. Text telling you to reload if your clip is not totally full. Stupid on-screen crosshairs that you cannot turn off.-Mediocre music throughout which succeeds only in setting the right tone but fails to be truly catchy or very interesting.

Posted: June 18, 2012
												I love the Fear series, and this game...well it does things quite differently. First off, there's co-op, and without a doubt that makes the experience in this game much better. You're working together with your friend as well as against, competing for your character's respective ending. The combat's quite different, especially with the inclusion of Fettel, the "ghost" you can play as, and brother to the main character. The story doesn't take very long to complete, so I'd suggest waiting to get this game at a discount price. And heck, then you can get the game as a "two-for-the-price-of-one" deal, maybe even cheaper than the current set price if you're lucky. It's one of those co-op games, so grab a buddy and enjoy!

												This game far exceeded my expectations. It delivers in almost every category where FEAR 1 and 2 shined. The only exception is the length of the campaign, which is comparatively shorter. The coop campaign mode is very fun and very well balanced. The multiplayer adds refreshing new dynamics to the game while also adding new and unique feelings of suspense. One mode in particular, called "F****ing Run!" is nothing short of a constant adrenaline rush. Fear 3 easily earns a 9 out of 10 in my book.Note: I edited this recommendation in response to a major patch.

Posted: September 27, 2013
												Like the other fear titles F3AR is showing it's age but still provides solid fun. The graphics are a little muddy in places and the engine groans under the weight of the poor outdoor sections. Having said that as with the first two games enviromental design, particularly the interiors, and the art direction is fantastic leading to some truly unique locales and great lighting. The combat is fast paced and fun but seldom rises above the average shooter tropes. Enemies like to flank you and use grenades which is a nice change from the increasingly banal pop up targets of the COD genre.  The story is a little ridiculous at this point and if you are considering by a game for plot then you probably want to look elsewhere. Overall F3AR is a good game that treads the fine line between average and exciting and falls towards the former a little too often. Pick it up if it's a rainy weekend and you want a little bit of mindless shooting fun. 7/10

Posted: November 25, 2013
												F.E.A.R 3 is a game I got in a pack from the Humble Bundle and is the first of the series I have actually completed, this review will focus mostly on a co-op playthrough experience. I'll start with the positives, since there aren't many. Firstly, the Fettel (Ghost guy) character had some interesting powers and I thought it made him a little different to the Point Man character, which was good to make the experience a little different for each player. Secondly, the Mechs were fun to run around in for the little while you really had to use them. Now, on to the negative aspects. The game is incredibly repetitive, tossing the same enemies at you level after level, having very little weapon variety among other things. Another aspect which didn't work as intended was the cover system, as enemies seem to be able to hit you from behind the "cover" you can take with a key press, making it a useless option to even have within the game. The final negative point I need to bring up is the lack of horror, the game contains no real "scary" moments at all, making little to no attempt to include some of the creepy atmosphere you might have found in older F.E.A.R games. Overall, I'd say to give this game a miss. Its around six hours (on nightmare difficulty) of repetitive timewasting, with little to no redeeming factors or unique features. If you are looking for a horror game, try the older F.E.A.R games, if you are looking for an FPS game, there are plenty of better examples, if you are looking for a co-op game, try something like Borderlands 2 or a gamemode for Garry's Mod.

Posted: August 30, 2013
												I don't think any of the reviewers gave this game a fair chance. There's an amazing shooter here, obscured by cheap horror tricks that failed to scare me 2 games ago and the predictable story. Day 1 Studio's take on F.E.A.R. is simply an ultra-gory action romp, and should be taken as such. When that's out of the way, the game's centrepiece comes into focus: the shooting. This is maybe one of the only games that gets the modern shooting model right. The cover system here never feels cheap or clumsy and never becomes a bore because the AI soldiers work in perfect synergy with one another to flank, frag and shoot down any cover you're trying to exploit. The shooting is tight and satisfying and kept at a fast pace because of the regenerating health. In Co-op, this game is just amazing. Pointman's slow motion allows him to take out whole swaths of enemies in between taking cover and perferming satisfying headshots while slowing time, while Fettel is a bad♥♥♥♥♥with the way he jumps into the fray by possessing people and murdering them close-up. There is a pretty deep achievement system here meant to have the two players compete and a levelling system that I've maxed out at level 21. The 4 multiplayer modes are really strong and not what you find in other shooters. In fact, the contractions (horde) mode is actually pretty intense, complete with randomnly generated Alma. A pity they are all dead right now. I've played through the campaign 4 times on increasing difficulties and somehow...the shooting keeps bringing me back.

												77 minutes into the game and I just uninstalled it... what a waste of money and time.Where should I start? The game wouldn't launch.. so I had to search Google to find out that it has issues with DX11 and since it tries to launch with that enabled (no option anywhere to disable it), I had to manually find some switches and use those to launch in DX9....only to be greeted by a horrible narrow FOV (field of view), which on my 24" 1920x1200 monitor looks like you are seeing the world through binoculars....Again I found a "somewhat" fix with another launcher switch which supposedly fixed the issue.... it was better but still....Then the gaming mechanics are horrible. Dare I say worse than FEAR 2 or even 1.Sure the graphics are a bit better, but at the end of the day, this is more of a "demo" with a story behind it, rather than an interactive game.Shallow shallow shallow.... I really enjoyed FEAR 1 & 2 but this one is a big disappointment.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												Pretty silly and unsubtle but I played it with my wife and it's actually a very good co-op game. You can play the whole main campaign with a friend and each character has unique abilities that compliment each other, encouraging strategic collaboration and communication between partners. Of course it's impossible to have an impactful horror atmosphere when you're spending time with a buddy but if you adjust your expectations accordingly it's a good shooter and action game.I played the first game but didn't spend significant time with the second, but this was enough to help me appreciate where the story was coming from. That being said, you don't really have to play the previous games and can jump right into this one.I can't speak to the solo game but I imagine it's not as enjoyable as co-op. Get this and play with a friend for maximum enjoyment. It's one of the better co-op shooters you will find.

Posted: May 30, 2014
												I've come to this sequel right after finishing FEAR 2, and, having read a lot of negative reviews, had low expectations. Fortunately, it's been a positive surprise so far, in light of that. No, it's not scary at all, that's true -- so real hardcore fans of the previous episodes may very well feel disappointed --, but it's quite an okay shooter/action game with its own little twists and a distinct, intriguingly dark mood. Let me repeat: it won't scare you, but if you're willing to go along, you'll get immersed. I also think I can appreciate how a new team of developers (afaik) managed to add their own to the story and to the world as well. Because there's a strong connection indeed.As some said, it's a solid game - it won't turn your world upside down, it won't give you what the previous episodes did, but it's definitely fun. (Especially if you manage to fix the initial resolution issue, which is a terrible bug indeed. I had to use a hexa editor and manually tweak certain files to get the game display properly on my screen.)

Posted: June 29, 2013
												The skinny: FEAR 3 is superior to FEAR 2 in just about every way. Much better gunplay. nicer level design and a better story. Is it a great game? No, not quite. Your enemies are still too bullet spongey and the creatures that come out of the walls might be some of the most annoying in gaming history. Some of the mini boss fights can be frustrating and the aim of the game is still to go from Point A to Pointt B. There is some replay value as once you finish the game with the Point Man, you can replay the game as Paxton Fettel. Or you can play co-op with one player as Point Man and the other as Fettel. That's a great option to have. All in all I'd definitely recommend FEAR 3. If you can get this in the $5 range (which it has been before) or preferably  with the rest of the FEAR series for around $14 you'll get a lot of bang for your buck. 8/10 from me.

Posted: September 23, 2016
												If you haven't played the first two games in the series before thins one, play those first and play this one if you really want to see the ending.I enjoyed F.3.A.R, but not as a FEAR game. It's a fun shooter, but the horror is lacklustre, the story's muddled and the AI is dumb.The upshot of this game is the ability to play it in multiplayer, either in challenges and things or as a coop/competetive campaign. This was a really nice addition, but it still doesn't really fit in a FEAR game.I can't think of anything in the first two F.E.A.R games that really made no sense or wasn't explained through the collectible lore drops or the story, In F.3.A.R a lot of stuff goes unexplained. There are points in the game where normal enemy soldiers, rather than walk in, or get airlifted in or something like that, they literally walk out of walls or are formed from lightning, with no explanation apart from some crap about "but psychics".Moreover I just found the enemies in F.3.A.R. just aren't as interesting as in the previous games, There's a recurring antagonist in the game referred to only as The Creep, how or why The Creep is in the form he takes is never explained, and virtually contradicts the previous two games A whole bunch of aspects in F.3.A.R. just seem to contradict the first two games' story, albeit sometime only the inferred story. in the first two games the actions of the character's are somewhat justified, whereas in F.3.A.R. the motivation is hard to see. Pros Fun gun-playNeat atmosphereLooks good, though somewhat dated nowFun multiplayer game optionsMech levels allow for on foot progression for those who desire a challenge Cons Horror relies on jumpscares many of which fall flatStory is a bit of a messNot a huge amount of enemy variationScrew those cultist enemies, numerous and bland Doesn't feel like a FEAR gameIt's a pretty good game, worth getting on sale or if you just want to see how the story ends, or if you want a good shooter.If you want a great FEAR game go replay one of the first two.

Posted: April 4, 2014
												I played this game because I was in the mood for some scares, but ended up with a bunch of feels that I didn't know what to do with.Honestly, I see a lot of people poo-pooing this game for having a bad plot, messing up the series, blah dee blah...But I absolutely loved it.The strange love/hate relationship between the two brothers is something I found to be very tragic and engaging. Unlike the past two games, this one humanized Alma and Paxton to the point where I actually sympathized with them, and the final scenes (both "good" and "bad") left me torn. Both brothers have been deeply wronged, and it was fascinating how each one dealt with their past... With Paxton choosing vengeance no matter the cost, and Point Man choosing to not give up on mankind, which in turn gave way to mercy.Maybe I'm just a sap, but this game is going to stick with me for a long time.

Posted: April 24, 2014
												Sorry F.E.A.R. fans, and sorry for myself :(Remembering FEAR 2 goes back in time, FEAR 3 episode goes Forward in the story again.Acording to the story events: FEAR 2 > FEAR (and expansions) > FEAR 3Just like any blockbuster, this game lives out of the previous successes. I have seen many bad reviews, unfortunatly they were all well fundamented. The story goes around the "Weird Family", just like any cheap TV show, now formed by: Alma the♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off dead Mum, her violent sons (we can play both), her new GI-Joe-boyfriend, and her new baby (Good Job Mr. GI Joe!!)Ok.. lets skip for goodies and badies..[Goodies]- Being able to replay the game with both brothers and use tactics according to their skills- Some visual improvement over FEAR 2 (but not much)- Some interesting "bosses" and get to drive a mech again =)[So so]AI: The AI looks ok, sometimes they move and change hideouts. I think FEAR 1 and 2 had a lot more fun AI. This ones just hide too much. They are predictable and we can be confident nothing fancy will happen. They do behave more realistic because I also wouldnt go out of the hideout if I was watching all my friends die =)[Badies]Where am I supposed to get chills and jump from my chair? It DID happenen in the other episodes. This game moves out of the thing that made it so interesting. Creepy stuff that wouldn't stop surprising me ( aka "gotta-change-pants-again factor")Sound: You dont know how I missed the comments from the enemies, full of courage or.. desperating in fear. In FEAR 3 they just say the same GI-Joe stuff through the whole game without any emotion.[Horrible!]Last the not least, the main reason for the score..I expected to play an FPS-creppy game and I was presented with a HUD full of fancy cheerful RPG stuff.Please keep the "Mission Score", "Found Items", "Play Style scores", "Achievements for shooting", "Achievements for camping".. bla bla bla FOR YOURSELF! Just give me a damn creepy game.Believe me, its hard to jump out of my chair at the same time a pop-up saying something like "CONGRATS! YOU'RE RANK IS NOW PIKACHU 7" comes on the screen. But despite falling behind in the FEAR series, its still a nice shooter.PlayTime: 13 hours (As pointman) + 1 hour (a few speedy levels with Fettel)Score: 6 / 10

Posted: October 4, 2015
												F.E.A.R. 3 follows directly after F.E.A.R. 2 but has very little of a connection to F.E.A.R. 1 since certain events never happened due to the Monolith and Vivendi timeline of F.E.A.R. being a bit different. In short, it's two different story lines, but none the less a good idea to play the predecessors in order to have an idea of what is going on in the game. The developers did an excellent job when it came to playability. I've spent hours playing this game over and over again, doing achievement hunting and completing the game in Co-Op mode (probably the best feature) with my friends. The greatest disappointment (in my opinion) is that fact that they moved away from the horror elements of the game. Don't get me wrong, there are a couple of scares in the game, but it's not nearly as intense as its predecessors. This shouldn't discourage you to play the game, because what lacks in horror the game makes up for in playability. A few multiplayer modes have been added that makes it so much fun to play. Like its predecessors, I highly recommend that you give this a shot, it's a great game with a great story line!

Posted: July 22, 2012
												A guilty pleasureThis manages to stand next to Mass Effect 3 for the worst ending in a "trilogy" series. Story-wise it's horribly written and leaves more questions than answers about Pointman, Fettel, and especially Alma. A sloppy mess.Now the GAME is fun. Although it has "we want call of duty's audience" written all over with with brown&bloom, ranking up, and crosshair hit confirmation... it still manages to be even more fast-paced than the first two without deviating from its roots. The campaign is best designed for co-op, so grab a buddy (or me) and have a blast.You can play one of two characters: Pointman and Fettel. Pointman plays as every FEAR game before, carrying an armory on his back and having bullet-time at will. Fettel is REALLY fun playing as a blood mage ghost sort of deal. You have precise shotgun blood-blasts, an enemy hold, a channeled shield for Pointman, and you can posess the bodies of enemies to fight ala-pointman style.

Posted: October 14, 2015
												I rate the game F.E.A.R. 3 4/5. Good.This is a fairly impressive FPS game which is designed to be played either as a single player game or entirely as a co-operative game. The plot supports the co-op mode very, very well. While it has some detractors, there is far more to like about this action game than to dislike if you don't mind incredibly violent, occasionally creepy, generally dark games which focus on the family histories of psychotic telepaths.+Wraps up the previous two FEAR games (and the add-ons for each) very, very well with nearly no loose ends while still leaving the way open for yet another sequel if anyone cares to bother to create one without feeling like it has a cliff-hanger ending.+While generally this is not a very creepy game (just bloody and horrific) the game does have its moments (particularly picking your way through the haunted houses in the suburbia section of the game).+The sound and the use of the sound, from the ambient sounds of creaking wood or running feet in another room to the loud gunshots are almost uniformly outstanding. Only the grenades and explosions seemed a little muffled.+Good voice acting though enemies often did end up saying fairly repetitive things during combat and one soldier often sounded like another.+Great between level movie scenes.+Interesting (though often disjointed feeling) plot.+Outstanding and shockingly impressive graphics (the bullet time mode and effects is very well done) Great lighting effects and use of shadows as well.+The two playable characters have interesting and different abilities (but playing as the Ghostly Fettel is much, much easier than playing as the flesh and blood Point Man).+Interesting and varied environments.+This game's plot causes all of the add-on packs to become canonical.+Highly replayable game with two different endings (depending on which character you use and/or if playing in cooperative multiplayer mode, who did better on all of the previous missions. FEAR 3 is Possibly one of the best cooperative FPS gaming experiences ever designed.+Excellent enemy AI and enemy variety.+Outstanding Mech battle sequences.+Your character can only pick up two guns at a time and 3 grenades of each of the 3 types causing for much more intense combat situations and requiring you to make more complex tactical choices.+Excellent controls which support five-button gaming mice.+/- Incredibly violent (and playing one of the character's this violence will often be seen in slow bullet-time motion in painfully exquisite detail. Definitely not a good game for the weak minded or easily influenced or previously disturbed. This game contains particularly disturbing situations and images throughout.-Not extremely creepy throughout. Mostly just bloody and horrific.-This game could have used longer between level cutscenes to flesh out the plot further.-Uneven difficulty. The game is fairly difficult for the point man character but much, much easier for the ghostly Fettel character.-In single player mode the other character vanishes (which, in terms of the plot, makes some sense if you are playing the flesh and blood character but not so well if you are playing the ghost). The game should have included an AI controlled character to assist you when in the playing single player mode to stand-in for an actual person particularly as the game's design and difficulty seems to occasionally forget that you might be playing the game by yourself causing some battle situations to be extremely difficult and possibly even frustrating even on the easier (recruit) difficulty.-The plot will be difficult for newcomers to understand. This game's plot does a very poor job of standing on its own and is clearly intended for those who had played not just the first two games but possibly all of the add-on packs as well.-Relatively short game with only 2 endings.-Fairly linear gameplay and level design. The mech battle sequences, while well done and very atmospheric are particularly linear.-This game has irritating HUD indicators. Text telling you to reload if your clip is not totally full. Stupid on-screen crosshairs that you cannot turn off.-Mediocre music throughout which succeeds only in setting the right tone but fails to be truly catchy or very interesting.

Posted: January 31, 2015
												I enjoyed FEAR, FEAR Extraction Point and FEAR 2: Project Origin (even if Project Origin was rather short it didn't stop me enjoying the 6 hours of gameplay I went through) so when I started seeing the negative comments and reviews for FEAR 3 I was some what confused as to how bad the game could be. As it turns out, all of these negative reviews have very very good points. I've literally just finished the first interval of this game and I can already see major flaws in gameplay which take away points for this franchise.NEGATIVE POINTS-AI are dumber than door nailsAt points in the first mission I witnessed at least several cases of incompitant AI. The shotgunners rush your position constantly and won't stop, not even to take cover, until either you drop or they do. AI seem adamant to hug every damn grenade thrown their way with some AI going as far as to throw grenades at themselves and not give two s*its. AI seem to like shooting at indestructable objects such as CHAIN LINK FENCES(?) and BULLET PROOF WINDOWS that you are behind. For me this made all enemies which I came accross turn into nothing but moving targets which took away most of the fun in the game for me.-Jump ScaresYep...Good ol' jump scares (sarcasm). FEAR and FEAR Extraction point earned their name sake by creating a very tense, suspension filled and dark atmosphere almost all the way throughout the game with minimal jump scares. For me, I prefer the atmosphere in anything to do with horror whether it's a horror movie or a horror game, atmosphere is what I want not some generic sudden appearance of a supernatural force followed by a loud sound effect. I want to feel genuinley scared or on edge during a horror experience. I want adrenaline to be coursing through my body at every interval during this game but that's not going to happen thanks to just five seconds of the screen going dark and Alma walking around with whispers in the background.-Regenerating HealthRegenerating health is not usually a problem for me as long as health regeneration is balanced for the style of gameplay like after an area is cleared of enemies health can then regenerate at a slow pace and this only applies if regenerating health is in place throught any previous games of the same franchise. In this case however FEAR 3 absolutely ruins the difficulty in this game by having a fast paced regenerating health system during combat.-XP and Ranking system...in a linear single player Story modeXP and ranking is fine for online play or in a open world sandbox style game such as TES:5, FALLOUT 3/NV or Borderlands and Mass Effect but having a linear story mode with an XP/Ranking system? Not even the Call of Duty franchise has implemented something that stupid and useless in their campaigns...and their campaigns since after World at War were♥♥♥♥♥♥ You have to unlock abilities with ranking up which the Point Man should already have from the first game...-Only two weapon slotsHaving only two weapon slots is such a disadvantage in a FEAR game as ammo is usually found in very small amounts on corpses and in little supply crates. Not only is ammo an issue but what if you decide to swap out empty heavy weapons for weapons like the pistol and submachine gun which have ammo and you have to fight some big bad Mutha F*cker with heavy armor and weapons which small arms are nothing but a damn tickle to him? You're going to get wrecked because you have only two weapons which do nothing and yet on FEAR and FEAR 2 you could just pull a missile launcher out your a*s and keep those weapons with ammo tucked safely between your butt cheeks whilst you just destroy the guy.POSITIVE POINTS-It gave me something to do for 20 or so minutesNow with all these problems (which are problems that I personally find annoying) that I found in the first damn interval, I have now just completely given up on playing the rest of the game.

Posted: December 29, 2014
												This game hasn't really improved upon F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin but is still a fun game to play. You basically play as Point Man, whom was the protagonist in the first F.E.A.R. game that was considered to be the best shooter of 2005. This game starts off by you being tortured in a jail cell by two gaurds and you have to escape to find Jin Sun Kwon. Here's where the plot problems come into play. The game doesn't tell you where or how you got to where you started, it just puts you there out of the blue, with no relation whatsoever to extraction point.The gameplay is like a basic first-person shooter with mechanics such as taking cover and jumping over obstacles. It's good but I hardly used it at all since how that controls is just hard to get used to. You also posses bullet time which allows you to slow down time and shoot at enemies much quicker and easier. This makes the game realitvly easy in the beginning but you will be greatful that you have it since the game gets realitvly hard and frustrating near the end.The major complaint I had with this game was that the game's difficulty is completly unfair when playing solo. Here's what I mean by that: When you have to fight the two commanders near the end of the second last level, you will die probably 10-20 times at least untill one of them gets hung up on the wall while you kill the other. Seriously if it wasn't for that I would be stuck here still trying to beat that part; it's just impossible.It's not a very good game but it's still a good game so I would still recommend you play this.
