Posted: December 14, 2014
												I've always been a fan of the Fear games. While their gameplay wasn't the best, it was still highly entertaining and had just enough horror to keep me shaking in my booties.Fear 3 takes a step into a deep dark part of the gaming world, co-op. For a Horror game, co-op ultimately ruins the tension in the game. Is this true for Fear 3? Ha, there was little horror left in the game other than the obvious jump scares and random moving chairs. Fear 3 is BARELY a horror game. It's more of a creepy looking game with gore and guns.But the strange thing is... I like it. I enjoyed running around wrecking my enemies. They never stood a GHOST of a chance! (That there is a Paxton Fettel joke... because he is dead) While I enjoyed the game, playing single player alone just didn't cut it for me. It wasn't worth spending the money on it at that point. However, co-op is where I was sold on this game.In co-op one person takes on the mute, bullet dodging hitman called... Point man (yeah screw good names!) and the other takes on the role of the invulnerable ghost of Paxton Fettel. Point man can basically bullet time his way around the place while Paxton, being the what is basically the most powerful psychic person in this universe, can take over bodies at will and have a taste of what it is like being a weak Point Man. Now I know this sounds kind of terrible but playing as Paxton gives you so many options. You can be a great support for Point Man. You can outright blast enemies or take them over as your temporary body. Now staying within the body is not forever and you will have to get another but until then, enjoy the shoot 'em up. While you would think being Point man sucks, it does have it's high points. You easily can get mechs, powersuits and other cool gadgets to take over and run wild in. (Paxton can get them as well by the way but he might bleed out before getting into one)Working as a team and dealing with all of the different difficult enemies thrown your way is really crazy fun. I enjoyed the feel of the weapons and how enemies reacted. You blast an enemy with a shotgun and he either gets knocked back or becomes bits. Shooting limbs and heads feel really good in the game, if not very rewarding.There is collectables that are actually important as well! You basically get these to increase the time in which you can either be in slow motion or take over a body.Now the story is forgettable at best as, I only remember the "Brother" jokes I was making as I pointed to my forehead (Again, another Paxton joke). Still, of what story there is, there is some seriously WTH moments in the game. And an ending you will literally fight over.As a co-op and a thinly lined multiplayer experience, I can recommend this game as cheap fun. As a single player experience, you really must be wanting to shoot something to come here for it.Co-op is 8 Paxtons out of 10.Single Player is 6 slowmotion punches out of 10Multiplayer is 7 Almas out of 10.Pick it up cheap and you will have no fears.

												If you play this game, please play it with a friend.  It was FANTASTIC to play it with someone I know.  The game is quite short if you go straight through the campaign (5-6 hours), so I would recommend getting it on sale.  This game has jump scares, it has camp, it has a terrible pun.  It was SO FUN that I have a new love for the F.E.A.R. series.  I was cracking up throughout the game on voice chat with my friend.  If you play it with someone you know, I think it has some good replayability.The co-op is alot of fun!  Very different play styles depending on if you are Point Man or Fettel.  There are also opportunities to compliment one another as well as opportunities to compete against each other.  Seriously, I had a great time with this game.

Posted: July 3, 2011
												What's great is that you get to play as Fettel. Assuming the role of Point Man gets you a fun fast-paced shooter with unalienable slo-mo. But playing as Fettel nets you the ability to possess enemies, and when they expire - they explode in a burst of blood!The game's length is on the shorter end of the spectrum, but on the bright side - you can finish the whole thing in co-op mode in a single afternoon. Additionally, the co-op mode is a great boost to the replay value.This game as not as creepy-scary as the original, and I started to get skeptical about the amount of scares - until I started interval 4 (the suburbs). This interval alone is worth the money in my opinion; that was the best of classic FEAR!The controls are very convenient, enabling the player to assign the same key to mutually-exclusive actions (for the most part). Audio is solid; soundtrack is non-invasive and at times feels very right for the circumstances.To sum it up, this game is a fun fast-paced shooter, and can be enjoyed not just by the FEAR veterans, but also the FEAR newbies.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												I was never really a big fan of the F.E.A.R. franchise, but this is too much, and not in a good way.Let's start with some good things:- the graphics in the game are pretty decent and good looking- the shooting style is good- it has co-op (favorite thing)Bad things:- the game is way to short (finished it for 5 hours)- not nearly as scary as the first two games- gets boring really soon (although it is so short)- the "story" is just stupid and almost non-existent Overall, if you can get it for a few coins and play it with a friend maybe, but just MAYBE, you should get it.If it wasn't for the co-op I wouldn't even finish the game. The last 2 hours of the gameplay I was just waiting for the game to end, and there is part where you are on a highway in a mecha or something for an hour, sounds awesome, but it isn't at all.I give it:3/10p.s. 3 points for available co-op.

Posted: August 1, 2011
												Well what can I say. Let's talk about gameplay. It's terrible. Yes the game may be a relatively small install but the replayability is pretty low. You can play as Point Man and then later unlock Fettel for the same level and experience different styles of combat and gameplay, not to mention that you can also go on co-op. The mutliplayer modes are well thought out and fun to play with different game types spanning possession, fighting against hordes of enemies; however it does become repetitive quickly.The storyline suffers from major plotholes. And it's terrible. Oh my is it terrible. I'm not saying that F.E.A.R. is the benchmark of storytelling but when you play F.E.A.R. & F.E.A.R. 2 Project Origin you will notice the huge drop in effort when it comes to story.I used to enjoy this game upon release but it's been well over 3 years since it came out and looking back retrospecitvely the entire game is awful. The horror is gone, Alma is no longer frightening, there is no depth and I really miss the JupiterFX engine that was in the previous 2 titles. I'm a ridiculously huge fan of F.E.A.R., to the point where I was an official moderator on the F.3.A.R. forums, received a free copy of the game, T-shirts, heck even a signed poster by the dev team. And yet... why is the game so bad? They just threw it out the window. And it's a real shame. I doubt we will ever get a F.E.A.R. 4 and the series ends on a flat note. Ridiculous. F.E.A.R. 3 is subpar. It stands nowhere near the previous iterations of the series by Monolith and you cannot help but wonder what went wrong. The characters of the story are not done any justice and the storyline is a shoddy mess. It's a horrible way to end the series and F.E.A.R. ended with a whimper, rather than a slo-mo explosion. TL;DR - Monolith shouldn't have given the game to Day 1 Studios to develop. Day 1 Studios screwed it up. Avoid game. Buy during 75%+ sale. Cry yourself to sleep knowing F.E.A.R. series ended badly.

Posted: June 26, 2011
												F.E.A.R. 3 is an unusual yet fun installment of the F.E.A.R. series. It is focused on the online aspect so the story of the game is told in a very fragmented and overall poor way, however this doesn't stop the levels from being fun. It reminds me of Modern Warfare 2 more than it does of the previous F.E.A.R. games. Thus, if you hate Modern Warfare you may want to wait until the game is cheaper.F.E.A.R. 3 is longer than other First Person Shooters of this generation. The game has eight levels with four modes of difficulty, with two characters to select from and a scoring system similar to Call of Duty's multiplayer challenges. All of this means that there is a lot of replay value to be had from this game.

												you play as Jordan Pointman, head zookeeper at your local Alma Park Zoo, situated in the heart of the Almaverse. when♥♥♥♥♥♥gets biblically weird, the zoo calls upon your expertise to round up the escaped animalssuddenly, you are haunted with frightening, poorly-animated models, 2d sprites and repressed images from your childhood. scared, scarred and terrified, Jordan Pointman is transformed; no longer a zookeeper, but the Almaverse's last hope of survival. strange, demonic species of animals spew into our realm, and it is up to you to utilize your Zookeeping skills to bag'n'tag the hellspawnas a zoo simulator, FEAR3 is lacking. there are limited amounts of animals, and the few animals that actually exist in the game are entirely fictitious. excluding rats and (poorly-animated, 2d) crows, there is insufficient fauna evident within the game. with 90% of the wildlife in the game being humanoid or blatantly demonic, FEAR3 will disappoint both animal lovers and zoophiles alike

												FEAR 3 is an enjoyable shooter that is more of an action game than a horror survival game. The graphics are decent when maxed out and slow motion makes the often frenetic shootouts very fun and rewarding. The story is ridiculously laughable, and while I played the two other FEAR games quite a long time ago, I don't quite remember them being as silly. The cutscenes do have their entertaining moments though. Overall, the game executes all the core fundamentals that make a first person shooter enjoyable and entertaining. While not groundbreaking or innovative, FEAR 3 is fun to play and has its challenging moments.

Posted: December 23, 2015
												Okay, before I say anyhting else, I would say, this is a really bad F.E.A.R. game. If they had called it something else, it would have been alright. Also, not sure why they didn't include local co-op when it's clearly a direct port from xbox including the clunky feel of the controls. Guess they just couldn't find enough corners to cut.This time you get to play both brothers (though you have to complete it with point man, the guy you play in the first game, before playign as Fettel). Fettel is by way the most enjoyable. Stealing other peoples bodies from across the room for surprise attacks was great fun and kind of wish I could find a better game with something like this. Shooting people is quite satifying as well. Unfortunately that's pretty much it for good stuff.On the bad, I don't want to give the plot away, but in short, there is no fear in this game (if you know even the basics of the original storyline, you'll know what I mean pretty quickly), so it comes down to just killing people, the reasons for which are totally explained (aren't they actually on your side?! Aren't they trying to do what you want to do?!!). If fact, the whole storyling makes no sense. When you play as Fettel (a dead guy floating around as a spirit) you can get shot at, which also makes no sense, at all, even less in the context of the game. I have to also mention there is this dead space rip off bit which is just annoying and the games end kind of blew my mind, for mostly the wrong reasons. You do get to drive some mechs, which is kinda cool, until you play as fettel, then it is just plain annoying. It's also pretty short, I'd say the shortest of the F.E.A.R. games, but I could be wrong. I could whinge more but I'll stop there.If you've never played a F.E.A.R. game, well, you could find more enjoyment in this than I did.

Posted: February 29, 2016
												F.E.A.R. 3 is a game with a serious identity crisis. Developed by Day 1 Studios instead Monolith (although they were apparently creatively involved), this is a seriously weak conclusion to a promising trilogy, with much of the signature creepiness and atmosphere plucked out in favour of imitating modern day shooters. Does it want to be a horror game, or does it want to be your standard points-based shooter with generic enemies?I recently played through F.E.A.R. 2 for the first time and enjoyed it, feeling that its shooting mechanics were great fun. It just felt smooth and easy to play through, with a couple of unsettling moments along the way that helped to make up for its less-than-stellar story. I guess I've always had an issue with the way this series tells its story, never quite fleshing out Alma Wade as a truly menacing presence, and being too cryptic about how the whole thing comes together. This wasn't really a major problem with the first two games though, as the frantic shooting and solid slo-mo mechanics more than made up for it. Perhaps the biggest issue with F.E.A.R. 3 is that most of the horror elements have been sucked out in favour of copying Call of Duty. This is a co-op shooter now, with a points system based on certain actions within the game. Co-op in horror games almost always dilutes the impact of the experience, and while I didn't get to try out the game with another person, I can't help but feel that these elements have affected what's here. Many of the scenarios within involve simply moving from one area to another, clearing out a bunch of soldiers along the way and maybe a few monsters later on. It isn't that there aren't some creepy moments (one early sequence wading through a warehouse with a bunch of flickering TV's is actually pretty effective) but they're thrown into a generic shell. The shooting is quite well done, with decent guns, and the tried-and-tested slo-mo effect helping you to take out enemies effectively, but it's just all very... "meh".By the end of F.E.A.R. 3 I felt like I'd sort of slogged my way through it just to see how the story concludes. I never felt truly invested due to how different the game feels from its predecessors, and the attempt to copy COD and modern shooters has drained much of the personality that previously existed. This is just a generic shooter now; a slightly painful limp to the conclusion of a story that was never brilliantly told from the beginning. You'll be playing this purely to finish out the trilogy, not because it's a good game. It doesn't stand out, it's not unique and it'll make you appreciate Monolith's two strong efforts all the more.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												After noticing that their price during the sale was FIVE DOLLARS, I actually had to delete my previous review because after playing F.E.A.R. some more and watching clips of it and Project Origin in another person's review, I felt I'd not explained ENOUGH just how much of a trainwreck this game is. The F.E.A.R. feeling is entirely gone. The gameplay is derivative and uninteresting unless you play as Paxton and they should have set it up like that in the first place instead of making you have to unlock him. Game looks, feels like dogshit compared to its predecessors.There, there's the whole game review. But that's actually less of the point. This game is like a cruel joke to those who liked the series. It has nothing to do with it gameplay wise. It's possibly the WORST ending to a trilogy in video game history. There's so much lore and story details that could make a person want to like it, but it honestly seems like the developer (not Monolith) was having a laugh at fans of the series. It literally feels like this was made in spite, and it's baffling considering Day 1 has made good games. They should have never made this game. They should have just made another Mechassault. For a moment, WB Games became the dumbest publisher ever. They reduced two silent, strong, badass protagonists to two uninteresting character, one of which has an extremely dull personality when he wasn't supposed to have one at all and one of which is a little ♥♥♥♥♥, making it seem like all of your actions were utterly in vain. Do not buy this game, even if it's really cheap, if you're a fan of the F.E.A.R. games and want to see how it ends. The only people this would probably appeal to are those who have never played any of the games in the series.Picture a clown laughing at you for ~5 hours before you whack your nutsack with a pool cue. Then, sticking your head up against the wall and don't STOP. DON'T. For another hour.That's F.E.A.R. 3.

												When i first played this mess of a game, i actually gave it a decent review. Hindsight is 20/20 i guess.  In reality, this game is HORRIBLE. God, where do i begin?  Graphics are ridiculously dated. Now i understand it's an older game, but that's not what i mean. The graphics in F.E.A.R. 2 are MUCH better. Gameplay is a joke, AI intelligence isn't and the story is stupid. oh, and the awards/achievements break immersion bigtime. The only redeeming feature is coop. so the majority of my score is for the coop. Avoid this stinker at all costs. If you are a F.E.A.R freak such as myself, only get it for completist purposes and then get it on huge discount on a Steam sale if you can. It's not worth much more than that. A sad and pitiful ending to a spectacular franchise. Final rating 2/10

Posted: March 11, 2016
												After the disappointment that was F.E.A.R. 2, Monolith decided to hand over the torch of mediocrity to Day 1 Studios, who in turn, dropped it into the ocean of incompetency, and drowned trying to retrieve it. The shooting components are noticeably weaker, nice to see the highlight of the series rammed even further into the ground. Mech sections make a return, because they worked so well in the second game, now a lot longer and more painful to plod through. The narrative is one of the worst I have seen, it started with an interesting premise in the first game and now has mutated into a despicable mess, devoid of any redeeming qualities. Giving the Point Man a voice and developing his character would have been a wise choice, engaging in dialogue with Fettel and expressing his thoughts and feelings about the chaos erupting around him. Instead we have Fettel trying his hardest to be unsettling and failing dismally, while Point Man gives him this hilarious look of contempt, which never leaves his face. I'm absolutely disgusted with how it ended, I didn't expect much but it really is abhorrent. As far as horror is concerned, Day 1 thinks that displaying butchered corpses and splattered blood in every corner is an effective way to drum up the scares, newsflash, it's not.A miserable way to end a trilogy.4/10

Posted: March 18, 2016
												A well made game in all rights and I will say that this is an ACTION game before it is a horror game unlike its predecessors.Multiplayer is good and feels well made but again it is DEADThe games story mode is done well yet short with only a few hours of gameplay to run through yet the leveling and point system creates competition during co-op gameplay which two players control two polar opposite characters. Player one takes on the role of Point Man which is pretty much that, he is the point man who goes in head on and guns down enemies with an arsenal of firepower and slow-mo gunplay. Player two plays as Fettel the main antagonist from F.E.A.R.: First Encounter Assault Recon who plays more as a support class with possessing enemy soldiers and using them for a limited time to use their weapons and back point man up.On the topic of the story is that there are two endings one is for Point Man (good ending) and the second is for Paxton Fettel (bad ending) and depending on which player has the highest score at the end of the game gets their ending but the solo campaign is solely Point Man's ending7/10 points needs a bit more horror to feel fearful of Gameplay 8/10Story 6/10Controls 8.5/10Multiplayer (If you can find a game) 7/10

Posted: November 26, 2013
												The campaign is decent, and if you get a friend along you'll have good fun(and some jumpscares too).The horror part has lost a bit versus more action and more shooting, but it's still there.The multiplayer part was a great adition tough, and even if it was underestimated it is one of the greatest aspects of the game.- "F**king Run" is an adrenalinic mode where you run away from almas wall of death all while fighting hordes of enemies.And believe me there is nothing more anxious than reviving a downed friend while seeing the wall of death aproach.The mode title couldn't been more hit on!- Contractions a round-based survival mode, where players must barricade and stock up weapons against a total of 20 waves of enemies.When the round ends stocks appear around the map that gives ammo and new weapons, all while trying to rebuild your shelters protection.The last few round are really hard so good team play is critical!So to sum it up, if you are looking for a really scary horror game, you should probably get any of the other good games around.If you are looking for a great action game to play with a friend, or some really fun and genuinely entertaining multiplayer modes, then this is most certainly for you!

Posted: November 26, 2013
												Well, it is not the Fear as it was before, but it actually is not that bad. The most refreshing element for me was the possibility to play as Fettel, it is fun to posses the enemies and rush it forward to collect souls or die, because you can actually die twice in this case - first possesed body, then Fettel. It is really fierce gameplay. As Pointman it is a bit generic,but...there are much worse FPShooters out there, so don't worry. Plus I liked the leveling up, which brings some more challange into it - like trying to get 50 headshots in a level, 20 kills without being hurt, etc. Yes, levels are simple and not very nice, enemies stupid (especially hellhounds and the freaks), but shooting them makes you feel good and that is what matters in any FPS.

Posted: August 17, 2011
												This is a wonderful game that really adds to the Fear series. The graphics look awesome and very well done. The multiplayer is totally awesome but can sometimes be hard to find people to play with. It is a game that can be play with a friend on singleplayer co-op. It is so much fun to play through the entire campaign with a friend. The sounds at times are really creepy and can give you the chills when you dont know were the enemy is and all you hear is the footsteps. The combat is what makes this game really shine, its really well done. The story can be confusing at times, so its a game that needs to be beaten a couple of times to really understand what is going on. I would suggest playing the previous Fear's to really understand this story better. This isn't as scary as  the previous 2 in the in the Fear series but it really does bring something unique.  I've loved playing this game and its a great one to pick up, I've enjoyed this greatly awesome game and I know you will too!

Posted: February 6, 2016
												Altough I recommend, be warned. This almost feels like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ cousin of Farcry, the Farcry that was hidden under the sofa from the neighbours. I would only suggest this for big fans of the series.Graphics:- Good, rich environments and very varying techniques. I thoroughly enjoyed the visual quality of this game. But it clearly looks like a console game. The performance is good, but I did have to drop my Antisotropic Filtering slightly which baffles me?Sounds:- Good, realistic and believable but suffers from the same problem as Fear 2 in that the music is cued and sometimes kicks off in strange intervals during a fire-fight.Gameplay:- This game is not scary. It is deviod of scares and just doesn't have the same element of fright as 1 & 2.- The environments are varied, and are done justice. Altough I do not like the fact that the game starts in Brazil, it was believeable.- Not all of the guns are useful, I hated the Combat Shotgun and only used the pistol when I was forced to. SOme weapons were absolutely useless.- The AI sucks, it seems to have gotten worse as the series has progressed.- The game is riddled with FMVs. FMVs? Is this the 90s? Is this Final Fantasy? I don't want FMVs in my action-shooters, I want action.Story:- Load of crap. It feels like multiple people had their opinions and ideas added and removed as the story progressed and the full view was just hard to follow and uninteresting.- I do like that they included The Point Man, Paxton Fettel & Becket, but the weaving of the characters together is so forced it feels like it's being helf together by super-glue and band-aids.- The protagonist (The Point Man) is so unlikeable it's ridiculous. He looks like a serial-killer and acts like someone who would NEVER have been accepted into the F.E.A.R. operatives in the first place.- The game starts in Brazil. Brazil? of all places, why Brazil? It's so far removed and misplaced. Guantanamo Bay, I could still believe, but a random slum in Brazil? WTF?

Posted: June 17, 2016
												Most say that F.E.A.R.3 sucks compared to the other F.E.A.R.'s. I disagree.  I believe F.E.A.R. 3 is a great game, it has a great storyline, great gameplay and if you pair up with a friend this game can easily provide hours of fun. I own this game on XB360 and PS3, I'm now working on 100%ing it on Steam. F.E.A.R. 3 was the first in the serious I played, and there were plenty of times I felt my heart race. It's more action centered than the others, but still able to give a few scares to an unsuspecting player. If you've played the other two games, the controls are a bit awkward to re-learn but everything has a great feel to it. The only downside to this game is unlike the first two, you only get two guns and they sadly aren't carried over after the chapter. Which for someone who loves snipers like I do, it sucks only being able to use them at some points. I highly recommend giving this game, this series a chance.

Posted: June 18, 2016
												Firstly, I have played all the F.E.A.R. games and can say they are amazing.  The immersion is incredible once you are sucked into the story it has you.  The scare factor is way up there and jump scares are out of control scary as hell.  I played the first two in Iraq and was terrified with my headphones on while others slept.  It has a very well executed ambiance that makes you look around the room more than play sometimes.  I would have to take smoke breaks just for my sanity.  I have played all the silent hill games to completion and this games ranks with those titles in my opinion.  If you are going to get a fear game then start from the beginning because the story carries throughout and gets weirder and weirder as you progress.  The movement and shooting along with A.I is on point and very difficult at times but the payoff is worth it.  If you are a whiny baby then play with a friend to make yourself feel like an adult I guess?

Posted: April 17, 2015
												I bought this game on HumbleBundle for around five bucks and I even finished the game. Here's my final verdict, splitted into Pros and Cons :)Pros:- The graphics are pretty good- Cutscenes are very decent- In-game cutscenes are seamless- Animations are smoothly, like the enemies' movements- The game runs extremely smoothly, no framedrops etc- The blood and gore is decent and there (but there could be more)- Fights can be pretty intense. Hard, but fun!- The weapons have a great impact and it's very satisfying to decapitate a enemy with a sniper rifle.- There is no direct safe / load option, but there is a checkpoint system. Normally I absolutey dislike a pure checkpoint system, but here it's done very well! Thumbs up.- Some levels were plain awesome. Like the one in the store with all those TVs. Awesome! I also liked it that there were same parts of levels where I was able to mount a Mech. Nice.- Auto-regnerating health. While many players hate this, I welcome this. Because I'm a bad player with no skills, so thanks for that.Things I don't judge:- Levels are very linear. I don't mind linear gameplay as long as the action keeps going.Cons:- Very few (but great!) weapons- No akimbo mode for pistols (but for Uzis, somehow)- The ranking system. Do I really need this?- The story. I didn't followed the story of any FEAR game. Same here, never was interested in.- Enemies are invulnerable while animated (while they are jumping over a crate for example)- The boss battle in interval 8 ist plain boring.- Even for me as a bad gamer, the game seems kinda short.- What the hell can I do with Fettel after I unlocked him for a mission? I never found out, to be honest.- Same with those zombies. They're still standing after three close range blasts of a shotgun. What the hell? And those knive throwing idiots in the beginning of the game, I felt like I'm in BIOSHOCK.- I got REALLY tired of those moments where you automatically start to walk slow, your slomo-option is disabled and you know that something will appear. Bored the hell out of me.- The later levels, screaming Alma and always that babbling Fettel. I know, it's probably part of the story but it annoyed the hell out of me.In conclusion, FEAR3 is a good ego shooter which will serve a few hours of fun. Don't expect much, because you won't get much.

Posted: March 29, 2016
												Despite a too-short campaign and repetitive levels, FEAR 3 is still a good finale to one of the most unique first-person shooter franchises I've ever played. The weapons are fun, blowing bad guys away in slow-mo remains satisfying, the scares are lethal and the graphics are still quite impressive, with a lot of really beautiful lighting effects. When it comes to the FEAR series, one thing that I've always loved about them is how the genius of each instalment lies in the mixing of cinematic elements of Asian horror with 80s action films. Perhaps the series as a whole could be best described as The Ring meets Die Hard. However, this wouldn't do it justice, these games are well worth playing, both for the casual gamer and the survival horror aficionado. Hopefully someday we can see a fourth one!

Posted: April 20, 2016
												FEAR is considered the last "classic" shooter, coming out shortly after Half Life 2.  A unique game in that it takes a survival horror atmosphere but doesn't pretend to be a survival horror game. It's balls to the wall in your face up your♥♥♥♥♥licks your boobies action in slow motion firing an automatic flak cannon at supersoldiers with tourettes in the middle of an office complex. Naturally once people realized that the game was not an independent shooter and was actually published by a big name corporation they pretended that they didn't like it as much as they really did.When the sequel came out it recieved pretty much nothing but praise because all of the nerds that want to look cool and pretend they don't like something popular couldn't deny the fact that they all fired off a couple broken arrows to the thought of Alma slamming them against the wall and taking their virginity with her haunted hot pocket.As for the third game, it recieved a relatively "eh" reception. At this point I would have to agree, but only if you take the story into account. I prefer to ignore the story completely. I didn't like it that much in the first game and was disappointed that the sequel didn't just resolve everything so we could stop dwelling on Pointman's mommy issues and start fighting other weird stuff. I mean, the government didn't create a SWAT version of the X-Files for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles.In an attempt to make the story more grimdark everything became extremely convoluted and "edgy" with every other character suddenly being revealed to be worse than hitler every 15 minutes because they realized they needed to end the story with all the plot threads resolved. In order to resolve these plot threads they dropped like 20 nukes and then said "♥♥♥♥ it" and made it so that when Alma had contractions that would cause the planet to♥♥♥♥♥♥itself for some reason.Like I said, I don't care about the story, the action is what it's all about. The gun butt is replaced with a combat knife but you can still kick guys in the balls and kill them instantly. Weapons can be fired form the hip with limited effectiveness, slightly more accurately than the first and second game.It's really not that bad. It's not amazing, but it's pretty good. It's like Friday the 13th part IV. They're just phoning it in but that's cool because a lot of people die.

Posted: January 18, 2016
												Fear 3 is a surprisingly in-depth FPS in which you must contend with both the forces paranaormal entities and the evils of people with guns. It may feel like you're fighting hoardes of combine non-stop, but after a few waves you will understand that you are NOT playing another HL2 clone, you're playing an entirely fresh and original haunted FPS thriller.The fully interactive scenery is gorgeous, with many nooks and crannys to explore much like the original heart of all FPS monster shooters, Duke Nukem 3D. The gun variety is impressive with pistols, smgs, shotguns....The stages may look a little familiar from other games, and the ai is a bit dated, but dont let that deter you from this exciting and innovative FPS!

Posted: January 27, 2016
												I went into this game with low expectations. I was pleasantly surprised. I was told that there was no horror in this one, that's not true. The atmosphere and sound engineering are top notch in this game. The three things that divided fans most were that Alma takes a back seat role, the horror is minimized and the levels are too straightforward. Let's address those one by one. First, I personally like that Alma took a back seat role. After a Fear 1 and Fear 2 marathon I was getting really tired of seeing a naked girl or a little kid in a red dress run across my screen. It's nice to see the other creatures take over more. Second, the horror is minimized. No, it's not, not at all. There's just as much as Fear 2. And that's from someone who played all 3 over a weekend. Rather than use the same boring jump scares (although they're still there) this game aims more for atmosphere and sound tension. The dread of something jumping out actually makes the game pretty tense. Third, the levels are too straight-forward. I 100% agree. There is almost no collecting, it's all done by achievements this time around. Rather than finding a needle to get more slo-mo, you just kill X amount of enemies with X or something. And even then there is no curiosity about it, just go down the tunnel and kill everything. Another complaint is the “COD-ification” of Fear. Again, I agree, in this game you can only carry two weapons off the bat and barely any ammo. This also works in the games' favor as the action mechanics in this game are far and away the best. Gunplay is tight, and solid. Seriously, the shooting in this game is easily the best in the series. All the weapons are absolutely lethal and splatter enemies. Sadly, the health regen (which I personally hate) from COD is in this game as well. Also, because there is health regen, there are some seriously cheap deaths.+Best shooting mechanics in the seriesFluid gameplay (smooth FPS throughout)Great atmosphereAll the guns are useful againTwo playable characters give the levels some replayability (You can play as either Paxton Fettel or Point Man)-The scares themselves are a bit minimizedNo collection, just overused achievementsLazy level layoutNo medkitsOverall 8/10, it's not perfect, but I really enjoyed it

Posted: February 6, 2016
												I just finished this game after having it in my backlog for quite a long time and honestly part of me wished I didn't play this game at all because of how much I love F.E.A.R and F.E.A.R. 2. Don't play this if you loved the previous F.E.A.R. games, which sucks to say, but this is not the experience you'd want for a sequel.Performance/graphics:Performance is ok in the sense that I was able to play at 120fps most of the time, but did have dips on occasion, There aren't as many graphics options compared to the first two games, but there are still some. What really bothered me was the forced Motion Blur the game had and the only way to turn it off is via an options.cfg in the game's local folders. Not too big of an inconvenience, but definitely something they should have added in the game's options menus especially when it was toggable  in the previous two games. Graphics themselves are ok, still good looking, but honestly F.E.A.R. 2 looks way better, at leas to me.Combat:F.E.A.R. 3's combat is 100% different compared to the first two. Obviously they're all FPS games, but the actual weapon combat(aiming, weapon firing/response, etc.) is completely different and I don't think it was for the better. You're limited to only two weapons at a time, no medkits/armor pickups(regenerative health), but there is still slow-mo and vehicles in the game. Also there are still around the same amount of weapon variation in the game compared to the first two, but you're just limited to only two at a time which I think is a huge negative, but might be because of the co-op mode the game has, so to balance it out.Atmosphere:Still "scary", but compared to the first two games F.E.A.R. 3 is more action than horror and that's bad. I'm not sure if it was because of the co-op addition so they couldn't account for player positioning for jumpscares or scene build ups correctly, but the games are suppose to be scary, but this game probably only scared me once out of the four hours I played it.Story:I appreciate the closure the game has given me for wanting more after completely F.E.A.R. 2, but I wish I didn't experience this closure exactly. The game has two endings, one considered "Good" and one "Bad", but I'd say both are pretty bad. I won't post spoilers, but if you love F.E.A.R and F.E.A.R. 2, don't play this.Price:This game is not worth $19.99, not even close to that. I got it for $4.99 a while back and that's honestly all I would feel comfortable paying.

Posted: February 6, 2016
												Altough I recommend, be warned. This almost feels like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ cousin of Farcry, the Farcry that was hidden under the sofa from the neighbours. I would only suggest this for big fans of the series.Graphics:- Good, rich environments and very varying techniques. I thoroughly enjoyed the visual quality of this game. But it clearly looks like a console game. The performance is good, but I did have to drop my Antisotropic Filtering slightly which baffles me?Sounds:- Good, realistic and believable but suffers from the same problem as Fear 2 in that the music is cued and sometimes kicks off in strange intervals during a fire-fight.Gameplay:- This game is not scary. It is deviod of scares and just doesn't have the same element of fright as 1 & 2.- The environments are varied, and are done justice. Altough I do not like the fact that the game starts in Brazil, it was believeable.- Not all of the guns are useful, I hated the Combat Shotgun and only used the pistol when I was forced to. SOme weapons were absolutely useless.- The AI sucks, it seems to have gotten worse as the series has progressed.- The game is riddled with FMVs. FMVs? Is this the 90s? Is this Final Fantasy? I don't want FMVs in my action-shooters, I want action.Story:- Load of crap. It feels like multiple people had their opinions and ideas added and removed as the story progressed and the full view was just hard to follow and uninteresting.- I do like that they included The Point Man, Paxton Fettel & Becket, but the weaving of the characters together is so forced it feels like it's being helf together by super-glue and band-aids.- The protagonist (The Point Man) is so unlikeable it's ridiculous. He looks like a serial-killer and acts like someone who would NEVER have been accepted into the F.E.A.R. operatives in the first place.- The game starts in Brazil. Brazil? of all places, why Brazil? It's so far removed and misplaced. Guantanamo Bay, I could still believe, but a random slum in Brazil? WTF?

Posted: March 11, 2016
												After the disappointment that was F.E.A.R. 2, Monolith decided to hand over the torch of mediocrity to Day 1 Studios, who in turn, dropped it into the ocean of incompetency, and drowned trying to retrieve it. The shooting components are noticeably weaker, nice to see the highlight of the series rammed even further into the ground. Mech sections make a return, because they worked so well in the second game, now a lot longer and more painful to plod through. The narrative is one of the worst I have seen, it started with an interesting premise in the first game and now has mutated into a despicable mess, devoid of any redeeming qualities. Giving the Point Man a voice and developing his character would have been a wise choice, engaging in dialogue with Fettel and expressing his thoughts and feelings about the chaos erupting around him. Instead we have Fettel trying his hardest to be unsettling and failing dismally, while Point Man gives him this hilarious look of contempt, which never leaves his face. I'm absolutely disgusted with how it ended, I didn't expect much but it really is abhorrent. As far as horror is concerned, Day 1 thinks that displaying butchered corpses and splattered blood in every corner is an effective way to drum up the scares, newsflash, it's not.A miserable way to end a trilogy.4/10
